column9: Kellie Ryan is a 26 year old kindergarten teacher who at the start of 2018 had seen a number of life changes.  She moved in to her first apartment, had a new car, and adopted a rescue dog.  She loved her job, her kindergarten kids, and life in general was going very well for her.  Sadly, things quickly changed.  On January 15, a routine blood test had anything but routine results.  She was awakened by a 2:00 AM phone call from her doctor saying she was critically anemic and missing half of her body's blood.  A trip to the ER resulted in a prescription, which caused severe abdominal distention and pain.  Another ER trip resulted in another prescription that accomplished nothing.  A return to the ER that same day caused Kellie to be admitted to the hospital, where she would remain for 12 days.  The last of numerous exams and tests determined Kellie's situation was caused by a large abdominal mass.  Emergency surgery was performed and lab testing determined she had Stage 4 colon cancer.Several days later Kellie left the hospital and has had the first of what will be many chemotherapy treatments.  Her life is now anything but normal, and a far cry from where it was just a few weeks ago.  She and her family met with cancer experts from USC and UCLA who recommended specialized testing and more probable surgeries.  She was placed on disability, resulting in a substantial decrease in her paycheck.  Sadly she also had to return her dog to the rescue foundation as she was unable to physically care for him.   Kellie will undergo more chemo sessions, blood testing, exams, meetings with expert doctors, and additional surgeries.  She badly needs genetic testing to try and determine why a healthy 26 year old, with no family history of colon cancer, has been stricken with this disease.  Sadly, her insurance has denied coverage for that urgently needed test. Your donations will immediately be used to pay for this genetic test that could determine the best course of action to treat her cancer. This will hopefully help get her back into class with her kindergarten kids, who she misses so much.  Kellie is and will be facing expensive medical bills in addition to her rent, car payments, insurance and other expenses.  She has never been one to ask for help unless it's absolutely necessary.  Any and all money received in this Go Fund Me account will be used for the current, pending, and future expenses not covered so she may continue to lead a semi-normal life while trying to get the treatment and help she needs.  In keeping with her love for kids, Kellie has determined any and all unneeded funds will be donated to St. Jude's Children's Hospital, so others even younger than she will also get the help they need and deserve.      Kellie, her family, and friends thank you in advance for all of your support.

Where to start…I Need Help!!!I find myself in one crazy situation. I am a 44 year old mother of three children (JJ-5, Nyah-9, and Izzy-17). I need HELP!!! I’m trying to raise $300,000.000, half of which I  need ASAP for a deposit. I desperately need a surgery, Hyperthermic Intraperitoneal Chemotherapy, known as HIPEC. HIPEC is an up and coming surgery to treat different forms of abdominal cancers. I have a very rare and aggressive form of ADRENAL CANCER called Adrenal Cortical Carcinoma (ACC).  ACC is called a “Terrorist” cancer, an “Orphan” cancer. ACC is relentlessly aggressive and extremely rare. I have limited treatment options and very little time. I have been battling with ACC for 2 years. I am statistically approaching the end of my road. My Oncologist and I have exhausted every conventional form of treatment for my ACC. We started with surgery combined with radiation therapy and it returned in less than 2 months. After my recurrence in July of 2017, we hit it with almost a year of intense chemotherapy. A 3 chemo cocktail that has left me disabled and suffering from a pulmonary embolism. The embolism ended my remaining systemic chemo treatments. My tumors have responded well to the chemo, and there has been significant shrinkage, but the 4 tumors are still in the peritoneal lining of my abdomen. During HIPEC, what is left of my tumors will be removed, then Dr. Miller will apply heated chemo directly into my abdomen. I will be the very first ACC patient to be treated with HIPEC at the University of Michigan Cancer Center.  This treatment can give me years instead of months. Without this surgery, I will not live long enough to see my two youngest children finish grade school. I have insurance, my husband and I purchased our heath insurance through the ACA Marketplace, and I am grateful to the ACA. Without its protections for pre-existing conditions I wouldn’t have had the last 2 years with my family. Unfortunately, treatments provided out of network and out of state ARE NOT COVERED. Like I said before, my cancer is extremely rare and very aggressive, less than one in a million rare, and only three surgeons in the United States perform this surgery for ACC patients. I have started this Go Fund Me page because, like I said, my insurance won’t cover this cancer-busting procedure, and I am running out of time.With your help in funding this surgery, to be done by the ADRENAL CANCER research team at University of Michigan, HIPEC is my opportunity and small window to be with my family for hopefully many more years. I have hope, my family has hope, that I can actually beat this cancer, but soon the tumors will become too large and HIPEC will no longer be a viable option.  We are not a family to easily ask for help, but cancer changes your perspective on many things. Please help us by donating. Every little bit helps in a big way.FINANCIAL GOAL:Our financial goal is $300,000.00. A jaw dropping amount of money, but the surgery is expensive. Your donations in any amount will help cover the following:-Travel expenses between Phoenix, Arizona & Ann Arbor, Michigan-HIPEC Surgery, a 12-14 hour surgery-8 to10 days in the ICU and the hospital-Follow up visits for 2 weeks after my release from U of M, with my ACC specialist, Dr. Gary Hammer, and my surgeon, Dr. Barbra Miller. -Medication,Tests, and imaging-Accommodations for myself and my family for 4 to 5 week stay in Ann Arbor   -Paid help for me, and childcare for Nyah and JJ, as recovery is estimated at 6-9 months.

The Adamo Family needs our help! This gofundme account has been created to help with funeral, medical and just all expenses as they navigate this incredibly difficult time in their lives. Update from Sarah: Today (Thursday) at about 1:50 PM Mountain time, Jacob met his creator face to face. I have no words, no emojis to give. My soul is numb. His body didn't want to go anymore and things started failing.I have one more request... pray for wisdom and the wherewithal to get through the next few days. There will be lots of decisions to be made.I'm headed home to love on my babies. And to tell them how much their Daddy loved them. ❤ Thank you for your prayers and support during this time. As soon as we have a date for his service, I will let you all know. ❤From Sarah: April 8, 2018 Update on Jacob... went to the ER... and he had some blood tests. For those nerdy friends his bilibuben level was 39...and his creatinine was at 8 (.5 to 1 is normal for his age). The doc said he needed a specialist (hepatologist) so he is en-route to Denver (UC Health in Aurora) ICU via ambulance where he is getting a CT scan. The pic is him just leaving the ER for the ambulance. I am on my way down with Thea (his mom). We will then get an official diagnoses.How am I? Wrecked. My birthday is tomorrow and our 15th anniversary is Thursday and the worst case stuff discussed in the ER were things like "kidney failure" and "transplant". Not the words you want to hear.The kids are at home being cared for. I am going to try and keep Mike Marlow updated as to his condition and for those that are local Leslie Marshall has set up a Meal Train (  https://mealtrain.com/68g4nk ) and a fundraiser to help with travel expenses. You can also reach out to Thea Adamo or Sherma Cundall if you cannot get ahold of me right away.Please pray for answers and for healing, for my sanity, and for our kids as we walk this out. I don't know how long I'm going to be down in Denver with him... just all the nitty gritty details are up in the air right now. Thank you so much to everyone who have already jumped in. I'm so thankful for you.I will update as soon as I know more.

On Sunday, August 12th, Derek Dietz unexpectedly went into Cardiac Arrest. He is currently in ICU and fighting for his life. Derek has a wife (Katie) and two small children (Jaxson and Peyton). Anyone who has had the pleasure of knowing Derek, knows what a great guy he is and how he would do absolutely anything for anyone. He is a doting husband, father, son, brother and friend. We’re putting this page together to help the Dietz family with unforeseen medical expenses and just expenses in general since Derek is obviously unable to work. Katie hasn’t left his side and therefor also is unable to work. Anything you are able to contribute to help them out would be greatly appreciated! Let’s all pray for a speedy recovery for Derek! You’ve got this Dietz

As many of you are aware, we recently received sad news regarding our beloved friend Duane (Dewey) Wallace.  Duane is battling cancer and going through treatment.Duane has been the lead staff member in the Locker House.  He has not only trained many of the young men who have worked there over the years, but set the culture for what makes each one of us feel so special when we walk through those doors. His absence is palpable. Duane is a key-stone in the Kirtland family and has had a large impact on each of us whether known or unknown. We feel that it would be a great gesture of gratitude and huge help to Duane and his family if we could pitch in to help him through this difficult process. We are all thinking good thoughts, but also know that any monetary help  we can provide would make a difference and mean a lot to Duane and his family.  All donations will be pooled and given to Duane on behalf of the membership.We appreciate your consideration. Thank you,Sam Ahuja and Woods King

https://itunes.apple.com/us/album/fight-song/1061182666?i=1061182684 Typically a post containing the name Fred Bachmann and Xiomara Bachmann is  filled with exciting training sessions, soccer tournament wins/highlights and wrestling championships.  This one is a bit different.  Their daughter Xiolani, who we all know as vivacious and energetic, a real hustler out on the soccer field and an all around sweet-natured kid is battling an illness that we still do not have a diagnosis for.  It is with a heavy heart that we write this message about Lani.  This young lady is in the fight of her life right now.  Lani has not been able to walk or talk for over a week and is currently at Dupont Hospital.  Fred and Xiomara were informed on Sunday that their 8 year old girl was being admitted to the intensive care unit and Lani would have to immediately start an invasive procedure call plasmapheresis in order to stabilize her condition.  The entire Bachmann community-family, friends, colleagues and sports community is devastated by this news.  Fred and Xiomara will be out of work for an extended period of time and their income is going to be drastically reduced as a result.  Unfortunately, the long term recovery for Lani will take months and her parents will have to miss a lot of work to support her recovery once the doctors stabilize her condition.  We have decided to start a Go Fund Me page for Lani.  Fred and Xiomara have no idea as they would certainly not allow it to be done.  Anyone who knows them knows they are not the type to ask for anything.  We have all watched Fred train wrestlers and soccer players over the years and never ask for a penny nor recognition. I know, from private conversations, he truly looks at these kids and parents as extended family members.  He truly loves watching all kids succeed-not just his own.  Xiomara has opened up her home to many families throughout the year and has willingly picked up the duties at home when Fred was spending a great deal of time helping others.  Lani, Fred and Xiomara are in need of all of our help.  Many loved ones are offering support in many ways and the last week has been incredible to see in terms of how good people can be when a family is brought to their knees.   The financial cushion that we are trying to raise will allow Fred and Xiomara to focus on Lani without the stress of worrying about finances.Lani is an incredible  soccer player who has excelled on the field as well as in the classroom.  Her smile is infectious and her good natured spirit has touched many.  She will beat this illness and come back stronger than ever!!!

*UPDATE: Sweet Emily passed away early this morning ( 06/01) due to her injuries. We are all devastated by her death. On Sunday May 27th, our dear friend Anne Humpherys along with her two granddaughters Emily (8) and Hannah (6) were hit by a driver under the influence. This resulted in the death of Anne Humpherys and left Emily at Loma Linda hospital on life support. Luckily, Hannah left without any injury. We are trying to raise donations as a way to ease the burdens placed upon the Humpherys/Boyd family. These donations will be used for funeral services and medical bills and other recovery expenses. Anything you can give will make a difference!

As some of you know, our Principal at LBHS, Dr. Trent Daniel, discovered last week that her son, Britton has a rare form of bone cancer. Britton is a senior at Oviedo High School, where he excels in academics as well as athletics. He will need to undergo 12 months of treatment beginning this week. Trent and her family will make countless trips to Gainesville, as well as accrue monumental medical expenses. Here’s how you can help:1. Donate. Remember, no amount is too small.2. Share this on social media3. Email friends this linkThank you and God Bless Britton

Funds raised will go towards taking financial pressure off this young hard working family in this time of great need and heartache. Jim and Michelle have always been first to put their hands up to help others both through not-for-profit Organizations and on personal levels. Now is our chance  to truly help them.

￼￼For those of you that that may not know on 3/26 Jody Brue had a debilitating stroke that caused a massive brain bleed that has affected the right side of his brain. Subsequently, he required a lifesaving surgery where the doctors had to remove part of the skull to allow his brain to swell without causing any more damage. Currently he has limited movement on the left side of his body, but he was able to say his name and give his wife Cara a high five. He has a feeding tube but hopefully it will come out soon!!  The next step is at least 6 more weeks in the hospital, an intense couple of weeks of stroke therapy at an inpatient facility and most likely followed by an extended stay in a professional nursing facility where he will continue therapy until he is able to go home. We have a very long road ahead of us, but Jody has an AMAZING, MAGICAL, UNBELIEVEABLE group of friends and family that surrounds him.  With all that said, even with insurance medical bills can be a HUGE financial burden. From doctor’s bills, insurance co-pays, and LOST WAGES we are increasing our gofundme goal to go towards financial assistance to meet Jody’s family needs! We are grateful for all the donations so far. Even if you are not able to donate we ask you to share this link so others can help and share the love.  We cannot thank each and everyone of you enough. We are truly blessed to have the support we do. More about our dear friend Jody Brue: Jody is 43 years young and has shared an amazing 18 years with his wife Cara.  He is also blessed with 2 beautiful kids, McKay 17 and Zoe 16. He is such a positive and encouraging person that always has a smile to give. Please help us support this amazing family. #BrueCrewStrong

Behind every great man stands an even greater woman and some woman rarely takes credit for everything her husband has accomplished.  That last part is not Judy.  She is very vocal for being the rock that has made Brian a great man; our mentor, our coach, our teammate, our brother, and our hero.  Joking aside, for everything that Brian has done for us we have Judy to thank.  It is her endless support and love for Brian that allows him to give back to the community.  This time Judy and Brian need us.Judy was diagnosed with a rare cervical cancer in January.  Despite rounds of chemo, the aggressive cancer has spread and doctors have recommended palliative care.  Judy and Brian are continuing to find options for a cure.  It is a tough and grueling journey.  But those who know Judy; she isn't giving up.  Born and raised in the mean streets of Chicago Chinatown, Judy is prepared to fight this.  As friends and families have offered support and prayers, we created this GoFundMe page to help with medical expenses and other costs.  100% of the donations will go entirely to the Hales.  Thank you for your generosity!  Please leave a note or favorite story of Judy.  We will forward all messages to Judy and Brian.  If you ever had the chance to watch Judy and Brian look at each other, you see the truest of love.  22 years of being together.  22 years of love, laughter, and 12 years of being husband and wife.  Behind every great man stands an even greater woman.  Judy: our mentor, our coach, our teammate, our sister, and our hero.

My name is Suzanne Tieder and I'm the proud aunt and godmother to Andrew Trouts - my loving, joyful three year old nephew. I'm here to ask you for your prayers and help as Andrew begins his brave journey to fight and BEAT Burkitt's Leukemia. Just three weeks ago, Melissa and Chris took Andrew to their pediatrician to diagnose and treat a lump on the side of his face. After two rounds of antibiotics and several stumped doctors, Andrew was admitted to the Children's Hospital of Philadelphia (CHOP). Days later, a battery of tests confirmed that he has stage four blood cancer.  Andrew received the first of many upcoming chemo treatments on Friday, March 30. Because the cancer is aggressive, doctors have put him on a chemo treatment plan that will last six to eight months, with most of his  time being spent at CHOP. We are optimistic that at the end of Andrew's journey, he will stand tall, proud, victorious and ready to continue his life as a survivor. In order for Melissa and Chris to provide the full time care and love so critical to Andrew's healing process, they need to work reduced hours, thus immediately foregoing their full time salaries for the duration of Andrew's treatment and recovery. To help them cover the lost wages and Andrew's increasing costs of medical care, I am kindly asking for your generosity. Every thought, prayer, positive vibe, and contribution will help Andrew stay strong and WIN. On behalf of the Trouts, Branyans, Tieders, and Andrew's extended family, I sincerely thank you for your show of support and standing by Melissa, Chris and Andrew's brothers, Conner (eight) and William (five) during this trying time. As they say, it takes a village, and in this case, #TeamAndrew. I'll be updating Andrew's gofundme page regularly so we can all keep track of his progress and cheer him on together. If there is a private message you would like me to send to Melissa, Chris, or Andrew, please feel free to do so by connecting with me here. Much love and thanks,SuzanneAndrew just turned three April 1! He's planning his second helping of birthday cake...Andrew was SO exicted to see his brothers, Conner (left) & William (right)! Andrew and his Mr. Potato head crew. :)

Hello, My wife Kaylene and I have never met Gabby yet we remember her from years ago when her story first aired in 2004. We saw Gabby on the news on May 23rd and were again touched by this amazing young woman. We decided to help and set up this GoFundMe page so she can get the smile she deserves! The funds will go to her and her family which will help to pay for the estimated $120,000 in medical costs that her insurance will not cover. View her story at  https://www.kare11.com/video/news/girl-who-cant-feel-pain-battles-insurance-company/89-8138661. Thanks to all of you for your donations and support!

Japanese Tourists Brutally Attacked in Kaka’akoOn Memorial Day, Japanese tourists, Masashige Tamura and his family, were spending what was supposed to be the last day of their dream vacation taking photos of the colorful murals that adorn the streets of Kaka’ako.  Instead a quick stop to use the public bathroom at Mother Waldron Park turned into a nightmare for Masashige and his family.  At this time, he cannot recall much of what happened when he entered the bathroom that day but it is evident he was brutally attacked by at least one person.  He suffers from cracked cheek bones, a cracked skull, deep cuts on his face, dislodged teeth and damaged gums and is obviously deeply traumatized.His wife, Miho Tamura, who ran to the bathroom when she heard the screams, was choked from behind till she passed out.  She suffers from deep cuts on her lips, bruises on her neck and face as well as lasting pain on her entire face.  She too is obviously deeply traumatized.  Somewhat fortunate, their two children (19 and 21years old) were not near them at the time (they were taking photos of the murals) or they may have been assaulted as well.The Tamura’s were rushed to Queen’s Hospital where they were told they would have to be hospitalized for at least 10 days.  Because they were tourists, their insurance would not cover the hospital bill.  The Tamura’s made the difficult decision to fly back to Japan the following day even though Masashige was in no condition to fly.  Back in Japan he could get the proper medical insurance coverage.  He went straight from the airport to the hospital and has been there ever since.  His condition is much worse than anyone imagined but they are glad at least he is still alive.  His next surgery is scheduled for June 9th.To the people of Hawaii, let’s show this family what true Aloha is all about!  This family did not deserve this…no one deserves this!  My name is Shoko and I live in Kaka’ako.  I was visiting Mother Waldron Park that faithful day with my 1 & 5year old daughters when I recognized some Japanese tourists were in distress.  Being raised in Japan, I rushed over to see if I could help.  I ended up translating to the police and doctors for the Tamura’s and taking their children to the hospital and visiting them.  I have remained in touch with them in Japan and really want to do something for them.  100% of the money raised from this site will go to the Tamura Family.  Pease donate anything you can!  No amount is too small!  Thank you!  I as a creator of this page, I will withdraw all the donation and send 100% of it to Tamura Family at my biggest responsibility. The funds will be spent for the medical bills that cannot covered by their insurance, recovery cost they need after surgery, to help with daily expenses until he is able to go back to work, to help to heal their hearts, to help to heal both physically and mentally distressed. Also, please share this with family and friends as a warning that we all must be careful and vigilant of our surroundings.  This could have happened to anyone.  Masashige was truly in the wrong place at the wrong time!ハワイ在住のShokoと申します。2018年5月28日にカカアコ地区で日本人観光客のご家族に起きた暴行事件。私は当時、たまたま子供達を連れて事件の起こった公園に入った時ちょうど事件が起きた直後でした。遠くから見て、男性1人が血まみれで座り込んでおり周りにいた3名の方もパニック状態でいるのがすぐにわかったと同時に日本人観光客とすぐにわかったので、大丈夫ですかと声をかけました。そこから、ご家族と警察、救急隊員、病院のナースなど通訳としてヘルプさせて頂きながら事件の全てそしてご家族の状況を目の当たりにしました。ご家族はハワイ滞在最終日に、最近話題になっているカカアコ地区のウォールアートを見に来ていて、お父様の正茂さんがたまたま入った公園のトイレで事件が起きました。正茂さん曰く、トイレに入って間もなく襲われたそうでその瞬間から記憶が全くありません。様子がおかしい事に気付いた奥様の美穂さんがすぐに確認しようと後を追いましたがトイレに入る直前で別の誰かに背後から首を絞められその場で気絶してしまいました。息子さんと娘さんはこの時幸いにも公園外のウォールアートの写真をとっていて、事件後に駆けつけたそうです。正茂さんと美穂さんは救急車で緊急搬送され、応急処置や検査などを受けた後、約10日間程の入院になりそうと診断されました。正茂さんの怪我の状態:頬の骨陥没おでこ左側深い切り傷歯茎から折られる頭を支える骨にヒビが入った為、髄液が流出両目とも開かない程腫れがる精神的ダメージ美穂さんの怪我の状態:唇の損傷 首、顔面のあざ顔面の痛み精神的ダメージ今すぐにでも手術が必要とされる中、不運にも海外旅行保険に加入されていなかった為に莫大な治療費となってしまい、事件翌日の飛行機で怪我を負ったまま日本へ帰るしかない状況に置かれてしまいました。幸いにも無事に日本に到着し、空港からまっすぐ病院へ向かい、正茂さんは緊急入院となりました。検査の方も進み、思った以に酷い状況であることが発覚し、次の手術予定日が6月9日と決まっています。集まった募金は私が責任を持って100%全て田村さんご家族に送ります。保険適用にならない分のハワイでかかった治療費、病院代、手術後の手当て、心の治療、お仕事に復帰できるようになるまでの日々のコストなど、そしてお見舞金として使われる予定です。私の周りのローカル達が、田村さんご家族の為にたくさんのアロハを送ってあげようと言ってくれて一緒に決めたゴール金額です。せっかくの家族ハワイ旅行でまさかこんな事件にあってしまうなんて、誰も想像すらできません。ハワイ在住の方、日本在住の方、世界中の方々、1円でも構いませんのでどうかサポートして頂けると嬉しいです！募金で集まった金額100%全て田村さんご家族に寄付されます。どうかよろしくお願いいたします。

Hello My Name is Renee, I am one of Faith long term friends. Many of you are personal friends of Faith and are familiar with her story and love her dearly. We absolutely need a miracle for Faith in the next couple of weeks. For those of you who have or have not followed Faith’s healing journey here’s what’s happening: Faith needs your financial help! There is nothing more that her Oncologist or Surgeon can do for her, she is in the lates stages of Stage 4 Mestatic Breast Cancer. Because it has already metastasized, ( spread to her spine ) It has the potential to spread very quickly to her major organs, it’s hard to say exactly how long she has. She is in the process of phasing our out of her job, as her health is seemingly declining. We don’t know how long she has, it could be just a series of months. Needless to say she is in need of a miracle. Faith has been accepted as a patient for experimental treatment at CHIPSA Hospital. This treatment will cost $33,427.17 This will cover 3 weeks of inpatient treatment, 3 meals a day, her own room, and covers the cost of an extra room and 3 meals a day for her travel companion. CHIPSA hospital has a lot of long standing integrity with Cancer.  https://chipsahospital.org/Faith has chosen this hospital because of the many first hand reports she has heard through the years in regard to their high results with cancer. CHIPSA has much higher results with cancer treatment for individuals with compromised immune systems........Of these Therapies are two in particular: IPT and the Vallovax Vaccine. IPT is low dose chemo assisted with Insulin, because cancer cells have more insulin receptors on them than healthy cells the chemo bypasses the healthy cells and only kills the cancer cells! Yay ! No hair falling out ! The Vallovax vaccine has received a lot of media coverage lately. 80-95% of clinical trials are seeing cancer patients with late stage disease with a clean bill of health, and with no side effects?! CHIPSAs hospital is only 23 miles south of sandiego, just over the border in Tiujuana. Faith has interviewed with her agent Kim, in addition to Dr Castillo her attending Physician. They have offered her 3 week opening available immediately. She has been approved for a comprehensive late stage cancer treatment program. She is most encouraged about the Vallovax Vaccine , it is anti angiogenic in nature and it is destroying cancer by: “reducing the growth of new blood vessels needed by tumors to grow and metastasize” It basically starves the tumors from their energy source and they die! The hospital is reporting that patients aren’t needing as much IPT because the Vallovax vaccine is having so much substantial success ! Overview- ( for those who need the back story) Faith was Diagnosed in July 2017 with stage 4 Breast Cancer. Faith’s White Blood cell count was dangerously low prior to starting any treatment. Her Oncologist says she has a condition called Leukopenia. This is where your white cell count is so low that even your own bodies bacteria can become dangerous to you. This makes Faith a risky candidate for chemo, Chemo greatly reduces your white blood cell count. Many people do not realize that it’s not the chemo that kills off the entirety of the cancer, it is the immune systems job to do so. I share this to clarify why Faith was never a candidate for typical Cancer therapy. Faith also has had a 9 year history of complicated auto immune diagnoses, there were years when she was so ill she couldn’t work. So now you have a better idea of why she needs to pursue this experimental treatment. Please consider donating or becoming a fundraiser yourself . If 350 people could find a way to raise 100$ from their friends and family , we could knock this out as quickly as possible and potentially save her life ! Sadly this is a life and death situation. We ask that everyone please share this post and more specifically if you would consider being a fundraiser yourself and gathering funds from you’re circle. If we get to the $35,000 mark Faith can go immediately...let’s get it done in three days and save her life!!

My name is Adriana Hill, and I am from El Salvador. My nephew, Juan Fernando Salaverria, an 18 year old salvadoran, needs to undergo surgery during the second week of July 2018 and we need your help, besides your empathy and prayers. Juan Fer was born in 1999 withTetralogy of Fallot, absence of pulmonary valve and detached pulmonary artery. There are only a few doctors and hospitals in the world that can, to this day,  perform the surgery because of its complexity.  Dr. Evan Zahn is his doctor (currently based in Cedar Sinai Hospital in Los Angeles)who together with Redmond Burke saved his life in1999. As a matter of fact, his condition was so rareback then and his odds for survival so low, that theMiami Herald published an article about him titled“A miracle of the Heart”. We gave everything forhim, not only emotionally, but also financially.Juan’s birth was supposed to be one of joy, the firstgrandson in our family. His mother was fully covered by insurance, but things changed radically when Juan was born with an undetected congenitaldisease. All of these medical procedureswere out of pocket expenses, since the insurancecompany denied coverage due to his congenitalcondition. After two open heart surgeries andseven catheterisms, plus the loss of sight in one of his eyes he needs another intervention.Two days ago we got the hospital’s quotation for his procedure. $89,000.00 We are not financially prepared for that and are turning to you to support us in finding themanner in which we might raise the necessary funds.  A child’slife, an amazing child’s life is at stake. We beg you, from our hearts,from my families’ and from our country of El Salvador’sprayers, where Juan has been an example of resilience, faithand hope, to help us. These funds will be used to paybfor his procedure  scheduled to bebon July 17 2018 Mi nombre es Adriana Hill y soy de El Salvador. Mi sobrino Juan Fernando Salaverria es un joven de 18 años que nació con Tetralogía de Fallo, ausencia de válvula pulmonar y de una arteria pulmonar. En la segunda semana de julio de este año debe de someterse a un cateterismo para poder reemplazar la válvula pulmonar que actualmente tiene. Solo hay un par de doctores en el mundo que actualmente realizan este procedimiento debido a su complejidad. El Dr. Evan Zahn es el doctor de Juan Fernando (actualmente trabaja en el Cedar Sinaí Hospital de Los Ángeles) quien junto con el Dr. Raymond Burke salvaron la vida de Juan Fernando en 1999. La condición con la que nació Juan Fernando era tan rara y su probabilidad de sobrevivir tan baja que el Miami Herald publicó un artículo sobre  llamado "Un Milagro del Corazón". Desde ese momento sus padres y el resto de su familia han dado todo para sacar adelante a Juan Fer no solo emocionalmente pero también  económicamente. Al momento de nacer, la mamá de Juan Fernando contaba con seguro médico, pero al ser la enfermedad de índole congénita, las cosas cambiaron drásticamente. Todos los procedimientos a los que se ha sometido Juan Fernando han sido pagados al 100% por la familia ya que la aseguradora le negó cobertura alguna. Después de dos cirugías de corazón abierto, siete cateterismos y la perdida completa de un ojo, Juan Fer necesita otra intervención. Hace unos días recibimos la cotización del hospital por el procedimiento $89,000.00.  No estamos preparados económicamente para esta situación por eso buscamos de su apoyo para encontrar la manera de poder ayudar a Juan Fernando. En nombre de nuestra familia agradecemos su apoyo, sus oraciones y su cariño para nuestro Juan Fer. Estos fondos serán destinados para pagar los gastos de su operación programada para el 17 de julio de 2018.

On behalf of Matthew Haynes, Abigail Haynes and family.This page is not intended solely for financial reasons. It may also serve as a platform for those to show love and support to baby Rowan and those who go above and beyond to care for him.  Those who choose to support through V E N M O: @mwhaynesOur fight with cancer: Our son, Rowan, was diagnosed with stage III Ganglioneuroblastoma at 15 months of age on March 2nd, 2018. An intermixed mass of cancerous and benign cells forming a tumor larger than a grapefruit was growing in his pelvis out toward his abdomen.  After two cycles of chemotherapy, the cancer was unresponsive and the only treatment left was surgery. On April 26th, the amazing surgical staff at Miller Children’s Hospital in Long Beach was able to perform a miracle. They took out 90% of the mass even though it was incasing his aorta and inferior vena cava. While considered overly successful, they could not safely remove the mass inside his spinal column and sacrum.Our fight isn’t over:  While the best possible outcome was achieved during surgery, our battle with cancer is far from complete. Depending on the type of tissue that still remains in his body and how well he recovers from surgery, he will still need a lot of treatment. He might need additional chemotherapy and maybe even radiation. Rowan will eventually need physical, occupational, and speech therapy to catch up on his milestones. Our oncology team estimates that his treatment will take anywhere from 6-12 months; we have been in the pediatric intensive care unit for only two months so far. As of April 28, 2018, he is still fighting hard in the surgical recovery stage of his treatment roadmap.Why we need your support: Plainly stated, we want to be able to ensure Rowan is being well taken care of. We also want to be able to support those who go out of their way to care for him. Rowan requires us to be by his side at all times in the hospital so we won’t be actively earning income. These donations will help us maintain his care and comfort. My awesome employer has given my family so much already, but those amazing benefits cannot last forever. All monies donated will be used for the treatment, care, comfort, and support of Rowan and those who care for him.For more detailed information on our son’s condition and treatment, scroll down for the whole story.The Haynes Family thanks you from the bottom of our hearts!Feel free to contact me at matthewhaynes@kpmg.com or mhaynes15@yahoo.com￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼The Story: We took Rowan to our pediatrician on March 1st, 2018 because he was being extremely fussy during the past week. He wouldn’t eat, sleep, or crawl. Rowan would just whimper instead. We thought it was an ear ache and teething but our doctor was more concerned about how bloated his belly was. She ordered tests: blood, stool, and an ultrasound.  Later that evening around 7 o’clock, we got a call from her telling us to go to the ER because Rowan's lab results were extremely abnormal. Most notably, his calcium was >15mg/dL (Severe hypercalcemia). That trip to the ER would change our lives forever.￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼Soon after we get to the ER, an abdominal ultrasound revealed that he had a huge mass growing in his belly.  We were admitted to the Pediatric ICU. From there, as if almost on cue, he started to developed severe diarrhea. He would end up losing about 3 to 4 liters of stool everyday.  Confounded by what could be causing the stooling, the PICU team could only treat the extreme electrolyte imbalances and dehydration until the MRIs would reveal what was truly inside. After a week, the MRI was presented to us by the pediatric oncology team. The mass was a lot larger than expected and appeared to be growing from his sacrum to his belly button; it was 12x10x12cm. It was compressing his stomach and bladder, and pushing his intestines toward his ribs. Tumor and bone marrow biopsies needed to be taken in order to give us a definitive diagnoses. Our worst fears came to fruition.￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼The diagnosis was Ganglioneuroblastoma: Stage III Cancer.  It is a very rare cancer that has benign and malignant growths intermixed. The cancer was also emitting a hormone (vasoactive intestinal polypeptide) that caused him to have severe diarrhea; even if he had nothing to eat or drink, he would still have watery stool. At the time, the edpidemiologists thought the dysentery was from a contagious disease, so Rowan was put on isololation for most of the time. In essence, he was forced to stay in his crib for weeks, which was horrible. The diarrhea posed a huge challenge because it resulted in Rowan having his blood tested every four hours so that they could replace his electrolytes and fluids. Eventually, he had to have a semi-permanent central line placed under his collar bone for easy access to blood and meds. He also had a feeding tube inserted through his nostril.￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼The plan of attack was to have two cycles of chemotherapy then check to see if the tumor had shrunk. Surgery would have been the first option but the surgical team was worried that the tumor was too vascular (bloody) and chemotherapy would hopefully kill some of the vasculature.  So, we treated the cancer with two rounds. A total of 42 days worth of inpatient therapy in the pediatric oncology ward. Eventually, Rowan's instability would bring us back to the Pediatric ICU where we would call home for most of the stay. They treated him as well they could.￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼After the first round of chemotherapy, preliminary signs indicated that the tumor was not shrinking and everything we did to slow the stooling wasn't working. We continued to give his second round of chemotherapy with different drugs to ensure that we covered all angles. After many blood transfusions, anti-nausea/pain medications, and diaper changes later, we finally take another MRI to see the results of chemo. In short, the results were not good. The MRI indicated that the tumor was unresponsive and actually grew just a few CMs. This was a hard pill to swallow. What was even more devastating was the MRI revealed that the tumor mass was incasing the two main arteries from the heart. The tumor was also being fed blood by three other arteries. This news was devastating to us. The only bright side was that flu restrictions were lifted and Rowan’s big sister, McKenzie, got to see him for the first time after two months.￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼The remaining treatment was surgery; to get as much of the mass out of him as possible. The problem was that removing the mass could be lethal and that only 50% could be taken out safely.  On April 26, 2018 Rowan endured a 6.5 hour surgery that required every pediatric surgeon in the hospital. We were told that 5 surgeons worked simultaneously on him. We were blessed and relieved that a miracle was performed that day and 90% of the tumor was removed. Everyone's prayers and support and love and kindness were answered. Tears of joy were shed by family, nurses, and doctors alike that day. But our battle is far from over. Only a few days into his recovery we are seeing the struggle that remains. He has a long road ahead with treatment to follow. ￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼We will keep you all updated!Thank you from the very bottom of our hearts.

column3: Help Mary with ALS Medical Expenses
column9: The last year has made Mary and I realize just how unpredictable life is and that you should be grateful for every day...In 2016, Mary had dropfoot and was limping. They could not figure out why and did a spinal surgery thinking that was it. She kept getting weaker and had a fall in Dec 2016, breaking her ankle in three places. In early 2017, she continued losing mobility and by September she could no longer stand. In September, they finally gave us the diagnosis but it was definitely not what we were hoping for...it is ALS (also known as Lou Gehrig’s disease). They say the average lifespan from the first symptoms is 2-4 years and we can definitely see the progression as she is almost bed bound 24/7. But Mary is still dedicated to trying to ‘Stephen Hawking‘ the crap outta this!The cost of paying for a full time caregiver is pretty incredible and we are still on the waiting list to get Medicare to pay for some of it. In addition to Mary's healthcare costs, she has started her inevitable decline, being mostly bedbound every day, losing the use of even her hands, and now her voice is becoming difficult to understand clearly. She also is needing respiration in order to sleep and keep oxygen flowing properly.  Ted has to work during the day to keep the ship afloat.  And after buying a handicapped van in October, the medical expenses are starting to mount again for us.If you are in a position to help, it is super appreciated.  We are thankful that we have a full lifetime to remember together.  Living in London, helping her get into Stanford, working at our startup GoTo together, years of watching our kids grow up. Now that she has pretty much only her memories left, we are dedicated to helping her as much as we are able. Thank you her friends and family for all of the laughter and memories.  Mary is dedicated to helping others even in this difficult time - and we've put together a blog with all her lists of life tips .  Check it out!You can also check out this amazing video that a close friend had made at our Team Mary party.  It's a very touching way to see how Mary has touched all our lives.Sending love from Mary.

Amanda is diagnosed with osteosarcoma. At this time, she will be undergoing treatment at UCLA. Funds raised will go toward her care, and expenses for her family during the time of her treatment. Her diagnosis is in the very early stages, so we will keep you up to date.Amanda Barvinchak is a 24 year old that has been living life to the fullest since day 1. She has always been active, healthy, and excelled in every area of life. Her favorite flower is the sunflower which is so fitting for her because she is truly the sunshine in so many peoples’ lives. Amanda was currently enrolled and on her way to becoming a naturopath doctor. She wanted to help people naturally improve their lives so that they may be healthier and live more prosperously. 5 years ago, she beat bone cancer in her left leg,  now that cancer is back and she needs our support. This time it has come back as a mass on the outside of her lung, causing her intense pain due to all the nerve endings in that area of the body. The doctors believe that it is is localized to that area, but are recommending some rather intensive chemotherapy options as well as large scale surgeries to get her back to her healthy. Although it hurts feeling like we cannot do anything to help her, there actually is a means of assistance.... By supporting her through this fundraiser and sharing this with your network, this will tremendously help her by allowing her parents and loved ones provide all the accommodations for her through this process. There will be many medical costs to get her through this. There is not a person out there that does not shower Amanda with praises on her soft heart and loving outlook on life, it is time we show her our appreciation and support through this hard time. Amanda is a fighter, has made it through this before, and we believe in her to make it through this again.Thank you for your continued support and remember to share this opportunity to support Amanda to your network.

column3: To show support for our Kelly!
column9: If you have been directed to this GoFundMe, then you are aware that our Kelly has been diagnosed with de novo Stage IV Breast Cancer.  Although we all have the greatest faith that Kelly will continue to be her awesome self and respond well to treatment,  there is still the reality that the appointments, scans, medications and changes in work schedule can take a financial toll.Many people have asked how they can help, and one important way to help Kelly and her family maintain normalcy is to make sure that these expenses do not cause unwelcome worry or derail them from enjoying their family time.Please join us in making a donation towards these expenses and show Kelly how much we love and support her!

On the evening of the 21st August, I lost my best friend and my brother Beni.  No words can convey the loss of such a wonderful person, who will no longer be part of our lives. Beni has left a giant hole that will be felt by all of us who have had the privilege of knowing him.   His loving family, Nolliyae, Adam, Tsehay and Teri have lost a friend, a brother, a son and a gentle soul.  I thank you all from the bottom of my heart for your generosity and continued prayers for the whole family as they go through this difficult time.It is heart-warming to know that he has left an indelible mark on all our lives.Beni my brother, may you rest in peace.Henock.=============================================================================Benji's family will be receiving friends and family at the Ethiopian Community Development Council (ECDC) located at 901 S Highland St. (Basement)Arlington VA 22204 on:Saturday 8/25 : 2pm - 7pmCANCELLED -- Sunday     * Please note - parking garage available in ECDC building *The funeral service is to take place on Monday, 8/27 at 10am in St. Peter Catholic Church located at 313 2nd St. SE, Washington DC 20003 (Capitol Hill)  NOTE: Since there is very limited parking near the church, we recommend either getting a taxi, using public transport (Capital South Metro Station which is two minutes walk from the church) or car pooling and arriving early.The burial is at 12:30 in Rock Creek Cemetery, 201 Allison St NW, Washington, DC 20011  Lunch at Ethiopian Community Development Council (ECDC) located at 901 S Highland St. (Basement)Arlington VA 22204 following burialFor questions, call Rodas at 202-820-0908 or Karine 571-338-9795=============================================================================Beni  is a son, a brother, and a friend to many.  Anyone who has met him knows how genuine, loving , considerate, hardworking and funny he is. Unfortunately he is suffering from stage 4 lung cancer which has spread to his brain, and bones.  He has been valiantly fighting it since January 2018.   Over the past few months, he has been subjected to chemotherapy, radiation, and is now undergoing immunotherapy treatment.Benji is the most decent human being I know,  and a breath of fresh air as anyone who had the pleasure of spending time with him could testify.  He is surrounded by friends and family, and his mother has been taking care of him day and night since he was first diagnosed.   A heartbreaking experience that no parent should have to go through. To make the situation more difficult, his medical insurance will not cover all the extensive treatments and care that he is and will be undergoing.He needs as many people as possible, to include him in their prayers, and to the extent possible, donate to lessen some of the financial stress related to medical expenses, outpatient treatment, in home care, and other unforeseen medical bills  (an unnecessary burden) when he should be focusing on getting better.Please do NOT share this campaign on social media.

The Short Version:Coach/Sensei/Friend David Butler's Cancer has returned - and as strong, as tough, and as spiritual as this incredible human being is, both he and his family need our help - and God knows he would never ask for it.  With that in mind, he does not know I've created this GoFundMe.  The reason we are raising money for the Butler family is because he'll be spending the next 6+ months going through a combination of radiation and hormone therapy to hopefully combat the cancerous cells.  As you can imagine, this is not an inexpensive process.  Add to that the fact that he owns his own business and is not covered by a corporate healthcare policy.  For someone like Coach Butler; a man who has spent his entire life serving others - it's hard to know how we can help him in perhaps his darkest hour.   Perhaps helping to take the weight of the impending medical expenses off his shoulders will be a good start. What I do know is this: there are few people in this world outside of my family whom I would jump in front of a train for.  Coach Butler is one of them.  Let's make this happen.Tim McMahonUNH Wrestling '99 - '03

column3: Support for Baby Olivia Faith Solis
column9: On February 22, 2018 Olivia Rene Solis was born to Miguel and Jacqueline (Nortman)Solis. From shortly after that time, Olivia has been in the neonatal ICU as a result of a congenital heart defect. In her short life she has already experienced two major heart procedures and received CPR for over an hour, and continues to fight for her life. Through this time, Olivia’s parents have been surrounded by friends, praying for them constantly, as they hope for a miracle. Olivia was baptized in the ICU and the family gave her the baptismal name, Faith. Miguel and Jacqueline are deeply grateful for all of the prayers and support that are pouring in from all over the world. While their request is simply for continued prayer, the reality is that the costs are mounting. Olivia is receiving the best of care, and it comes at quite the cost. As friends of Miguel and Jacqueline, we ask you to lend your financial support to the overwhelming costs of hospital care for Olivia Faith Solis, as well as continue to extend your prayers, hopes, and best wishes to the family as it keeps them encouraged and hopeful. All donations to this campaign will go directly to offsetting the expenses the family is incurring during this time. Your support is needed urgently and anything you might offer is deeply appreciated.

As many of you may know, in August 2018 my 33-year old sister in law, Laura Allio and her husband Michael, received devastating news of a probable recurrence of her cancer. After nearly 18 months of chemo, radiation, a double mastectomy, more chemo and countless hospital visits, Laura was seemingly on the path to recovery from the stage 2b breast cancer diagnoses she received in April 2017, just 6 months after their sweet baby James was born. In January, Laura’s scans showed that there was no evidence of disease. Despite this, Laura was adamant that another scan be taken in mid-August to confirm that she was cancer free. While doctors noted an additional scan wasn’t needed, her persistence won and the scan was performed.As a shock to us all, on August 23, 2018 Laura and Michael received the devastating news that the scan showed a concerning spot on her liver. Laura’s doctors are confident that this lesion signifies a recurrence of her cancer and therefore, at the beginning of September, Laura will have the lesion removed and sent out for testing. This recurrence would put her at stage 4 cancer which means that more creative methods need to be put into place to ensure Laura has the strongest possibility to beat this. So many people have reached out to show their love and support, and to ask about ways they can help. This Go Fund Me Page is a way to help Laura and Michael access the care, resources, and lifestyle they need to give them all the strength to continue to fight like hell. Beyond cancer being devastating, it is expensive. Insurance will cover the scans, the surgeries, etc. but ALL other supplementary expenses are out of pocket. New costs pop up every day, but here is what we know they can expect soon. Those costs that are known for certain are listed below, however there are some costs we are not exactly sure of yet. Western Medicine- COBRA costs due to Laura carrying the insurance prior to the loss of her job earlier this year ($1600/month)- Flights to and from hospitals for second opinions, treatment, etc. (airline tickets will cost at least $300 each time they travel, not including hotel costs and other costs associated with being away from home)- Research on her lesion performed by Foundation One (a sample of her lesion will be sent out for testing to determine the type of cancer she is dealing with so she can best fight it)- Functional medicine expenses - A consult Dr. Nasha Winters who uses natural medicine to target stage 4 cancer successfully ($500 for just the consult, not including ongoing treatment) Eastern Medicine- Acupuncture 2x a week ($31 each session)- Natropath doctor visits twice a month ($200 each visit)- A treatment facility to focus on detoxification and finding the root cause of her cancer (approx. $10K, depending on the facility)- Research by Sator Therapeutics – Cost is TBD but likely in the thousands (this is a personalized approach to treatment in Europe that would allow Laura to receive a customized treatment based on her specific type of cancer)  - Additional exploratory medicine expenses that arise (This will be the driving cost of treatment going forward as Laura needs to determine the root cause of her cancer and be vigilant in her approach to treatment)- Mistletoe injections ($180 monthly)Lifestyle- Regular massage treatments ($40 each session)- Organic groceries weekly in lieu of a meal train or other meals dropped off ($200) – Laura is on a very strict diet and this will allow her to maintain it- Supplements ($180 a month)Despite the stage 4 diagnosis, Laura and Michael are confident that they can beat this. People live for many years and go into remission with this diagnosis, but this type of success requires a lot of work, exploration, alternative medicine, and the expenses that go along with it all. This Go Fund Me page will help to ensure that Laura and Michael can focus on her treatment and have relief from some of the expenses that will come their way in the future Following the removal of this mass in early September, we will know, for certain, if this is cancerous. Because the doctors believe it is, we would like to give Laura and Michael a jump start on the upcoming expenses. If, for some reason, the results of the test indicate that this mass is not cancerous, all funds will be refunded Thank you in advance for your generosity, love, and support.

As many of you have heard, the Burns family has suffered a major tragedy in their family.  On Friday June 16th Pete was in an accident that resulted in a Traumatic Brain Injury. Kristen, Pete and their five children have volunteered so much of their time and gifts to members of our community. It is hard to find someone that they have not helped or touched with their kindness in some way.  Many of you have asked how you can help. First of all, we would like to thank you for reaching out, allowing the family some privacy and offering prayers. Prayers are the one thing Kristen asked for and continues to ask for. However, because of the Burns overwhelming kindness to others many would like to do more.  This GoFundMe page has been created to do just that. It is where you can make a donation and offer up a prayer/wish for the family. Pete is making progress however it will be a long road ahead. This page will remain open during the family’s journey.  As the family feels comfortable they will periodically use this page to update you on Pete’s progress. In addition, you can continue to wish them well and donate as you can. On behalf of the family we thank you for truly showing what community is about and paying it forward.

Estimados colegas, amigos y familia. El pasado 3 de mayo nuestro compañero Ismael Ortiz Cartagena, Fellow de segundo año del programa de Cardiología en el Hospital de Veteranos sufrió de un derrame cerebral hemorrágico. Los que han tenido el placer de conocer a Ismael, sabemos que él se desvive por la medicina, él fue el ganador del primer lugar en nuestra competencia del Congreso anual de presentación de research de fellows. Él fue escogido para ser el Chief Fellow de su clase graduanda y fue aceptado para continuar su entrenamiento en el programa de Cardiología Intervencional de la Universidad de Florida en Jacksonville. Siempre se ha enfocado en dar la milla extra, dirigiendo y participando en múltiples estudios de investigación clínica buscando echar hacia adelante la Cardiología en Puerto Rico. Pero Ismael no solo se caracteriza por sus sobresalientes logros académicos. Con sus pacientes siempre demuestra empatía y humildad al momento de brindarles el mejor trato posible. Como colega y amigo siempre brinda lo mejor de sí para ayudar a su prójimo.Él siempre se ha hecho disponible para participar, ayudar, y educar en su programa de entrenamiento, en las actividades de la Sociedad Puertorriqueña de Cardiologia y las del American College of Cardiology de Puerto Rico.En estos momentos, él se encuentra hospitalizado y batallando por recuperar el movimiento de sus extremidades derechas/dominantes. No tenemos duda de que él tiene la fortaleza y el coraje para lograr una recuperación completa. Es de esperar que el camino va a ser difícil y va a requerir de mucha terapia para su pronta y completa recuperación. No queremos que nuestro colega se quede privado del mejor tratamiento posible por razones económicas. Ayúdennos a brillar luz en el camino de Ismael durante este momento de oscuridad para asegurarnos que él logre brillar por sí mismo como siempre lo ha hecho.Sus donaciones serán utilizadas directamente por Ismael y su familia para propósitos de pago de gastos médicos, equipos médicos, terapias, y gastos personales durante estos próximos meses que no podrá ejercer. Ismael nunca ha sido persona de pedir, ni de depender de otros para sus logros. Cuando se le hizo el acercamiento para ofrecerle esta ayuda, quiso dejar claro que todo dinero restante cuando logre su recuperación será donado a un ente benéfico. También expresó que tanto él, como su esposa y familia, se lo agradecen grandemente.Los donativos de esta campaña para el Dr. Ismael Ortíz serán entregados a su esposa la Dra. Yaneris Agosto y serán manejados directamente por ambos para para propósitos de pago de gastos médicos, equipos médicos, terapias, y gastos personales durante estos próximos meses que no podrá ejercer.

Helping out the MacDonald family during this difficult time.Every little bit helps.A Note from Anabelle’s Mom:We are at Children’s again with Anabelle. She had a seizure at gymnastics Monday and we discovered yesterday that she has Idiopathic Pulmonary Arterial Hypertension (IPAH). It is quite serious, as it is a disease. It is also rare, 1 in a million people have it. Thankfully, it is treatable with aggressive intervention. We also have time on our side since she is only 4 and still growing. There have also been great developments over the past five years in regards to treatment. We will be here for another two weeks they think. Soon we will be learning our options for medication and possibly making a tough decision. We were told her best option is through a permanent line surgically implanted, which breaks my heart, but once she is better she can lead a normal life. We are pulling the horizon much closer, taking it moment by moment, and learning about what our new normal will be like. Keep my family in your prayers.

We write this with such heavy hearts.  We lost our sweet, energetic and sassy Leah Murtha on June 19, 2018. Taken from us way too soon. Raymond and Jessica are heartbroken, along with the rest of our family. This tragic loss comes within 10 months of them losing their wife and mother Luci Lynch-Murtha, after her courageous battle with cancer.  We have had such an outpouring of love and support, it has been overwhelming and we want to say thank you. I know many people want to be able to do something so we set up this page so you can post your messages donate if you choose, but just a way for all of us to express our feelings and thoughts. Raymond and Jessica will receive all the proceeds from this page. Thank you so much again, for your support and love.

Sgt. Daniel Pedersen US Marine Corps (ret.)This is Dan Pedersen, a 24 year old Sergeant who just finished his 5 year tour of duty, with the US Marine Corps. He was stationed at Camp Pendleton, and served in the Middle East and in the South Pacific theater. He was officially discharged from the military on February 3rd, 2018. Shortly after returning home Dan developed a cough. He worked through the pain and discomfort but knew he needed further medical attention. Doctors found a tumor in his right lung on April 26th.  Dan then had his first surgery on April 29, 2018 and was diagnosed with a small cell Neuroendocrine Tumor. It is extremely rare to find this form of aggressive metastatic cancer in such a healthy young man. He has chosen a special form of immunotherapy, that is not covered by his insurance. This therapy includes two-three years of strict adherence to a personalized medical protocol. Through many miracles Dan is able to travel to receive these treatments. Currently, Dan is working as a certified EMS provider in downtown Salt Lake City for a ambulance agency. One of his many aspirations includes attending nursing school to further his education within the medical field. With proper treatment, Dan will still be able to accomplish these goals, have a family and live a normal, healthy life.Dan's friends and family have set up this GOFUNDME.COM account for the purpose of raising funds needed for this specialized immunotherapy treatment. Dan is highly motivated and positive. With your support, we know he can beat this cancer.Thank you all for your love and for your support in this very unexpected and challenging life development. If you would like to contact Dan, please send him a personal message. He will be posting his thoughts, feelings and all of his successes, everyday on this Facebook page.  https://www.facebook.com/sgtdanielpedersen?lst=100026069892175%3A100026069892175%3A1526354636 6670    Please feel free to post your comments or questions.            With warmest regards, Dan's family and friends.

column3: FAITH, HOPE & LOVE FOR ADRIAN  V.
column9: Hello Friends & Family,I am making this Gofundme for my cousin Adrian Valenzuela who is near and dear to my heart. Adrian is 21 years young and loves being around race horses and has a passion for  these beautiful animals. He grew up around them since the day he was born. Unfortunately on Saturday morning while working horses at Santa Anita Race Track he went down in a bad spill and was not able to get up. He was rushed to Huntington Memorial Hospital where they confirmed he had broken his back, broken ribs and he has no sense of feeling from the waist down. He will be going in for surgery within the next couple days on his spine in hopes for things to turn around. As we all know there will be medical bills and lots of therapy which is why we have created this to try to help out with him and the family. Any donation is very much appreciated. Please keep him in your thoughts and prayers and Always keep the Faith, Hope & Love strong for Adrian during this time. Thank you & God Bless!

Please help Nicholas' family afford a van so he can be safely transported when they need to leave the home.Adaptive vans are needed to  safely transport medically complex and physically disabled people to and from doctor’s and therapy appointments. It also helps them have the ability to experience life outside of the home. Nicholas is a two year old deeply affected by cerebral palsy. He can't do things like sit up without assistance, lift his arms or push up to help those caring for him move him from place to place. He's a tall boy for his age and the risk of injury is high for both him and caregivers. Getting a van with the right equipment will help transfer him more safely than out of a car seat in a typical vehicle. Kids like Nick have bulky, heavy medical equipment, and if it's not used as intended, expensive repairs are needed. This happens when components that aren't intended to be broken apart need to be in order to fit into a car to go to multiple appointments, sometimes in the same day. Nick's family has some important visits to the Seattle Children's Hospital scheduled later in the summer with  specialists and they have to bring equipment that doesn't fit in their car.Nick's family will soon be selling their small SUV and hope to buy an adaptive van, but they need your help.RECENT VISIT TO DEALER TO SEE HOW NICK'S CHAIR FITSThis is Nick's story, told by his Mom and Dad:In June of 2016, my husband and I received a phone call that a little boy was born many states away to an unprepared mother and that the baby needed a family. We had been chosen for the task if we could quickly decide to take him. After a surprisingly short discussion and a long flight to meet him, it was obvious that Nick was meant to be our son. Because we had gotten him "overnight", our community rallied around us and started delivering clothing, strollers, a crib; almost everything we needed showed up miraculously at our doorstep in those early days.A few short months later, our perfect baby started to slip in meeting milestones and started exhibiting what medical professionals called "hypertonicity". He was unable to turn his head easily to the left and his leg and arm muscles were consistently tight. He also started having issues bottle feeding and he barely slept. The hardest part about the first few months was not knowing what was happening with him and feeling like we weren't giving him what he needed. Typical new parents, right? What we didn't know at that time is that Nick's brain had suffered a stroke early on in the pregnancy and he had a condition called bilateral schizencephaly  with polymicrogyria . When we received his diagnosis at 6 months of age, we were told that he probably wouldn't walk and that controlling his seizures and muscle tone would be life-saving as he grew.NICK'S FIRST EEG, WHERE HIS SEIZURE DISORDER WAS CONFIRMEDThe first year of his life was deeply disorienting for us and filled with hospital admissions, trips to the ER, trials and errors with feeding tubes, procedures, tests, sleepless nights and mastering a whole new vocabulary. We learned the difference between OT and PT, balanced appointments in the home and in-clinic and we signed him up for every service we could afford, leveraging the Early Intervention's Birth to 3 services. As his mother, I was unable to return to work and filled my time with going to support groups, hiring dependable caregivers and even attending seminars about neuroplasticity. Kids like Nick need help re-wiring the brain to use their muscles, including those supporting vision, so they can have hope for some sort of "normal" life.NICK AFTER HIS FIRST MEDICAL PROCEDURE TO GET A FEEDING TUBE, HELD BY DADAs symptoms of his brain disorder, Nick has cerebral palsy, intractable epilepsy, cortical vision impairment and other symptoms like trouble swallowing and digesting food. He doesn't use any words to communicate. He's followed by over 15 doctors and we see 6 therapists - Occupational Therapists, Physical Therapists, Vision Therapists - either weekly or monthly either in our home or in clinics.What my husband's health insurance doesn't cover has been paid out of pocket so far. Big expenses are looming because he's such a big boy and because he can't help us move him at all.  Expensive things like adding tracks in the ceiling to support his weight as we move him safely from one room to an adaptive bathroom - not yet built - or removing steps and replacing them with ramps to roll his chair. We need to find a space in home to accommodate durable medical equipment like his activity chair, an adaptive stroller or foam wedges to support him during vision therapy. He'll soon get a "stander" to help him bear weight so his hips can develop enough to avoid surgery.TWO OF THE PIECES OF LARGE EQUIPMENT WE NEED TO TRANSPORTThe tricky thing about medical equipment is that it's bulky and heavy. Not only do we need to protect our bodies as he grows but we need to protect the integrity of the equipment by not breaking it down when it needs to go with him to appointments. The retail cost of one of his pieces of equipment alone is over $7,000 and if it breaks, there are limited options for loaners. The process of getting the blue chair in the picture above through the local children's hospital, including insurance approvals, took almost 7 months!We've waited as long as possible to buy an adaptive van to safely transport Nick and his heavy medical equipment. Soon, he won't sit in a car seat and instead, his chair will be strapped down inside a van for transport. By purchasing a properly adapted one, we'll be able to roll Nick into it and reduce unnecessary wear and tear on the chairs. If you have ever shopped for a van, you know that they can be costly. If you add the conversion package, the cost is between $60,000 to $80,000 for a new one. The conversion offers essential features for families like ours, like:-    A wheelchair ramp that automatically retracts from the vehicle after the van is lowered closer to the ground. You might have seen this with buses being lowered to accommodate a passenger with physical limitations. -    Modular seating that can be easily removed to add space for large equipment or a disabled passenger in the front when they're old enough. Why should a person who would typically ride up front be pushed to the back of a van simply because they can't open a door and sit in the front seat?-    Illumination on the floors to see where you're working on tying down chairs or when you drop things like syringes while meds are administered.We've been setting aside money to buy the van but other expenses are adding up:  adapting our home, hiring additional caregivers so we can both work to afford therapies and treatments. So, we're asking for some help. We're lucky to have a fair, family-run and owned local dealership  in our area but we really need some help putting part of the money down to be able to afford the monthly payment.It's very hard to ask for help so publicly but we've been encouraged to do so by some of his doctors and therapists and we all need help from time to time.Thank you listening to our family's story and for your support. Even if you can't contribute financially, sharing our story with your friends and family or leaving a kind note is always appreciated. You can share the link by email, phone, Facebook or Twitter:   www.gofundme.com/VanforNick. Or, you can just use" share buttons" and mention why Nick's story inspired you to donate or share.Thank you again,Nick's Mom and Dad, Nick J.

Our old friend Tom Trott is battling ALS. He is confined to an electric wheelchair and can no longer speak, having to communicate via a text-to-voice device. The disease has progressed to the point where he needs in home care which isn't covered by insurance. The demands for in-home care will increase over time placing a financial strain on the family. If you are able, please donate to this site to help offset the tremendous cost of in-home care. To give you a sense of the Trott’s need, here are some estimates on caregiver costs they will soon face:    $5,000 (cost of four weeks of in-home caregiver services, 8 hours per day)    $1,250 (cost of one week, 8 hours per day)    $250 (cost of one 8-hour shift) To make a significant dent, we need some donations towards the upper end of the chart. However, we understand that each of you is in different financial circumstances. A donation of any size is appreciated and will add to the total amount we are able to raise for the Trott’s. Let's rally to help one of our brothers.Due to an overwhelming response, we increased the goal from the initial $25,000 target to a new $35,000 target. This extra money will allow the Trott’s to use additional caregiver services. They likely will need this and more. Thank you for your generous support!

On August 13, 2018, at 2:49AM, Officer Jordan Wingate (solo driver) was responding to a call of a suspicious persons in the area of 7th Street and Middle Harbor. The marked patrol vehicle traveling Eastbound in the 1900 block of Middle Harbor collided with a civilian car and then a parked semi-truck. Officer Wingate was extricated by the Oakland Fire Department and taken to a local hospital and is listed in critical condition. He is still in a comma, listed in critical but stable condition. The doctors advise that Officer Wingate’s fight to recovery has only just started. Officer Jordan Wingate is 23 years-old. Officer Wingate started his career with the Oakland Police Department as a Police Cadet in 2013. In 2016 he was hired as a Police Officer Trainee (POT) and graduated from the Oakland Police Department’s 176th Basic Academy on May 2017. Officer Wingate is currently assigned to the Patrol Division.

The Switzki family has reached a point where they could use your help.  Matt fought stage IV cancer for two and a half years.  He passed away peacefully in his home, where he was surrounded by the people dearest to him; Tricia, Kane, Elin, his parents, and Tricia's mom.  They had told Matt he had six months to live, and as strong as we all know he is, he beat those odds and never gave up his fight to the very end.Tricia is reluctantly accepting financial help.  She has never asked for help through it all.  So many people have asked what they can do to help, and this is one way we can all make her life a little more comfortable.  She was always Matt's rock and had been there with him every step of the way, 24/7.  There will be medical bills coming in that Tricia will have to find a way to pay.  She has been working full time, being a mom to Kane and Elin, and a care-taker for Matt for so long.  She hasn't looked at bills in months, because she wouldn't leave Matt's side when he was in the hospital.  He was her only focus, as it should have been.  Any amount you could donate to the family, would be wisely used as she see fits.If your son or daughter are on a team or activity with Kane or Elin this year, offer to drive or car pool to help Tricia out.  She has amazing family to be there for her, but sometimes something as simple as driving her kids, can be the biggest help.  Keeping Kane and Elin entertained, happy, and busy means more to Tricia than you could ever know.The most important thing in Matt's life was his family.  Please pray for them all.  There is nothing more important in life than love and family.

Diane is a mother of two sons–Holden, 9 and Gavin, 7–who is now facing devastating life changes, loss of limbs after a simple surgery went wrong, and the inability to pay for most of the medical bills because insurance won’t cover them.On June 7, Diane went into what should have been a simple sinus surgery to help with chronic nasal infections she had been suffering from for months. The next day, she suffered from a 104-degree fever, a headache, nausea, rashes, vomiting, and diarrhea. She was taken to urgent care, where they eventually couldn’t find a blood pressure, and then she was rushed to the emergency room.Somehow, Diane had contracted an infection during the sinus surgery that had quickly become septic(bacterial infection in blood stream). She was taken into an emergency surgery, where her entire large colon and part of her small bowel were removed. She then spent almost two weeks in the ICU, unable to see her sons, and was taken back to surgery for an illeostomy and given a feeding tube (peg) as well. She wasn’t able to speak again until she was extubated on June 17th—her first words were, "Happy Father's Day."Because the infection became septic so drastically, Diane no longer has use of her fingers and feet, but she can currently stand briefly on her left foot. She struggles through having her wounds dosed with alcohol, wrapped, and unwrapped multiple times a day. She is also still suffering from a swollen small intestinal area with gas and stomach pains, a clogged feeding tube, anxiety, and minimal sleep. She is enduring physical therapy trying to regain mobility with hopes of returning home to her boys, husband, and the community that she knows and loves.The doctors are advising amputation. There is a possibility of hand transplants and a right below-the-knee amputation, as well as an partial amputation on her left foot. The doctors are also hopeful that more can be done to improve her small intestine, bar any more infections or setbacks. However, most of the above won’t be covered by her insurance or social security. The current estimate for what she’d have to pay out of pocket is over $500,000.The insurance will pay to put Diane in a nursing home, but refuses to pay for at-home health care, prosthetics, or the necessary procedures. The worst case would be Diane being placed in a nursing home at 35 years old, where she could only get visitation from her boys and husband after school and work, but would no longer be able to live with them. The family has yet to hear back from Medicaid, but we’re hoping that Diane will be accepted so that she and her sons can have some insurance if she were no longer to have insurance from her job due to her condition.We are asking for donations to this GoFundMe page to help pay off her medical bills that the insurance won’t cover, and for the ability to receive any prosthetics or at-home care she’s going to need moving forward.Thank you for reading, and thank you in advance for anything you can give.  Any little bit will help, even something as small as the price of a cup of coffee.  Please share to spread the word even if you can’t help monetarily!We thank God for His many blessings and that Diane is alive and can still hug her boys with her arms and talk to them. Through this whole ordeal her faith in God and multiple prayer group-support from Open Door Church, where she volunteers and where her boys to go to school and support has been a tremendous help. We thank everyone who has prayed and for the many churches across North Carolina, her family, and her friends that have gotten her this far.All funds raised will be withdrawn in a special bank account on behalf of Diane and the family.  Paula Loftin will work to oversee the withdrawals of the funds.

There have been so many of you voicing concern about our long- time head bartender, NASSO, who has been MIA since the end of January. As of this new posting, we have collectively raised about $32,000 to support our longtime friend and favorite bartender in his most challenging year. I am happy to have spent a couple of days with Nasso this past week in the beginning of August, around and in my swimming pool, a scenario neither of us could have imagine even two weeks ago. It is a convenient place for him to begin a long process of rehab in tandem with his other physical therapy routines. He is in good spirits but still trying to process all the life changing events that have occurred these past 9 months.The good news about his bone marrow biopsy being negative was a big deal of course. He is still waiting on an additional report regarding the possible presence of an aberrant “t” cell that would make him more vulnerable in the future.
