In late April, 2018, Mark discovered he had a colon blockage.  After further testing, it was determined to be cancer.  Surgery was scheduled to remove the affected area, but they discovered the cancer had spread and was worse than originally thought, so it could not be removed.  He is currently undergoing chemotherapy and other treatment.We've recieved many questions from people asking if there is anything they can do to help.  We've created this fund as an opportunity to come together and help Mark and his family through these tough times.Any funds raised will be donated to him and his family to help pay for medical bills and costs for him not being able to work.Thanks,Jonathan

Please join us in showing our love and support for Steve and his family in their greatest hour of need. Below are words shared from his wife, Sarah Pupillo. Dear friends, I’m writing to ask you to pray for my sweet husband. On Wednesday night he had a seizure. We came to the ER via ambulance where it was discovered that he has a mass in his brain. He was admitted to the Neuro ICU and over the next several days they did more testing which found two more smaller masses in his brain and one in his left leg. Tomorrow morning he will undergo a surgical biopsy (under anesthesia) to determine what kind of cancer this is. I can hardly believe I’m typing these words. Our lives have felt like a horrible dream that we need to wake up from. We are frightened and anxious and overwhelmed. BUT, we are resting in God’s promises. This was no surprise to Him. He loves Steve and He is holding him right now, guiding him through this difficult journey. So many of you are praying hard for us right now and have asked your friends and families to pray too. From the bottom of our hearts, thank you! Please, please keep praying for healing, for peace, for strength and courage. Even in moments of fear, we feel God’s overwhelming peace and we are so thankful for that.Zephaniah 3:17  -  "The Lord your God is in your midst, a mighty one who will save; he will rejoice over you with gladness; he will quiet you by his love; he will exult over you with loud singing."

Dear friends, My friend Rakesh who is just 27 years of age has been diagnosed with kidneys failure and has been admitted to Washington Hospital in Fremont,CA. He was admitted under emergency on April 14th 2018 and was told that both his kidneys are not functioning. He was placed on the transplant list and requires an inevitable surgery for his survival.  Rakesh doesn't have a proper insurance that cover his hospital bills and treatment. He has just completed his MS and is looking for a job when he fell sick and was admitted to the hospital.  It has become a huge burden for him to cover the hospital bills that have just added up after a week of being monitored and determining a plan of care. His condition is aggravating day by day. Now with a transplant and surgery becoming inevitable, it is taking a huge toll on him both financially and emotionally.  Any generous contribution  on humanitarian grounds would be a great help and may help Rakesh save his life .Regards,Sai KumarFremont, CAPh: 510.626.6678Patient Details,Rakesh Fremont,CAPh: 845.943.9422Bank Account Details,Digital Credit Account# : 5826521Routing Number: 211391825

My name is John Prince and I am the father of Jordan Prince.  Jordan is 26 years old and has been in the grip of anorexia and bulimia for the last 10 years.  During the last 12 months, Jordan has been hospitalized 4 times.  Last summer, she was in the ICU for almost 8 weeks and she is currently in OSF.My daughter is almost dead and the beautiful daughter that I once had is gone.  I spent the last 2 years full of anger.  Anger at my daughter for what I viewed as the terrible choices she continued to make each day and anger that I could not find a way to control the circumstances.   The Lord has brought me to a place of peace and I just want to take care of my little girl.My wife and I reached out to Selah House in Indiana and they have agreed to help.  OSF sent Jordan's file to them yesterday and they called my wife today.  They stated that our daughter is in a severe state and will die without immediate treatment. My daughter is unable to keep a job and currently has Illinois Public Aid as her health insurance.  There is not a single treatment facility that accepts IPA.  Selah House has agreed to cut the daily rate to $850.00.  At first, I thought this sounded like an unusually high amount, but after talking to other facilities, we found out that this was a highly discounted rate.  (Denver Acute is $5500.00 per day)Per Selah House's advice, we are currently trying to have the hospital keep Jordan until a bed opens up at Selah House the last week of March.  Selah stated that Jordan would need to be there 12 weeks.  As I type this, there is a little box out to the side giving me suggestions on what to write.  It says to "Tell how these funds will help you or your love one".It will help me by keeping my daughter alive and helping her to have a quality of life that I have not been able to give her.  I want to help her to the depths of my soul, but my business went under at the end of 2017 and I am at the end of myself.  It would help my daughter to continue to live and become the person I know she can be.Not knowing what else to do or who to turn to, I am doing this GoFundMe page.  I need to raise $71,400.00 before a bed becomes available at the end of this month.  I will be forever thankful for any help you might be able to offer.

Early last week, our dear friend, Michelle was diagnosed with stage 3 peritoneal cancer - a rare type of cancer that affects a very small percentage of the population. She was admitted to St. Anthony's hospital, in St. Pete, Florida,  on June 7, and has spent the days since surrounded by an incredible group of supportive friends and family who continue to be amazing advocates for her care. Michelle's symptoms began just a few weeks ago, but progressed quickly. After consulting with her primary care physician, she underwent a CT scan hoping it would reveal the cause of her abdominal pain and bloating. The CT scan did show some abnormalities, but additional testing was required which took her to St. Anthony's. We received official word that cancer cells were present in her abdomen on June 12, and surgery was performed the same day to remove as much of the cancer as possible. Doctors were pleased with the outcome of the surgery, and to no one's surprise Michelle was an absolute Rockstar from pre-op, through the entirety of the 4-hour surgery, into post-op and recovery. We look forward to getting her back on her feet as soon as possible so she can take the next step in her treatment plan, which will involve chemotherapy. As we begin to digest this news and plan for Michelle's continued care, we have decided to create a GoFundMe page on her behalf as an outlet for friends near and far to connect and contribute should they feel called to do so. As you can imagine, the emotional shock of a cancer diagnosis and so many uncertainties are only compounded by the financial stress.First and foremost, your love, prayers and emotional support will be the family's lifeline in the months to come. The outpouring of support already has been such a blessing and provided great comfort to Michelle and her family. Michelle's beautiful, kind and caring spirit for others has touched so many people in so many ways over her 56 years on God’s earth. As a nurse she has spent her life caring for others, and now it’s time we care for her. We hope that we can raise $25,000 to help defray some of the medical costs and and household expenses while she is unable to work, easing the family's financial burden, and allowing her to focus on beating cancer!We believe that God is bigger than the cancer that has impacted her, and everything is possible through Him. So, Michelle will fight, and we will fight with her. Thank you for being in our corner!

Lenny Torres was driving in Pennsylvania on a business trip on Friday March 2nd, when a tree fell on his car. Lenny suffered a severe head injury, fractured vertabrae in his neck, a bruised heart, and both ankles were shattered along with other cuts and bruises from the incident. Lenny was transported to the University of Maryland Hospital Shock & Trauma Center in Baltimore, Maryland. During surgery on his face, the doctors were unable to save Lenny's right eye. Lenny still needs to undergo facial reconstruction surgery and ankle surgery. Right now Lenny is sedated and in stabile condition. Lenny's wife, Mariana and youngest daughter drove through the night on Friday from Greenville, SC to Baltimore to be with him while he is in the hospital. Local families in Baltimore have graciously opened their homes for a time to give Mariana a place to stay while doctors continue to do procedures and get Lenny to a place where he is able to travel. Once Lenny is able to be transported back to Greenville, the plan is to bring Lenny home to heal and continue treatments.As you know, there are and will be travel expenses, food, and an unknown amount of medical bills that are going to start piling up as a result of this incident, not to mention Lenny is unable to work right now. At this time, it is unknown how long it will be before Lenny can make the trip back to Greenville or what kind of rehabilitation he will have to go through. We don't know if worker's compensation is going to assist in the incident at this time, so let's get the ball rolling by helping this sweet family financially in the meantime. Galatians 6:2 "Bear one another's burdens, and so fulfill the law of Christ."

Julie's story begins in the summer of 2014 when she was diagnosed with Stage-3 breast cancer.  She endured months of chemotherapy, a double-mastectomy, radiation and later reconstructive surgery.  Throughout the difficult journey, Julie remained strong & focused on beating her cancer, which she had named "Oscar"; as in the Grouchy Green Trash Can Monster from Sesame Street.  She has always had a passion for children and loved her job working with the children at Little Lambs Preschool.  The children truly loved Miss Julie as well. During and after her treatment, she made her experience a way to support other women with breast cancer by offering them support, guidance and resources.  Just one week prior to her stroke, Julie was again offering such support when she provided help and guidance to a gentlemen she had just met who was suffering with cancer.  Her family and friends supported her all along the way and some even participated in a Bee Brave 5K Run/Walk, in October 2014, raising funds for breast cancer research.  In spring 2015, with great celebration, Julie was declared cancer-free!!  She had beaten Oscar!!  To celebrate her victory, Julie and her husband Chuck took a trip to Hawaii and looked forward to a bright and healthy future.Fast forward to early 2018, Julie started experiencing shortness of breath and a CT scan revealed fluid around her lungs and that she had a slight enlarged heart. The following day an echo cardiogram was completed on her heart, which reveled damage to one of the valves showing it was operating at only 20%. This damage was caused by the chemotherapy (known as Cardio Toxicity). The following day during a needle biopsy (Thoracentesis) of the fluid, on March 1st, Julie suffered a stroke.  She was rushed from Spectrum Pennock Hospital in Hastings to Spectrum Butterworth Hospital ER, in Grand Rapids, where we received the sad news that she had suffered severe brain damage in her left brain resulting in right-side paralysis, speech and cognitive issues. Julie spent 16 days in the Critical Care Unit, then transferred to the stroke unit where she spent two additional days, before being transferred to Spectrum Rehab Facility. Julie then began a long, difficult journey of rehab. She has repeatedly revealed her strength and spirit by enduring a ventilator, grueling tests, painful treatments and challenging physical therapy on a daily basis. The past months have been a virtual roller-coaster due to her heart issue, spasticity in her right leg and foot, as well as multiple other complications, setbacks and difficulty finding the proper balance of medications.  Along the way, medical insurance issues have made getting her treatment needs difficult. She has been through approximately 2 weeks of rehabilitation at Spectrum Rehab Facility, then 4 weeks of rehabilitation at Mary Free Bed in Grand Rapids, back home for in-home therapy for a few weeks, then, because of setbacks for various reasons, has been in and out of the hospital, as well as another almost 2 weeks of rehab at Mary Free Bed (not covered by insurance). Chuck has been working tirelessly day and night with God's grace and doing a marvelous job of advocating for her and doing what's best for her; which is what one would want done for themselves if they could not speak the words.  Julie's team of doctors are finding that their options are becoming limited given the condition of her heart and the effects of the stroke.  In the meantime, Julie will be at home trying to get her heart strengthened with medication.  She will need round-the-clock care, as well as daily professional in-home care, which will not be covered by insurance, contributing to the financial strain that has been building over these past months. The costs have been significant and will continue to be.  Those who know Julie know that her big heart has compelled her to always be there for anyone in need and the Lord has blessed so many people through her support and actions.  She has always had a unique ability to know what people need even when they did not know they needed it themselves.  She goes above and beyond to provide whatever is needed.  Be it a helping hand, resources or sometimes just her love and prayers.  At this time of need, here is our opportunity for 'Giving Back to Julie'.  Her family is so grateful for all of the support: thoughts, prayers and expressions of love that she has received.  It is with great faith that we continue on to whatever God has in store. OCTOBER 2014 - BEE BRAVE 5K RUN/WALK

Erin is a loving daughter, sister,  wife, mother, friend and educator. She has been part of the the Worth Elementary School family as a reading specialist since 2003. In October 2016, she was diagnosed with Stage 3 Triple Negative Breast Cancer, which is an aggressive form of breast cancer that occurs in younger women and has a high rate of recurrence. After undergoing chemotherapy and radiation, her scans came back clean this past December. Erin thought she had finally beat this awful disease. A month ago, her cancer returned and had metastasized to her brain, lungs, liver, and bones. After receiving this difficult news, Erin and her family maintained their hope and were ready to fight this again. Immediately upon this diagnosis, Erin began treatment with radiation and chemo. Unfortunately, this treatment has put too much stress on her body, but her strength continues to amaze us every day.  We will maintain our hope that she will be able to come home soon! If you are lucky enough to know Erin, you know that she truly is a special person. She has an undeniable love for her husband, Adam, and their two beautiful children, Brooklyn (6) and Connor (4). Her parents, Diane and Mike, and her brother, Ryan, along with amazing extended family have been constant supports for her throughout this difficult journey.Erin has always been someone to put her family and others first. It’s time for us to put her first and help her with her fight. This page has been set up by her friends to help offset expenses for Erin’s cancer treatments and to alleviate financial stresses on her husband and two young children. As long-time friends of Erin and her husband, Adam, we have set up this Go Fund Me page to help with any medical expenses or unexpected financial situations that may arise during this difficult time. We humbly ask for your help. No donation is too small. #mottsgotthis

Philecia was diagnosed with Stage 4 Breast Cancer and this is her story: “In April 2017, I found a small marble sized lump in my left breast while adjusting myself in my sports bra. I did not qualify for insurance, nor did I have the financial means to afford private insurance. I had to go to the free clinic, where they referred me to an imaging center. The test results showed a benign cyst. In retrospect, they think the cancer was behind it, not seen on the ultrasound at that time. They told me to come back if it bothered me, otherwise the cyst did not alarm them/seemed normal. In November I started to notice it was larger and actually noticeable through clothing, which bothered me a little. I said I would get it checked out, but holidays happened and life got in the way, and they said it was benign.... Come January 2018 I was snowboarding when I fell and hit my chest pretty hard. Two weeks later it wasn't getting better and seemed swollen, so I went back to the free clinic where they ordered an ultrasound. That came back abnormal. I then had a second ultra sound, blood work, and referral for a mammogram which showed a more serious issue. I then had 4 biopsies, two left breast, 1 lymph node in left armpit and a pretty traumatic one on my right breast. The results are that I have ductal carcinoma in situ. As I waited for the next steps they started doing an MRI, and a petscan, which resulted in showing the cancer has spread to both my lungs and my sternum. Our protocols for women and breast cancer testing is not good enough. It is not  protocol to get a mammogram until 40 years old because programs/insurance won't pay for it without valid reasoning. Mind you because I didn't have insurance, didn't qualify, and am not able to afford private insurance and the clinics are so full and over worked I was forced to wait 5 months to know what was going on. Had regulations and insurance been different I wouldn't be in such a fight right now."Those are the words of our friend Philecia. Her cancer is stage four and has spread. She is the strongest most vibrant woman we know. We are gearing up to fight this as hard as we can as a team, which is why we need as much help and support from our respective communities as we can get. There will be more tests, more surgeries, special necessities, and specialists. Once we’ve beaten this, the testing will be ongoing and extensive to ensure it never returns. Even if you are unable to help Philecia financially please share this far and wide, help us help our beautiful friend. To follow her journey, through the good and the difficult, Instagram updates will be posted @philecia

If you know Amy Gross, you know that she loves her family with all her heart, cares deeply for her students, and moves through life with positivity and joy.  She has been teaching since 1987.  She has impacted thousands of students with her infectious love of life.  Amy was recently diagnosed with stage 4 lung cancer that has metastasized to her liver.  This came as a huge shock because Amy has lived a very healthy life style and has never smoked.   Recently Amy has begun chemotherapy and is also seeking alternative treatments to support her immune system through the process.Unfortunately, the alternative treatments are not covered through her insurance.  We ask that you prayerful and thoughtfully consider joining us in supporting Amy and her family by donating to help offset this huge financial burden.  Amy has always been one who has rallied around others.  This is our chance to rally around her!#HopeforAmy #proudtobeMUSD #honorthecode #sierraproud

column3: Help Laura, Chad, and Kaylee Jane
column9: Unfortunately, our beloved friend and coworker Laura Thompson suffered unimaginable complications during the birth of her beautiful daughter Kaylee Jane, and has been fighting for her life for the last several days. Thankfully, Kaylee Jane is just as healthy as she is beautiful. Both Laura, Chad and many of their own family members have been a part of our Worley family for years now and they need our support. While we would all love to be by their side to lend our support, most of us are left wondering what we can do to help. All of our positive thoughts and prayers are being heard - Laura knows that Kaylee Jane and her family are counting on her, and rooting for her, and she knows how much love and support she has from all of her extended family. If you have the means to contribute monetarily, please do. We know there will be mountains of bills to pay following Laura's hospital stay, all of the expenses that come along with a new baby, and of course the lost wages as a result of all of this. Let's remind this family how much they mean to all of us. Thank you all in advance for sharing this with the hundreds of folks who love and care for Laura and Chad, and who can't wait to meet Kaylee Jane.

Morgan “Mo” was just diagnosed with a brain tumor. This sweet boy is so brave. He will undergo surgery to remove the tumor in the next couple of days. We don’t know what the road ahead will be like but we know he is strong and we want him and his family to know how loved they are. With so many unknowns ahead, financial strain is inevitable. This fund is put together to support the family so that they can put all of their energy and time being with and supporting their sweet Mo. Help us Move Mountains for Mo! ❤️

July 4th, 2002. The Hannoun family departs from France to South Florida to start a new life in the United States. Even though it meant leaving the remainder of the family behind, the two young children, David and Robin, are so excited to get to a life of sunshine and rainbows (literally) and get away from all of the negative stigma that France held for them. “We’re never going back,” Robin said to David as they both saw the Independence Day fireworks streaming through the sky, something they’d never even thought about in their young days in France. Well, funny how life turns out sometimes.Fast forward to June 2018. Robin, now 21 years old, has just returned from a trip to Asia and is starting his first professional internship at an investment firm in Tampa, FL. He has a bit of a headache and is feeling nauseous, but he just shrugs it off as nerves or bad Chipotle or something like that. A week goes by, still the same feeling of nausea. He starts to seek medical attention, going to see a few different medical professionals in the South Florida area. No one is able to tell him what’s wrong with him.Rightfully worried and concerned, he decided to take matters into his own hands. Despite how the two brothers felt about France, there is one thing that is undoubtedly true – the healthcare system is miles ahead of that of the United States. So, Robin got on a flight to France, not even booking a return flight because he knew something was wrong. This was Friday, June 29th. He landed in Paris at 1:00 PM. By 3:00 PM, he found out he had a benign tumor in the left ventricle region of his brain. With his grandfather a highly regarded doctor throughout France, he was able to get in the care of Professor Parker, one of the world’s leading practitioners in neurosurgery. Robin met with him that Saturday; within a few minutes, he was scheduled for intensive brain surgery for that Tuesday, July 3rd.Everyone’s life changed. His mother, who was with his sister in New York for a dance competition, booked a flight to France immediately. His brother, who lives and works in Atlanta, did the same. His father was already in France, but now, there were no plans of returning to the States. Everyone was there for Robin when he got out of surgery, and we were all so impressed and pleased by the man we saw.Literal moments after getting out from brain surgery, when it normally takes weeks or even months to be able to move, Robin was stretching his arms and rotating his legs back and forth. He was conversing with us, he was completely conscious, and he was kicking his recovery’s ass. In fact, he was able to walk by himself within 2 days, something which usually takes several months for patients with a similar surgery. We were all so happy and pleased with how everything was going, and quite honestly, so was he.And then came the next piece of the story. Robin’s benign tumor had been sent to the lab for biological analysis just as standard procedure, and as it turns out, it actually wasn’t benign at all; in fact, it was quite the opposite. What Robin had gotten removed was a malignant medulloblastoma, a cancerous tumor which turns out had metastasized into  another region of his brain. Long story short, he had brain cancer, and needed to get treatment right away.Robin was then sat down and told the plan, the plan that would ultimately determine the most basic thing – his survival. Regular sessions of chemotherapy followed by regular sessions of radiotherapy. He would perform all of these in France over the coming months.Now, the hardest part for most cancer patients isn’t the physical symptoms and reaction to the therapy; the hardest part, by far, is the mental part. Staying positive amongst all of these negatives, keeping faith in the process even when your platelets get so low that you have to get a transfusion that doesn’t even work because you’re so depleted that your vein literally bursts when plucked with a needle, or being able to tell yourself that you’re going to get through this even when there is no indication or certainty at all. This isn’t like a common cold, or breaking a bone, or twisting an ankle. This is cancer, and nothing is certain.So how does this apply to Robin? Well, he has always been a fighter; when it comes to the physical symptoms, he’s reacting very well and he himself is not worried about them. The mental part is a different story. Remember how when he and his brother were little kids, he told David “We’re never going back.” Well, he meant it. He never wanted to go back and spend extended amounts of time in France, much less live there while getting treated for arguably the worst type of cancer known to man. So, it’s needless to say that not only is the treatment tough, but he is incurably homesick, misses his friends, his habits, his familiarity of living in the US. And while we can’t literally bring the US to him, one thing we can do is bring the next best thing – his friends.Robin has a crew, a group of several young men who all call each other best friends, and they all would be willing to do anything for one another. The goal of this fundraiser is to pay for biweekly trips to France for Robin’s best friends to come see him, to establish some sort of resemblance of home and bring some happiness and familiarity back into his life as he goes through and fights this horrible disease. As they say, even the smallest of lights shines bright if it’s in the darkest of places. Help us save Robin. Help us save my brother.David Hannoun

Last night a good friend and colleague of ours, Loren Davy and his wife Sara Stafford Davy, were involved in a tragic vehicle accident in Monahans, Texas. This accident resulted in the passing of Loren’s beautiful wife, Sara. Both Loren and Sara are well known, loved and respected in the medical and aviation community around the Permian Basin, West Texas and beyond. Loren is one of our amazing Helicopter EMS Pilots for our MTC/AeroCare #5 Base in Odessa, Texas. Sara was a Flight Paramedic for CareStar in Odessa before becoming a Registered Nurse.  Sara was currently employed as an RN at Odessa Regional Medical Center. She previously worked at Ward Memorial Hospital in Monahans, wearing multiple hats in the ER and trauma department.  Loren and Sara have two awesome little boys, Luke who is 9 and Jake who is 6.  Loren and these boys were the center piece of love, happiness and joy to Sara.  Both Sara and Loren have dedicated much of their professional careers to helping those in need. But more importantly, they have given even more of their personal time and finances helping those in need. Now it is our turn to help their family during this terribly tragic time. This go fund me account has been established to help Loren, Luke and Jake.  Any monetary donation no matter how big or small will be appreciated. 100% of these funds will got to the Davy family. Thank you for your continued thoughts and prayers. Please help us honor Sara’s memory by assisting her beloved family.

She’s here! Danni Jo Napolitano was born on August 10th ~ 6 pounds 3 ounces ~ 20 inches Our beautiful little butterfly was born with a rare skin disease calledEpidermolysis Bullosa (EB). EB is a lack of K protein, which causes the first and second layer of skin to separate. The separation then causes blistering. Blisters can occur with even the slightest bit of friction to Danni Jo's skin. Danni Jo is still healing from blistering sustained during the birthing process and continues to develop new blisters daily despite the amazing 24 hour care she’s receiving from doctors, nurses, Austin, and Chris in the NICU. To combat blistering and infection, Chris and Austin must keep Danni Jo covered in Aquaphor  and work as a team to bandage her entire body from the neck down at least once a day to help protect her skin. Danni Jo is tough as nails just like both of her parents and she’s eating well and getting stronger everyday. This will be a long journey ahead for  Christopher, Austin, and Danni Jo as EB is a lifelong condition. Medical costs for people with EB can be astronomical at up to $10,000 per month for special equipment and medical supplies alone, plus doctor visits, special clothing and bedding, and more. Most insurance  companies have a cap on the amount covered for medical equipment specifically and only Chris will be able to work due to the constant care that Danni Jo will require. We are asking anyone who has it in their heart to help donate to this beautiful new family, and help our little Danni Jo on her journey ahead. Austin and Chris are both military veterans with Austin serving in the Air Force and Chris in the Army stationed with the 173rd in Bamberg Germany and Logar province Afghanistan from 2009-2012. There is so much love and good energy surrounding this beautiful little butterfly, and we hope you can be a part of that. Thank you all! - If you would like to help out in  other ways please email cjnapolitano13@gmail.com￼￼￼￼￼

column3: Unidos por la salud de Marlene
column9: Hola a todas y todos, En marzo de 2018, luego de batallar por varios meses con lo que se pensaba era una sinusitis bacteriana, Marlene fue diagnosticada con rhabdomyosarcoma.  Este cáncer es muy común en niños y adolescentes pero muy atípico en personas adultas (ya se imaginarán qué es lo que ella dice sobre lo de la edad). El tumor creció muy rápido,  afectó su ojo izquierdo y en cuestión de días el dolor era insoportable. Tomamos una decisión inmediata y los doctores coincidieron que el mejor curso de acción era traer a Marlene a MD Anderson Cáncer Center en Houston, Texas.  MD Anderson Cancer Center es un lugar especial. Muchos médicos boricuas trabajan acá o se preparan aquí para dar servicios de oncología en Puerto Rico.  A Marlene se le ha asignado un equipo médico con un especialista en cuello y cabeza, un oncólogo y una cirujana orbital. Todos coinciden que este tipo de sarcoma lo tienen que atacar agresivamente con quimio y radioterapia.  También, coinciden que Marlene va a ganar esta batalla contra el cancer, pero tiene que seguir su tratamiento al pie de la letra.  Marlene recibe un tratamiento de forma ambulatoria. El mismo es sumamente costoso y nos obliga a permanecer en Houston por un período de tiempo significativo.  La ayuda económica que solicitamos viene apoyar todos los gastos relacionados al proceso de curar y cuidar a Marlene.  Todo apoyo es importante, todo apoyo será para este proceso. Ayúdanos a sanar a Marlene.

We want to show our support and love for Ross and his family during this time. In January, he was diagnosed with Thymoma, a rare cancer that only a few hospitals around the country have experience with. They have been in New York City at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center. He was also diagnosed with Thyroid cancer in May. He has undergone 3 months of chemotherapy, 2 major surgeries  in which they had to replace the lining of his heart with gore tex and remove 10% of his left lung. He is currently going through radiation. Please continue to keep Ross and his family in your prayers and give financially as you feel led. The money donated will help with medical expenses not covered by insurance, travel expenses for Ross and his family, and living expenses in NYC that have grown over the past 8 months.

Our Warrior PrincessAida R. Del Orbe Go Fund Me From all her loved ones especially her Husband Carlos Betancourth and daughter Raquel The life of the partyThe one who makes everyone laughThe one who can turn any situation into an adventureThe one with the loudest, rowdiest, howling laughterEveryone's best friend...that is our sister, AidaLove, Laugh, Live, Dance a lot and Pray. It’s her way of life in its simplest form. Enjoy every moment as tomorrow is not promised.  Loved fiercely by so many, she personifies what it means to live life to the fullest. Some of the hallmarks of being Aida are her sunny but caring personality, quick wit, and no filter responses to life's unpredictability. From New York City, to Arizona, to Florida she has amassed a circle of friends and loved ones who would do anything and everything for her. She is everyone's biggest cheerleader. If you ask anyone of her friends they will tell you "She is my best friend.” She makes everyone feel as if they are the most special person in her life. That is the essence of who she is. June 2016,  held the promise of  a wonderful summer to look forward to with warm sunny days, beach plans, catching up with friends and family. Little did she know it would be the beginning of a journey that was unimaginable.  After months of enduring pain that would not dissipate she finally decided to go to the doctor to determine the cause.  Like millions of women across the world, she’s diagnosed with breast cancer – Stage 3 later developing into Stage 4. After months of chemotherapy, radiation and a double mastectomy seven months later, she seemed fine. Unfortunately Aida's cancer continued to progress. The most recent diagnosis as of Saturday, Monday, May 19th is that the cancer has progressed to a brain condition called Leptomeningeal Carcinomatosis (LC). It is a rare complication of cancer which spreads to the membranes surrounding the brain and spinal cord. LC occurs in approximately 5% of people with cancer and is terminal. This causes blurred vision, strenuous headaches, causes the body to clamp up with no mobility, unable to speak clearly (slurring of words) where she cannot be understood and increased pressure in the brain. These episodes are increasing day-by-day. The doctors determined that a shunt surgery would stabilize the pressure that is in her brain. Monday, May 20th she will undergo this procedure. Our Princess Warrior’s hope and faith for a cure and longer life have never wavered.  She hasn’t stopped laughing and enjoying her time with family and friends. Her will to live has never diminished. God is wonderful and has blessed her with the greatest group of supporters!The doctors at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center are in search of different types of treatment to extend her life. The treatments are costly, one that will require the help of all of us coming together to relieve strenuous and costly medical bills . The situation is urgent!  We have created this Go Fund Me in hopes that collectively, all of Aida's loved ones can raise the money to pay for treatment. These funds will be a tremendous help as she explores all avenues that can lead to a potential life-saving treatment. We appreciate you taking the time to read this appeal and considering a donation to this urgent cause. As always, any amount goes a long way and we are grateful for your generous gift. Prayers go a long way, so please do not stop praying for our Warrior Princess. To help us get the word out, you may share the link to your Facebook Timeline. If you would like to stay up to date with Aida’s condition, please provide us with your email address and the team will send out updates periodically.Thank you all for your support.Team Unbeatable

**When donating, you DO NOT NEED TO TIP GOFUNDME. Instead, click "Other", delete the amount in the box and type "0". If you want to help Laura Nilson fight cancer for the THIRD time, you are in the right place! Frank and Laura found out this week that after a remission of 5 years, her breast cancer has returned and aggressively metastasized to her liver and bone marrow. They are acting fast to fight it, and we can act fast to help offset the cost of treatment. All contributions will be used to pay medical bills and living expenses while Laura focuses on getting healthy.Laura has given 100% of her energy, time, and hilarious sense of humor to serve others and lift their spirits.  Her life has been dedicated to friendship and love. We are grateful to have a way to help their family during this difficult time. Thank you for your generosity!**When donating, you DO NOT NEED TO TIP GOFUNDME. Instead, click "Other", delete the amount in the box and type "0".

This is Rocky Jr. age 9. On the night of Sunday, July 1, 2018 after a normal active summer day, Rocky suffered a severe stroke caused by a congenital condition called Arterlovenous Malformation (AVM). The stroke caused significant damage leaving him unable to walk and at first even speak. He will have to undergo at least 2 brain operations to hopefully reverse this state. But before the surgeries, Rocky Jr. will have 5+ weeks of intense rehab to hopefully regain some of his strength before the procedures. Rocky's dad, Rocky Sr., his mom, Marivel and his older sister Alison are obviously heartbroken and distraught. This is a hard working family with both parents working two jobs just to provide a normal lifestyle for lil Rock and his sister. Rocky's neurosurgeons say he is in for a very long haul from here on out but his prognosis is good. This however will involve overwhelming financial expense for the family. Please no matter what the donation, help this family through this most trying of times. Thank you.

We, Pam’s friends and family, humbly request you consider donating to the “Amazing Grace that is Pam” with the same love and commitment she has given and continues to show us.Pam's StoryFifty-one years and thankfully we continue to count the days that Pam Riley Molloy graces our world.  In that time, she has proven that everything can and should be done with continual grace. As a brain cancer survivor for the past two years, she continues to show a poise and elegance while enduring the latest treatments provided by Memorial Sloan Kettering to battle this disease. At the onset of it all, Pam decided to become an active participant and survivor by joining the newly formed NJ chapter of the National Brain Tumor Society. The Molloy's Marchers have been the #1 fundraising team for the non-profit organization for the past 2 years.  Pam was raised in Glendora California by Pat and Gil Riley along with her sister Sherri. She moved to Manhattan in her 20’s, fell in love and married her soul-mate, Steve. From the beginning, this high-fashion clothing buyer exemplified style, elegance and poise. She left the work force and stayed home to raise her family. Her love for her two boys, Jack and Alec, combined with her knowledge of industry helped birth the business she called “Tickle Toes.” It was never about money and she eventually sold the business to have more time for her family and community. Pam was always active in the Colts Neck Schools and joined the PTO where she was the Fundraising Chair and eventually President for 2 years. During her time in the PTO they raised tens of thousands of dollars for the community while bringing them together to enjoy one another at the same time. Today, she is battling brain cancer and we, her friends would like to see her have that same grace and dignity she has always shown as her illness has evolved. While the cancer is in remission, Pam is suffering from Radiation Necrosis a side effect from her treatments that has affected her memory.  Now, the Molloy’s need our help as Pam requires constant supervision and care.Pam’s husband, Steve, will be the designated recipient of the funds raised during this campaign, which will be utilized for the continual care and supervision that Pam’s Necrosis requires.

On Valentine’s Day, our world came to a halt when Mac was diagnosed with a rare childhood cancer called Ewing’s Sarcoma. What had been a nagging pain in his leg turned out to be the last thing any parent wants to hear: that their child has cancer. No one wants to think that this can happen, let alone to a child that we love — our smart, funny, interesting, and creative twelve year-old Mac.        Mac has been under the care of doctors at Doernbecher's Children's Hospital at OHSU in Portland. After the diagnosis, he quickly began chemotherapy and just finished his second round. It is an excruciating schedule: he is inpatient for all his chemo which is every other week, anywhere from 2-5 days.  All totaled, he spends about half the month in the hospital.  Mac has to endure 7 rounds of chemo and then will undergo an extensive surgery in May to remove the tumor and rebuild his leg.   After surgery, Mac will be non weight-bearing for at least three months! He will be in a wheelchair and eventually on crutches if possible. He will require constant care. He only gets  a couple weeks reprieve and then begins several more months of chemotherapy after surgery.      All in all, Mac is facing nearly a year of treatment, hopefully getting his last round of chemo before Christmas. Mac’s prognosis is good, and we are all counting on a clean bill of health and a joyous return to normal life once this process is over.  However, it is a daunting year ahead. It will be filled with much worry, suffering, and demanding care — and also with strength, wisdom, love, and support. Our family has felt the love pour in from so many, and now we are asking for your support.   It is difficult to ask for help, but the year ahead will have many trials, including financial. Mac’s chemo schedule requires Laura and Kelby to join him in the hospital (there is no place they would rather be) and then at least one of them must be home to help when he’s sick. Kelby continues to work when Mac is not in the hospital, and his fire department has been unbelievably supportive with offers to cover his shifts and be flexible with his needs.    As many of you know, Laura has her own private practice and so when she doesn't work she doesn't get paid. Her schedule has already been vastly reduced, seeing clients when she can.  They have insurance, but many things are not fully covered.  Here is an idea of some things they have immediate needs for:   *  Wheelchair ramp for Mac * Bathroom remodel to accommodate wheelchair and non-weight bearing status * Laptop for Mac to video conference with his class to keep up with his schoolwork * Knee scooter, wrist crutches and other devices not covered by insurance * Supplementing Laura's loss of income for a year            This all comes at a great cost, and that is why we are asking for your support. Mac is doing the hardest work of all, and the greatest gift is enabling Laura and Kelby to have the ability to care for him during this unimaginably difficult year. By easing some of the financial stress, you would be directly helping Laura and Kelby devote all their resources to caring for Mac and helping insure that he has the best support possible for the fight ahead.        Here are some words about Mac from a dear family friend:   Mac is an incredible friend to so many. He has grown up as a Candalaria Husky and is now an exemplary student at Howard Street Charter Middle School in Salem. Mac delights in the ordinary, and extraordinary experiences that life has to offer. He is zealous about being a keeper of tradition, finding meaning and belonging in annual trips to the Polar Express with family and friends and annual Easter hunts in the back yard with neighbors. He can transform a trampoline or a dining room table into a fortress of fun and innovation. He is an encyclopedia about all things Lego, Marvel, Magic and Star Wars. He loves to create movies and animations of his own that express his interests, talents and showcase his great sense of humor. Mac has an abiding love for dogs, especially his 3 labs, Brick, Lego and Leia. It is not uncommon to find him piled up in a snuggly blanket with one or more of his canine companions. Mac finds points of connection with anyone who lends him an ear. Whether you are an adult or one of Mac's peers, you can't help but admire the way he creates an environment of inclusion wherever he goes. Mac can move from serious to silly seamlessly and has the ability to ignite contagious laughter. He is kind, brilliant, innovative, all without losing his empathic spirit. Mac knows what it is to truly walk alongside others, and often is a place of refuge for those who feel outcast. Now it is our turn to walk with Mac. For such a rare and unique individual to have such a rare form of cancer, we are afforded a rare and unique opportunity to journey alongside Mac and impart our strength to carry him through the next year of treatment.

As many of you have heard by now, our friend and band mate, Pete Distefano has been impacted by a disease that hits so close to home for so many of us. Pete and his family have being tasked with a hefty load to take on this battle with cancer.  Hefty volume of treatments, hefty schedule of appointments, and certainly hefty level of financial burden as these treatments and appointments begin.During times like this, people are always looking for ways to help. If we can help to lighten their load by taking away some level of stress around medical bills, that will be a way to help Pete and Michelle focus their energy toward what is most important and needed right now; his health. If you've ever had the privilege of seeing and hearing Pete perform, you have been blessed.   Now it's time to give back for all those wonderful memories he's given us all.  Any little bit can help make a difference to them and can help us all feel like we are doing our part during a time where we can feel so frustrated as cancer takes its toll yet again. We thank you in advance for any donation.  No amount is too small.    Rock On!!!  We plan to!!

As Brian is transitioning from residency to his career in Brevard, NC he is unfortunately dealing with unexpected medical issues and unforeseen expenses. Nobody has a more humble or kind demeanor, so please join me in showing your support for him.

Help Peter Walk Again!Dear Friends and Family,Some of you may know, on January 13, 2018 our father, Peter Montgomery, suffered a spinal stroke causing a spinal cord injury (SCI) that led him to become a T-6 Paraplegic Incomplete. This means that he is paralyzed from his mid-chest down with partial paralysis in his right leg and complete paralysis in his left leg, leaving him unable to walk. He also has sensory deprivation mid-chest down that makes him unable to distinguish between dull and sharp touch; as well as, temperature variations.Anyone who has met our dad knows what a determined and optimistic person he is. Through all of life’s uncertainty, he has maintained a positive outlook and helped others in any way possible. Although the doctor’s prognosis from his SCI is uncertain and we are still awaiting a diagnosis, he has not accepted this as his personal reality and is exemplifying the strength of his spirit by challenging himself everyday. Through this trial he has been motivated and eager to put in the hard work necessary to regain the ability to walk, something many of us take for granted, so that he too can experience the little joys life has to offer, like back packing with his children, river rafting, and dancing with his daughter at her wedding.The road to walking again will be intense, but our dad is prepared to do everything in his power to get there! Although we are currently looking at a two-year (at best) time frame for his recovery, it is crucial to have continuous physical therapy throughout this journey and to ensure that his medical needs are met.Donations will go towards medical and physical needs, such as: durable medical equipment, wheelchair costs, medications to alleviate his constant pain and muscle spasms, and various physical therapies including PT, acupuncture, swimming, cycling and massage. The most important aspect for his progress will be his acute rehab at SCIFIT, an extremely rigorous, holistic physical therapy regimen specifically customized for each individual SCI patient’s particular needs for the fullest recovery possible.Below are links to some of the organizations that have helped to inform, educate, connect and inspire our father.We would like to share these resources for people in Northern California also affected by a SCI.NOR CAL SCI: https:  https://norcalsci.org/NO LIMITS COLLABORATIVE:  http://www.nolimitscollaborative.org/BORP:  http://www.borp.org/get-involved/SCIFIT:  http://sci-fit.org We appreciate all the love, support and positive vibes we’ve received and are so thankful for your donations.  We would also like thank all the Occupational and Physical Therapists; as well as, the doctors and nurses who have and continue to help our dad.Please share, so our dad’s story can reach as many people as possible and hopefully help a few people on the way! Klaes, Jack, and Gwen   ** Spinal strokes are very rare and account for less than two percent of all stroke. A very special thanks to Teresa Montgomery whose love is like a mighty river. I love you -Peter

Our close friend Ryan, during an afternoon on March 14, suffered a unfortunate accident by falling though an open 3rd story window onto a cement walkway. Due to the freak blizzard conditions the Boston area was experiencing, a snow layer prevented the fall from being fatal, but nevertheless Ryan was rushed to the hospital with a substantial list of injuries. Ryan suffered a skull fracture (above the ear) causing his brain to bleed in 3 separate places, 3 broken ribs, a collapsed lung, fractured right hip, and lacerated kidney and liver. A 2nd year Environmental Science major at Boston University, Ryan is a passionate, energetic, and hardworking individual. Described by many as “the life of the party,” Ryan truly embodies the Aloha Spirit. The type of upbeat character most people wish they’d meet earlier. Growing up in Honolulu, he embraced the local culture of community, where surfing, hiking, paddling, and weekends selling pineapples at the KCC Farmers Market kept him busy. There, and everywhere he ventured his infectious laugh, smile and goofy personality charmed everyone he encountered.In order to minimize the stress and anxiety on his family during such turbulent times, we ask for everyone's help to donate any amount to assist Ryan. Donations will go directly towards the extensive medical bills for his current and future procedures/tests, which already include multiple CAT scans, chest x-rays, and ICU costs. The second main hurdle that funds will cover are the rehabilitation costs, which doctors estimated could last up to a few months. While all this happens, Ryan’s single mother plans to remain by his bedside in Boston as long as she can, taking time off from her full-time job.  Ryan is a loved son, brother, cousin, nephew, and friend to to us all. We ask that you PLEASE share this page with anyone and everyone you know on any platform that you see fit. More importantly please send positive energy and prayers for the strength and recovery of Ryan Hwang. - Mahalo!

On June 12, 2018, my son’s best friend, Ben Mitsevich, was struck by a car, as he was crossing the street while the driver was extremely preoccupied texting away. She crushed Ben’s right leg leaving 2 of his 3 main arteries torn and unrepairable. Ben will not be able to drive hence the fact that it’s his right leg.  After multiple surgeries the doctors are not promising if Ben’s leg can be saved.Ben has been through more than one kid in his 15 years should handle, as Ben lost his father 6 years ago on his birthday. His life has changed forever all over again. The medical bills are piling up and we don’t even know how many more surgeries he will need.I ask everyone to come together and please help Ben’s mom, Lana Mitsevich give Ben the medical support that she needs to provide him with the on-going surgeries that are still ahead of Ben’s road to recovery. PLEASE PRAY FOR HIM AND PLEASE HELP!

July 26 2018I wanted to THANK YOU for the outpoor of LOVE and SUPPORT!! THIS IS ABSOLUTELY INCREDIBLE and beyond generous! Malia is currently undergoing her treatments. The chemo is hard but we are confident that she will be healthy by the end of the process. Some friends expressed the desire to continue this fundraising campaign. All I can say is that this is already making a difference in her day to day. Sending love and blessings!----------------Je voulais vour REMERCIER TOUTES ET TOUS du fond du coeur pour votre AMOUR, SUPPORT et GENTILLESSE! Malia a commence ses traitements qui suivent leur cours. La chimio est difficile mais nous avons bon espoir qu'elle en sortira en sante. Certains amis ont exprime le desir de vouloir continuer cette campagne. Ce que je peux vous dire c'est que cela fait deja une difference dans son quotidien. Merci encore!--------------------June 2018Let's join together and support Malia in her battle again cancer. Malia got recently diagnosed with an aggressive breast cancer at only 42 y/o. She will be starting her chemotherapy treatments next week and will not be able to work for a while.  This fundraiser was created to financially help support her and her children Axel and Leola through this particularly challenging time. Malia is our light and we want to give her the space and peace to gather her strength and focus on healing and getting better over the next months. I encourage you to please share this fundraiser with Malia's network of friends and family, or others who you think may want to show their support. I know this will mean so much to her and her children. Thank you all so much in advance!-----------------Unissons-nous ensemble pour soutenir Malia dans sa bataille contre le cancer. Malia a appris recemmennt qu'elle avait un cancer du sein aggressif juste quelques jours apres son 42eme annniversaire. Elle va commencer ses traitements de chimiotehrapie la semaine prochaine et ne pourra pas travailler pendant un moment. Cette collecte de fonds a pour but de l'aider financierement elle et ses enfants Axel et Leola durant cette periode particulierement difficile.Malia est notre lumiere et nous voulons lui donner l'espace et la quietude de trouver la force de guerrir et de passer au travers de ses traitememts.Je vous encourage a partager cette collecte de fonds avec ses amis et famille ainsi que toute personne qui aimerait lui montrer son soutient. Cela fera une grande difference pour Malia et les enfants. Merci d'avance!

This fund is set up for my son, Mark. Mark is a son, a brother, an uncle, cousin, nephew and a loyal friend to many. He has always been the one to light up a room with his outgoing personality and sense of humor. But now he is depending on his strong support system of family and friends to help him through his time of need.He is suffering from a liver disease and his condition has left him in need of an immediate liver transplant. Mark has been in the hospital for over a month now and he has been unable to work for the majority of the year. If you could support my GoFundMe by making a donation and then sharing it with your network, I would greatly appreciate it. I know that money can be tight, so please know that even $5 helps me get closer to my goal! Let me know if you have any questions and I’ll be happy to answer them.

With a heavy heart, we have decided to reach out to you our friends and family to help this young, struggling family in crisis.  BreAnn Ahara is a woman who, at 33, found her life as she knew it to be over.  The once vibrant, independent, business owner and mother of 3 is now essentially incapacitated with no definitive diagnosis, treatment plan, hope or end in sight.  She's seen dozens of doctors and had numerous hospital stays.  She's been living in chronic, torturous pain and growing weary.  Her husband, Rikio, has taken over caring for their 3 daughters (10, 7, 6), their household, working full time, and caring for her like a rock star.  There is still a huge financial deficit to be covered with her much-needed and life-saving medical treatments that are not covered by insurance.  Her pain is chronic and widespread and she cannot even care for herself with the simplest of tasks.  Pain medication doesn't even begin to alleviate the chronic pain.  Her body is being taken over by new and unknown sickness/disease/ailments that doctors are baffled by and referring her to specialists that her insurance won't cover.   Every time a medical professional seems to have some semblance of an answer, it ends up being a dead-end and she's left discouraged and still in chronic pain.  The life that she knew has been stripped away to where she's almost completely bedridden, relying on caregivers for help constantly.  We are 1. reaching out for emotional support for this family in a heart-breaking crisis  https://www.caringbridge.org/visit/breannahara 2. asking anyone who can, to please consider donating any amount possible to aid with the mounting medical bills and costs of trying to stay afloat as a family of 5 after losing an income and gaining medical debts.A note from Megan:  Many of you have been surprised that she's suffering so much despite "those cute pics of her on facebook".  There have been a couple of days a month - A COUPLE - here and there where she's been able to somewhat get herself out of bed and put on lipstick to feel human again and show up outside of her home and into the world around her.  These moments have been few and far between, and she's often needed to rest in bed for days afterward just to recover from attempting to walk around.  Lately, she hasn't even been able to get out of bed unassisted.  Lately her world has been closing in on her even more and leaving her bedridden and alone.  It's torturous for me (her friend) to have to write that truth down, but I think it's important that we share this harsh truth with all of you so you're aware how desperate the situation truly is.  WE NEED TO GET HER BETTER!With so much love and gratitude,Megan (friend), Coco (mother) & Melissa (sister)

column3: A Fresh Start for Bill ... HALT MS
column9: A Fresh Start for Bill ... HALT MSIntro:  HSCT Help & Your HelpAfter countless months of pressure, this extremely humble person finally let me put up this GoFundMe site. The reason why I’m reaching out to you is because he needs our help. Currently, there is NO cure for Multiple Sclerosis but there could be a way to HALT the progression and possibly repair the damage with a procedure called HSCT (Hematopoietic Stem Cell Transplant). Sharing his MS disease has been a very difficult thing for Bill. He’s NEVER wanted to discuss this debilitating disease to anyone but there’s now … some real HOPE. Diagnosis and What IS MS?Bill was diagnosed with Multiple Sclerosis in 1994, his form of MS is called Relapsing-Remitting. MS is a chronic disease of the central nervous system and is an unpredictable condition that can be relatively benign or entirely disabling. There is NO cure for MS, it damages the nerves in the spinal cord and brain, this causes the exacerbations that lead to difficulties in walking, vision, cognitive problems and other physical difficulties.  More about MS: http://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/multiple-sclerosis/home/ovc-20131882 Today and Future:For the last 23 years, this disease has worsened for him. He has explained to me the exhaustive treatment options over his lifetime having MS; he’s been on countless FDA approved disease modifying drugs and advised by numerous MS Doctors, all while most of these Specialists and the MS Society have said,  “ There will be a cure SOON… just wait.” He’s been on extensive Paleo diets, physical fitness regimes, alternative vitamins, alternative therapies and alternative procedures … he is NOT getting better. Life is more difficult every year and it’s also more difficult for his family. The 20+ years of cumulative damage are now greatly affecting his ability to walk, balance, run a business, process thoughts, and just live life...let alone enjoy life. MS limits ALL of his life! He finds it difficult to imagine where he’ll be in 5, 10 and 20 years. He doesn’t want to deteriorate more but it WILL happen if the underlying disease is not stopped. MS is a persistent and relentless disease. Finding HSCT/Stem Cell Therapy: After years of researching, Bill found a procedure called HSCT. Finally something concrete…HSCT HALTS the disease for a significant number of people and it has been proven in FDA medical trials and international journals for over 15 years. In Scandinavia where MS is very prolific, as a part of their national medical care, HSCT is their standard protocol. Here are some studies looking at the efficacy of HSCT.  Click here  www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/22127896/  and a second study  https://bit.ly/2IV0iTC .Unfortunately, HSCT treatment in the US, Australia and other countries are in medical trials. Unlike standard US medical trials, these trials are almost always paid for by the patient, anywhere from $200-$500K for the treatment, on top of that there is a strict criteria to even get into the study.What is HSCT?HSCT (Hematopoietic Stem Cell Transplant) is an established chemotherapy treatment demonstrated to be effective for halting disease progression in autoimmune diseases such as MS. It should not be confused with Regenerative embryonic or Fat derived stem cell therapy, which have yet to prove their long-term effectiveness for MS. HSCT “reboots” the immune system back to a point before the patient ever developed the "markers" for MS. The patient's body can then, over a period of months/years begin to repair/improve itself. Some of the awful symptoms that have the potential to improve are: balance, fatigue, heat sensivity, cognitive function, and the ability to just simply walk. Although HSCT procedure is NOT FDA approved in the US, it has been done for more than 10 years in clinical trials at Northwestern Hospital in Chicago and many other hospitals around the country. These trials have shown a 90% disease stoppage success rate. These ongoing clinical trials in the US are only for qualifying patients. In countries like Canada, Mexico, Russia, Germany and Israel to name a few, the qualification for patients is broader and although the success rates aren't at the 90% level, they do far exceed the rates of current treatments used in the US.Every legitimate medical treatment available today was at one time previously not FDA approved. However, HSCT itself IS an FDA approved medical treatment for cancer and has been performed millions of times since 1967. It simply isn't currently FDA approved for the indication of an autoimmune disease, but it WILL be eventually. It just takes time for the slow-moving wheels of medicine + Government bureaucracy to complete this approval process but make no mistake about it. . . . just because HSCT is not approved on paper for autoimmune diseases does not mean that it doesn't work. The data are crystal clear today; HSCT is the most effective legitimate medical intervention so far discovered to completely and durably HALT autoimmune diseases like MS. It is not necessary for treatment to be "approved" to show this….. www.healthline.com/health-news/ms-patients-who-received-stem-cell-transplants-still-in-remission-010715%2523modal-close or this 60 Minutes newscast ... https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_0hekaFdmD0&feature=youtu.be.If you only watch one video/click any hot spot on this site, please go to this site below. This is a newscast from the BBC just published on March 19th, 2018; it IS proof of ALL the studies for over a decade … HSCT does HALT Multiple Sclerosis.  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TFyByMiwNNg&feature=youtu.be .Why Treatment at Clínica Ruiz in Mexico:Other countries have clinics currently treating MS with HSCT, since Bill was not accepted at the Northwestern Chicago study (Northwestern has a very narrow acceptance criteria) and because the cost there is approximately $200K, he has applied and was just approved to be treated at Clínica Ruiz in Mexico this summer. Clínica Ruiz is the largest patient volume autoimmune disease HSCT treatment center in the world. Dr. Ruiz Argüelles and Dr. Gómez-Almaguer have performed more than 2500 HSCT procedures during more than 20 years, out of which over 700 have been for MS. Their transplant related mortality is 0.22%, among the safest treatment records in the world. Positive results have been achieved in over 78% of the patients transplanted at Clínica Ruiz.Dr. Guillermo José Ruiz, namesake of this clinic, studied Internal Medicine and Hematology in Mexico and proceeded on to the Mayo Clinic in Rochester MN for his Post-doctoral research and training. As a result of the academic activity stemming from this program, he was elected Mayo Clinic’s distinguished Alumnus and elected Master of the American College of Physicians in 2013. More Information go to Clínica Ruiz’s site:  http://www.hsctmexico.com The Procedure/Recovery & Cost of Treatment :The procedure is intense; 4-6 weeks in the hospital, where T-cells (stem cells) will be harvested from his own bone marrow. He will then undergo a chemotherapy procedure to wipe out the immune system and the memory of MS. After a period of isolation, those T-cells will be reintroduced into the body. The new cells will migrate back to the bone marrow and eventually establish a new immune system that is less likely to attack the central nervous system, therefore HALTING the progression of MS; essentially its like a “FRESH START!”Here is where Bill NEEDS OUR HELP.  Unfortunately, nothing is covered by insurance. The procedure will cost $60,000, these funds would cover the cost of the treatment, travel to Mexico and a 24/7 trained out-patient staff during his time in Mexico. Bill will be there for approximately 4-6 weeks depending on various stages of the protocol and on his immune systems recovery. He will update the GoFundMe site regularly  with his progress. Appreciation:That big hearted person is still there but this disease has taken away:   The Rock Climber,  The Kayaker, The Explorer and most importantly … A Part of that Person whose Treasured things in LIFE are his FAMILY and FRIENDS.With HSCT there is finally some HOPE. The sooner HSCT is performed, the sooner this progression STOPS!~ Walking is man’s best medicine. HippocratesYOU CAN HELP BILL …1.  GIVE whatever you can. No donation is too small.2.  SHARE on Social Media3.  EMAIL this page  http://www.gofundme.com/BillSparrow to your family + friends + co-workers.Thank you for taking the time to read this and again, please SHARE.   #AFreshStart4BillSparrow

Friends, family, and wider community, we reach out today with an urgent call for help. On May 31st our sister, Shani Tsfoni, was struck by a car while jogging in New York. She was taken to Jamaica Hospital where she was found to have fractures in her arm and leg as well as a head injury. In addition to emergency surgery to correct the fractures, Shani has undergone an emergency craniotomy/craniectomy in order to relieve the swelling in her brain. Currently, she is in critical but stable condition. Her treatment team has kept her intubated and sedated to minimize the stress on her body. As with most brain injuries, her prognosis is uncertain. We expect her to stay in the ICU in New York for at least two weeks. Our mother has not left her side and our father is flying from Israel to be with her in a couple of days. Our family hopes to eventually have Shani transferred to a hospital in Atlanta so as to be closer to us. She has a long road to recovery, but Shani is resilient and strong and we know she can overcome this. We are asking today for help in supporting Shani and our family through this difficult time. As anyone can imagine, the medical expenses are more than our family can manage. We need help paying for Shani’s medical treatment. Any donation can make a difference in alleviating the financial burden on our family, and allow us to focus on getting Shani back to her smiling self.Finally, in whatever version of prayer you practice, please hold Shani and our family in your hearts. With love and gratitude, Ariella & Yarden Tsfoni (All donations will be sent to our mother, Laura Wiener)

Skip DiStefano, at age 42 was diagnosed with stage 4 Glioblastoma (brain cancer). Skip was raised in Dedham, and graduated from the Dedham High Class of 1993.  Skip moved to Quincy in 2008 to be closer to the ocean where he worked for many years as a lobsterman and a charter boat captain. Skip and his wife Stacey have 4 beautiful children, Dylan age 8, Lyla age 6, Dominic age 4, and Julia age 2. In January Skip was hospitalized after he suffered a grand mal seizure. It was then that the doctors discovered a tumor, that began at the thalamus and radiated out to the right parietal lobe. Later that week, Skip underwent brain surgery. The doctors removed as much of the tumor as they could without causing further damage. The largest part of the remaining tumor lies deep in his brain near his thalamus and is inoperable. With Skip no longer able to work, no longer able to drive, and visually impaired, you can imagine the financial burden his family now bears. With your support, our goal is to raise over $100,000 to help cover increasing medical costs and family expenses. Thank you in advance for your support. Your donation is greatly appreciated to help ease the burden on this young family.

Aloha!  My name is Maike, I am 32 years old and I was born in Hong Kong, raised in Germany and currently living in Hawaii working as a Photographer.I recently got diagnosed with breast cancer (invasive ductal carcinoma). The tumor is quite aggressive and very large in my right breast (measuring 11cm x 9cm) and has spread to several lymph nodes under my right armpit. The doctors have urged me to immediately start with chemo therapy in order to shrink the tumor enough, so they are able to perform a full mastectomy, after which we would continue with chemo therapy paired with radiation. Since my diagnosis two weeks ago, my husband and I have been driving to hospitals on a regular basis spending many hours each day with doctors and surgeons for consultations and various tests.This has immediately become a full-time job for both of us. It is a very emotional and overwhelming time but we are both staying very optimistic and motivated to win this battle! =)After hours of research and connecting with family and friends who went through similar situations, we have decided on procedures and treatments in Germany, most of which will not be covered by our insurance.My husband and I rely on both of our incomes to be able to pay for the roof over our heads, monthly bills and food. On top of all this, we will have to face the expensive bills for the treatments for my recovery, which makes it all very overwhelming.I am trying to work as much as I can during this time, but for obvious reasons I won't be able to work as much as I would like.It breaks our hearts that we need to ask for financial help since we are two very independent people, but we humbly ask for your support in helping us with the financial funds to help pay for the treatment and unexpected bills over the next several months so that we will be able to focus on becoming cancer free again!We appreciate all the help, support and love coming our way and no matter how small of a donation will be greatly appreciated!Mahalo from the bottom of our hearts!Maike & Eric

Just months before Beth’s 57th birthday, she received a heart wrenching diagnosis. After months of countless doctor appointments, frustration and confusion about why her leg wasn’t working properly, she was diagnosed with Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis, well known for as ALS or Lou Gehrig’s Disease.  In a very short 6-month period, Beth went from a healthy hard working math teacher, to a strong and hopeful woman fighting a serious disease. ALS is a disease of the parts of the nervous system that control voluntary muscle movement. In ALS, motor neurons (nerve cells that control muscle cells) are gradually lost. As these motor neurons are lost, the muscles they control become weak and then nonfunctional. A number of strategies and approaches are being tested around the world, both in the laboratory and in human clinical trials. One of the most significant breakthroughs in the last decade has been the discovery of a number of genes that, when flawed, cause ALS.  In late 2017, Beth took an awful fall while playing her beloved sport of tennis (yes this super woman managed to play tennis every Wednesday with her girlfriends). She was badly bruised and decided to take a little break from the sport as she healed. Not too much later she started experiencing fatigue, lack of mobility and twinges in her feet. Walking short distances had become slightly difficult for her and Beth was starting to get concerned.  After going to the orthopedist and having numerous x-rays taken, she was diagnosed with Spinal Stenosis.  Beth began physical therapy but there was no improvement and was getting worse. She continued with this diagnosis and saw a specialist in Manhattan who had much acclaim with treating patients who had spinal stenosis.  She received a cortisone injection, however, again, there were no improvements. Beth's fears heightened, but being such a strong, prideful woman she hardly complained.  She expressed that she had an awful feeling that she may have MS but tried not to think along those lines.Winter recess was now around the corner and her walking difficulties became more pronounced.  Less than a half a block walk was extremely hard for her and this vivacious woman was having a tough time. It seemed to all be happening so fast.Fast forwarding slightly, Beth was now seeing neurologists and other doctors to see if an alternate diagnosis could be found.  Beth was then diagnosed with ALS.  This disease has moved quickly and she is now in rehab.  Her beautiful and strong family have one goal in mind and that is to get her overseas for a special treatment that has been showing hope for this dreadful disease. Beth is the sweetest, kind-hearted and most hard working mother, friend and women anyone could ask for. She has dedicated her early years to the garment industry and 20+ years to devoting her days to teaching hundreds of kids in Brooklyn, the complicated world of mathematics. Her students, parents and colleagues adore her and has always brought nothing short of smiles, positivity and friendship to her work environment. Beyond her work life, she is a magnificent wife, mother and friend. She has three beautiful children and a loving husband, Ron fighting through each day with her. Her caring, nurturing and loving personality has created a strong foundation for her family and a warm environment for success. But now, Beth needs our help. In addition to the prayers and well wishes, Beth needs financial support to assistant with significant medical expenses, including adaptive living devices, rehab, home care and medical treatments. As you can see, this is a tragic situation. Your funds will directly support Beth’s treatment, alleviate the financial burden of Beth being unable to work, and to assist with the ongoing medical costs that are yet to come. Please share this page to everyone – all the support helps! Thank you so much for your support!

As some of you may already know,  John was recently diagnosed with cancer and will be requiring surgery and treatment.  Anyone who knows John knows he has a huge heart and would do anything for his friends.  Please show your support for John and Xakira and their children Christopher, Annalise and Madison by keeping them in your prayers and by making a donation to help them with their medical expenses.

On June 5th, the Williamson's were involved in a car accident that left  Tess, Lindi and J with serious injuries that will require surgeries and rehabilitation.  Tess will need surgery to repair her leg, hip and jaw.  J, at this time, is in a coma due to head trauma from the accident.  We know that the family will need a lot of support from us, not only emotionally, but financially.  They are a wonderful family that we have been lucky to have in our lives due to Tess' love of softball.  Anything you can do to help us in raising some funds to support them is greatly appreciated.

Frankie Knowles is a sweet, loving 6 year old who was recently diagnosed with a brain tumor.  He was brought to the local emergency room with a bad headache, vomiting and extreme lethargy.  They did a CT scan and determined he had a brain bleed.  He was flown to A.I. DuPont where his endocrinology and neurosurgeon team are based.  There, they did an MRI and found the brain tumor.  He had a procedure to relieve the pressure the blood was putting on his brain.  After the first test for one type of tumor was negative (yay!), a biopsy is now necessary to identify the type and also relieve continued pressure from fluid buildup.  The tumor location is compressing the connection to the pituitary gland.While he was extubated, is breathing on his own, and is starting to converse when not asleep, there are still further tests and procedures to be performed to determine the path forward.  This unfathomable situation for this sweet child bears unfortunate costs.  The funds raised here can be put toward the undesired, impending bills.  While one could only hope that the cost of this type of care would be reasonable, the reality is that unexpected healthcare bills are never reasonable.  Please join the efforts to raise funds to support Rick and Erica in this time of need.  As their focus will be on strength, love, and support to Frankie, and, their daughter Brooklyn, let's help relieve this burden from their minds.#TeamFrankie

Maureen Bole Gibbons was diagnosed with stage 4 lung cancer in May, 2018.  She and her husband Ryan were married just a few short weeks prior to her diagnosis and learned of the unfortunate news two days after returning from their honeymoon.   Both Maureen and Ryan have taken time off from their jobs for the immediate future as Maureen undergoes additional testing and treatment.The money raised here will be used for insurance premiums, deductibles, co-pays and medical expenses that insurance will not cover.  To the extent any of the funds collected are not needed by Maureen and Ryan they intend to donate the balance to a charity that supports cancer research and outreach.
