It’s not always easy to reach out for financial help, but this is a great and easy way for us to show our support for Maureen and Ryan as they navigate this difficult time in their life and new marriage.  All donations are very welcome through the Go Fund me site. If you are more comfortable writing a check, it can be made out to Ryan Gibbons and mailed to 916 Ormond Avenue Drexel Hill, PA 19026.Please keep Maureen, Ryan, and their families in your thoughts and prayers during this difficult time.   Send them your positive energy, love, and courage as they move mountains and make their way past this point on their life’s journey together.- Friends and Family of Ryan

Hi, my name is Earl Teopaco. I’m the oldest child(21) of John and Jennifer Dedmon. I started this GoFundMe with a heavy heart because my mother and father were sadly involved in an ATV accident over the Father’s Day Weekend and were admitted to the ICU in Utah Valley Hospital.John and Jen and the entire family from Las Vegas were celebrating this Father’s Day Weekend at Yuba Lake State Park. On Saturday, June 16, John and Jen went out on an ATV ride. While out on the ATV there was an accident and they were thrown from the ATV and sustained serious injuries. Shortly after they were rushed to the closest hospital via helicopter.My Mother, Jen, was admitted into the hospital with a broken ulna and radius in her left forearm, a fractured rib, a fractured pelvis, a few fractured vertebrae’s of the lower spine, and lacerations/road rash all over her body.My father, John, was admitted into the hospital with a severe head injury. He has multiple facial fractures around his left orbital and is currently in a coma. The doctors are not sure when he will wake up. Doctors ran tests and have found his brain activity is almost completely normal with the acception that they have identified the bleeding in his brain to be a very minor Subarachnoid Hemorrage(SAH), so they are sort of perplexed to why he hasn’t woken up yet... The road to recovery for this type of injury is a long and winding road, so John will need all the loving support of his friends and family to help him through this tough time.John and Jennifer are two loving souls, two warriors of light, who always do their best to create a better world, a better environment for themselves and everyone around them. They find their happiness in helping those around them find their happiness. Besides me, John and Jen also have an 18yr old son, 12yr old son, and 10yr old daughter whom they love unconditionally and support financially, emotionally, mentally, and spiritually. Unfortunately, my father is the family’s main source of income while my mother is a stay at home mom which causes a little hiccup in handling the finances due to the intensive care that both my mom and dad need, the surgeries, cat scans and MRI’s, air transportation to the hospital, and regrettably not having any health insurance. Any and all donations will be going towards our family to help with medical bills and any financial hardships due to my father not being able to work. Any amount helps. If you cannot donate, we still love you. My family and I just ask you pray for John and Jen and send them as much positive, healing energy as you can.Thank you and Namaste <3￼￼

"I know it's stage 4...there is always hope, and no matter my acceptance of the circumstances - my choice will always go in the direction of more life" ( Katia Bozhikova)Dear friends and strangers,For those that don't know Katia, here is a little bit of a background.Katia is my friend, a beautiful soul, the definition of kindness.  She turned 35 in May and she's been dancing with cancer for the past 8 years. In the past 6 months, the journey has not been easy. Now, the journey it's even tougher. Health Insurance slammed her with an outrageous bill and the treatment that gives HOPE is extremely expensive...On medical front - she's been having intense weeks. Spending 4-6 hours in the doctor's office, draining the energy out of her body.  HERE  you can listen to her view about cancer, death, and life.Friends, colleagues, strangers - I am asking again to step in.Please DONATE whatever you can. Remember, no amount is too large or too small.Thank you,Simona

Imagine, you're 30 years old, with a dream to be a lawyer, you have put yourself through Law School. You have so many hard earned letters after your name it's crazy. You move to LA to pursue your dream and hunt down a job.You have a neck pain, go see a Doctor and they tell you that you have Non-Hodgkin Lmmphoma, and that this cancer is such an aggressive strain, they don't think you had it three weeks ago...   You have tumors in your heart and lungs and up you neck.How would you feel...?Hey all, many of you know my friend  Dan Goldberg as the eager, helpful young chap around the Castle, an amateur magician working hard to make a new life for himself here in the US.  He's just 30 years old and a month ago was diagnosed with Non-Hodgkin lymphoma.  At 30 years old.  To say the treatment is taking a toll on him and his career dreams is an understatement.  The cancer is a aggressive and moving fast. Even with insurance he is still incurring costs that are causing great stress, and as you know that just feeds the sickness.Treatment starts with six rounds of intensive chemotherapy,  each of which requires him to be an inpatient at a hospital for 5 days. He has been fighting with his insurance company to have them cover the treatment, literally since his  diagnosis and often in the middle of treatment.It's next to impossible for him to make any kind of a living.  As his friend I can't sit here and watch the man suffer, so I've put together this little go fund me to ask for help for Dan.  Anything would be of help, as little as $5 and much as... well you know cancer treatment charges, they're astronomical.  Then there's rent (he could be evicted soon)  food, transport, medical, it all adds up.  And it's all needed as soon as ossible.  .  I have set a goal of $30,000, although I'm sure the bills will far exceed that.The type of cancer Dan has is called “Double Hit” Lymphoma, which is a very rare subtype of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma – which is already super aggressive. He is at Cedars Sinai because that is one of the few places in the world that has the required expertise on the double hit lymphoma . So if you could all do me a huge favor and help my friend Dan, I would be most grateful, and I know he would be too.Cancer can strike at any time and at any age, having friends who can help in an emergency is a wonderful thing. We can do this xxxThank you in advance.Steve

Our friend and classmate, Bridgette Pumphrey Turner, has been in the hospital since June 17. Her symptoms began with hives and a fever. She was treated for an allergic reaction in Oxford and sent home. Within 24 hours, she was not improving, so her husband, Preston, got her to Memphis. Within 72 hours of her first symptoms, her legs and arms began to show signs of discoloration  and she was in severe pain. She has been in ICU/step down units since.   The physicians are still working on an exact diagnosis.  On July 5, she was air-lifted to Vanderbilt. Her wounds are being treated similar to wounds from a severe burn.   She had surgery on July 12 to remove unhealthy tissue from her lower extremities and apply skin grafts. She will have several more surgeries as she continues to recover. Bridgette has a fourteen-year-old son, John Preston. This fund will allow her friends to get funds directly to Bridgette and her family  so that we can help cover immediate expenses that comes with extended hospital stays away from home. She is being so brave, and in true Bridgette manner is meeting this with a smile and positive outlook.  There will be a long recovery ahead but we believe she is receiving the very best care possible . One way we can help ease this transitional time is by blessing this fund with whatever you feel led to give. Let’s do as we were taught at Hernando High School and follow the golden rule. “Do unto others as you would have them do unto you” #bbstrongUpdate 7/25/18. Since the creation of this fund Bridgette has undergone several skin graft surgeries and ultimately has experienced amputation of both feet, her left hand at the wrist and a portion of her right hand. She will undergo several more surgeries throughout this journey. Prosthetics will be utilized ASAP when appropriate healing has occurred. The focus now is to keep infection at bay and for Bridgette to work with her therapists to gain skills to navigate her new normal.  This will be a long road...a costly road...  Friends, family and strangers have been so generous in blessing this fund. Please continue to share her story. Please continue to bless this fund as you feel led and most of all please continue to pray for Bridgette and her family.  Thank you for all you have done! ❤️

This father and son were in a horrible fire caused by a car explosion and are both currently suffering from 2nd and 3rd degree burns in over 70% of their bodies. They are currently fighting for their lives. They will have to be in the hospital for over two months receiving multiple surgeries. Any donation is greatly appreciated and it will help us immensely.

column3: Help 13 year old Jack Fight Cancer
column9: Hello everyone, we have decided to help raise money for a friend of ours Jack Hytner. At age 13 he has been diagnosed with stage 4 Osteosarcoma. He is an adorable, sweet kid and we are trying to help with their medical bills and expenses. With your kind donations, you can help Jack fight his battle with cancer. Any amount will help. Thank you from the bottom of our hearts and we thank you for your prayers and support.  For supporters who wish to donate over $250, please see the link below.   http://jackscavalry.com/

column3: Please help Bekah and her Family!!
column9: My almost 22 year old niece Bekah (Dan’s sister’s daughter who I’ve know since she was 6) was in a near fatal car accident at 1:55am early Saturday.  She is still (as of this writing on 8/27) in the ICU after an 8 hour surgery yesterday and she's in surgery again right now as I write this.  After her surgeris, and skin grafts, she still has a looooong way to recovery, as you'll read below, including at least a week in the hospital, adapting to a wheelchair for the foreseeable future, finding furniture to support her living downstairs, and dental work that will come later.She is the 2nd oldest of 7 AMAZING, humble, genuine, loving and kind children. The best family on earth I am sure of it - seriously they are amazing and I am SO LUCKY to call them MY family through marrying Bekah's mom's (Lisa) brother Dan. Bekah was not found until 5:30am, approximately 3 hours after hitting the power line and rolling around, managing to get herself off the hood of the car and out of the glass, where she then rolled around screaming in the grass and mud until someone found her on their morning run at 5am.  She quickly spun off the road and hit a power line pole head on.  She was ejected from the car (thank goodness because I don't think she'd be with us had she remained in the car because it is absolutely crushed).  God was with her for sure and she fought through because of her love for her family.  Some of the siblings went to the site of the accident and there was no blood.  Her lacertations were down to the bone and through muscle, but no blood at the scene, even though she was covered when she arrived at the hospital.  I told Lisa yesterday, if anyone doesn't believe in God, just tell them this story.Her hair was found on the pole. Her injuries are agonizingly tragic and include a fracture neck vertebrae, lacerations on her liver, lacerations on her leg in two places (almost to the bone) - all the way around her knee and a huge gash they couldn't even close during surgery yesterday right near that main artery in your leg, 5 broken ribs, a broken scapula, two strokes!!! (omgosh), and torn nerves and ligaments in her hand affecting the mobility of her two middle fingers at this point. Her arm was also completely severed and will need skin grafts and more surgeries.  All of her teeth were chipped and dental work will be expensive in the coming months once she's through the more life threatening tragedy.I know I am writing very candidly, and I don't mean to upset her friends, family, relatives or community.  But for everyone who shares this, it reaches many more people and I want them to understand the gravity of the accident.I am setting up this GoFundMe account because the family really really needs all the financial support they can get.  Bekah's dad just finished paying off the bills from his heart surgery two years ago and they support 7 children!!!, including a 2 year old who they fostered and then adopted.  Adoption runs through our family.  My goal is to raise $40,000 to cover her approximate medical costs (they have a very high out of pocket maximum because they have so many kids and do not work for large corporations).  We also need to raise money to pay for her rent while she moves back in with her parents for a while, the dental work which won't be covered and the list goes on, including her parents being out of work to take care of her, her car, etc.).The whole family really needs all the prayers and support they can get as they adjust their lives for a few months.  Bekah doesn't even realize at this point what all has happened  They are the most lovely family and I cherish them. PLEASE PLEASE PLEASE find it in your HEARTS to help them financially and through prayer.  Remember, we are a VILLAGE and it sometimes takes a village to get through something as tragic as this.  Hug your loved ones and PLEASE PLEASE PLEASE help us raise this money so they don’t have to worry about how to manage and stress over all that and can focus on getting Bekah well and back to a new normal!!  If you aren't able to donate, please PRAY and SHARE this with your network!!!!  And tag anybody and everybody who knows Bekah and her family!I promise you, this money will go toward a wonderful family, who is near and dear to me, and many others who will share this on their facebook walls.  And TRUST me, the money is truly going to what they need.  They have tons of family and community support but we can't do this without raising money.  Karma and God will pay you back, ten fold.

On April 14th, Dana was diagnosed with a very rare and aggressive form of ovarian cancer called Carcinosarcoma. Within one week it had aggressively grown which blocked her bowels. She had emergency surgery on April 22nd to remove the tumors only to find that the cancer had spread throughout her abdomen and bowels. Doctors did not remove all of the tumors during the first surgery because that would have required the complete removal of her bowel system and delayed the option of chemo.After a week of recuperating at Kaiser, she was sent home, but is unfortunately unable to eat any solid food. For the next 6 weeks she will receive her nutrition via an I.V. line called a T.P.N. In addition, Dana is also undergoing chemotherapy and will require another surgery in the near future. Dana has a great support system of family and friends to help her, but she does required around the clock in-home care. Dana is self-employed and recently took over her Father's business after he retired. She was just getting started on building her business when we were all shocked by this awful news. Unfortunately, Dana's cancer is what doctors refer to as "chronic" which means it will continue to be recurring even if she if she is able to get this into remission. Due to her major emergency surgery and chemo, Dana is currently unable to work for the foreseeable future. During this time of no income and the increasing medical expenses, we are asking her family, friends and network to donate what they can to help Dana cover ongoing medical costs and her loss of income.

column3: Brett Copp vs the Brain Tumor
column9: This GoFundMe is to help the Jason Copp family with the expenses related to the treatment of their son, Brett's, brain cancer (Grade IV Glioblastoma Multiforme or GBM). A Little About BrettBrett Copp is a funny, sweet, charismatic, loving fourteen-year-old who just finished junior high. He lives with his dad, Jason (an Airman and part of the Special Forces community at Fort Bragg), in Pinehurst, NC during the school year and spends time with his mom, Beth, and his brothers, Alec and Braxton, in Ohio during the summer. He loves to cook (he wants to become a chef!), hang out with friends, play video games, scuba dive, and get into trouble at his grandma's farm.This summer Brett was supposed to be preparing for his first year of high school. He was going to take drivers education, go camping, and take a trip to Florida with his dad and brothers. Instead, Brett has spent weeks in the hospital having numerous surgeries after being diagnosed with brain cancer - specifically, a Grade IV Glioblastoma Multiforme (GBM). How it StartedBrett began having headaches this spring. His dad, Jason, took him to their doctor in North Carolina. The doctor thought the pain was from allergies and suggested an over the counter allergy medication.On June 4th2018, allergy medications in hand, Brett traveled to Ohio to spend time with his mom and brothers. Later that week, Brett began to struggle with nausea and his mother took him to the doctor. The doctor diagnosed him with an ear infection and Brett was given antibiotics as well as new allergy medication.A week later, Brett's mom took him and his brothers on a camping trip to Pennsylvania. During the trip Brett once again became nauseous. On June 10th, his mom took him to a hospital in Clearfield, PA where they gave him steroids for his ear infection along with an IV and then released him. Brett felt better and continued camping with his family.After returning from camping, Brett would still occasionally feel upset to his stomach, but the family thought it was from his ear infection. On June 22nd, Brett made the trip to Iowa to spend time with his grandpa. However, on June 23rd, Brett began vomiting uncontrollably and was rushed to University of Iowa Stead Family Children's Hospital in Iowa City. When Brett Was DiagnosedAt Stead Family Children's Hospital, they conducted an MRI. Brett was kept in the hospital over the weekend while he and his family anxiously waited for the results. His parents were notified Brett had a mass on his brain and surgery to remove the brain tumor was scheduled.On June 26, Brett had surgery to remove the tumor. What was supposed to be a five-hour surgery turned into a terrifying thirteen-hour waiting game while surgeons tried to remove the brain tumor.A biopsy of the tumor was taken and a week later it was confirmed that Brett had a Grade IV Glioblastoma Multiforme (GBM). What is a Grade IV Glioblastoma Multiforme (GBM)Glioblastoma Multiforme is an aggressive brain cancer that can cause nausea, vomiting, headaches, speech problems and even seizures. Surgery alone cannot remove the entirety of the tumor because glioblastoma grows on healthy brain tissue. This means chemotherapy, radiation, and other forms of aggressive treatment are needed to fight the tumor. Glioblastoma Multiforme is VERY rare in children. Brett's Treatment So FarBrett has had three surgeries:The first surgery took four hours. This surgery was to place an EVD (external ventricular drain) to drain brain fluid. This allowed enough pressure to be taken off his brain so the doctors could prepare for the surgery to remove the tumor.The second surgery was scheduled for five hours but ended up taking over thirteen hours. This surgery was to remove the brain tumor.The third surgery took five hours. This surgery was to place a permanent shunt (tube) that runs from Brett's brain to his stomach. This allows the excess brain fluid he is unable to absorb to drain into his stomach. What is NextBrett has now been transferred to Duke Medical Center in North Carolina. On July 19th, Brett and his dad met with the Duke Medical team (including neuro-oncology director and staff, neuro-surgery director and staff, and radiation director and staff) and discussed what his immediate treatment plan would be as well as the side effects, prospects, etc.Brett's first treatments will be a type of chemotherapy (Temozolomide) in pill form and radiation daily for six to seven weeks at Duke. The doctors have informed the family that this has about a 25% chance of working on Brett's glioblastoma. There will be more treatments after the initial chemo and radiation for approximately one year, but the doctors are hopeful that Brett will be able to return to normal activities after a few weeks post radiation. How You Can HelpAny donation size is helpful. Three $10 donations equal $30. That could be one less meal the family has to pay for.If you are unable to contribute monetarily you can share Brett's GoFundMe page on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, or even through text. GoFundMe believes "Sharing your GoFundMe on Facebook can increase donations by 350%."Don't have a social media account? Try talking to someone in person. GoFundMe predicts, "a face to face ask is 34 times more effective than an email."  The more people who hear about Brett's story means more donations. Every little bit helps! How Will the Funds Be UsedBrett's journey is just beginning. Instead of taking drivers ed with his friends Brett is going to start chemotherapy and radiation treatments. Instead of going to movies on the weekend or staying up all night playing video games he will be spending countless days, weeks, months, in and out of the hospital.The first round of treatment is going to last approximately one year with multiple trips and stays in the Durham area which will be extremely costly. For example, during Brett's first six to seven week chemo and radiation treatments the doctors said Brett would not be able to handle the three to four hours every day it would take to travel for his treatments. His dad has found lodging close to the hospital that could hold the family, but it will cost approximately $4,000 for the first six weeks. That is just a place to stay, that does not include meals.His dad is also getting an in-home tutor for Brett so he will not fall behind when he is too ill to go to school.  Because Brett's mom and brothers live in Ohio, there will be numerous travel costs. Road trip costs include money for gas, food, and hotel. That doesn't take into consideration any emergency trips when the family will have to pay for last minute airline tickets. The closest major airports to his mom's home in Ohio is Detroit, MI or Cleveland, OH. The nearest major airport to Duke Medical Center and Brett's home in Pinehurst is Raleigh, NC.  Last minute airfare for three people (Brett's mom and two brothers) from Detroit to Raleigh is approximately $1500. That is a conservative quote.Brett's mother will also have to take unpaid days off of work to travel to see her son. And when his brothers are unable to make the trip the family will need to find childcare. Help Brett and His Family!While some of the costs may be small (a tank of gas may cost less than $50) everything adds up. Brett's family shouldn't have to worry if they can afford a last minute flight for an emergency procedure or be concerned about how much debt they will accrue living near the hospital while Brett has treatments. By supporting Brett's GoFundMe you're helping Brett and his family concentrate on beating cancer instead of agonizing over their bank account. This summer Brett and his family have been living a nightmare. Help us lift the burden just a little.Brett with his brothers Braxton and Alec (2017)Brett and his dad, Jason Copp (2018)Brett with his mom, Beth, and brothers, Braxton and Alec  (2016)Brett celebrating his 14th birthday this year (2018)Brett scuba diving in Florida (2016)Brett camping in North Carolina with his dad and brothers (2016)Brett with his dad and brothers (2017)Brett on vacation with his dad and brothers (2017)Brett and his dad (2017)Brett getting some sun during his stay at the University of Iowa Stead Family Children's Hospital in Iowa City (June 2018)Brett showing off his special "Brett's Get Well Pillow"  while at the University of Iowa Stead Family Children's Hospital in Iowa City (June 2018)

Josh has been is diagnosed with the final stage of kidney failure ••• stage 5. This is the last stage before dialysis and a transplant. The money raised will be for medical expenses associated with Josh’s treatment. The Phillips family is grounded in faith and is praying for full healing and no dialysis. Thank you for your prayers and generous hearts!

Last year on April 12, 2017, beautiful wife Gervel Sampson received that phone call every spouse dreads. It is a phone call that no one can every really prepare themselves.  It was a call that dramatically changed Gervel and her children’s life forever. Her incredible loving and giving husband, Dr.  Reginald Sampson (Reggie) suffered a massive stroke including hemorrhaging in the brain. He was paralyzed on the entire left side and loss the ability to speak.  He also suffered Congestive Heart Failure, Pneumonia along with other subsequent complications.This catastrophic event left Gervel, Amani and Reggie Jr. emotionally devastated and grief stricken. There were so many unanswered questions that went through their minds. “What is going to happen to my husband that I love and adore?” “What is going to happen to my daddy?” They came together as a family to use all resources to help #ReggieRecover. Reggie spent the last 10 months in hospital care fighting for his life with his beautiful wife and children along by his side never missing one step. No one could ever imagine Reggie would remain in the hospital for 321 days!Family is everything to the Sampson Family. Reggie, the patriarch has been the provider, the loving husband and father and an extraordinary physician.  To witness Gervel and his children respond with so much enduring love and strength to be an advocate for his care brings tears of hope.  Amani  came home to assist with  her daddy's medical practice  and Reggie Jr. dropped out of college to take care of his mother and his daddy.Reggie was discharged on February 27, 2018 from the hospital and is at home now but his recovery continues. Although he is happy to be home with his family, his journey to recovery will be long, arduous and expensive. Reggie’s fighting spirit is inspirational.  Through the amazing grace of his loving wife and children, he is determined to get better.The medical expenditures far exceeded insurance reimbursements not to mention insurance denial of payments (not covered).  Medical (Medicare) insurance will only provide limited resources and reimbursements. It is up to his wife, Gervel and his children to take care of him 24/7. He will need home healthcare, extensive physical therapy, occupational therapy, speech therapy, medication, medical supplies, follow up physician visits and medical transport.The Sampson family is blessed with so many incredible AMAZING friends, family, patients and acquaintances that are looking for a way to help Reggie, Gervel, Amani, and Reggie Jr. with his long-term continuum care. Go Fund Me is now available for all of us (it takes a village) to pull additional resources to help Reggie with his care and for his loving family. We all want Reggie to get better soon!!!!! A man that has touched and given  much to so many people, patients and the medical community deserves a fighting chance.  All donations and support are sincerely appreciated with unconditional love.   Thank youPlease follow Reggie , Gervel and Family Love Story Album on  Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/gervel.jonessampson/media_set?set=a.10213818885124793.1073741961.1187261410&type=3&pnref=lhc#ReggieRecover

Sergeant William “Bill” Nealys’ co-workers would like to take a moment to tell you about a great father and what a selfless individual he is personally and professionally, throughout his 11 year tenure at the West Palm Beach Police Department (Palm Beach County, Florida).Throughout Bills’ career he has worked tirelessly to combat gang violence and bridge gaps between Law Enforcement and the community he serves. While assigned to the Community Response Team-Juvenile Unit, Bill and his co-workers worked passionately with kids in the community.  Bill was instrumental in affecting the lives of countless less fortunate children teaching them violence and drugs were not a way life.  Bill recruited and encouraged all children to become involved in positive programs.  “Cops & Scholars” is a perfect example of this.  “Cops & Scholars” hosts weekly lunches and dinners where quality time is spent positively influencing kids in the community.Bill and his co-workers have great success stories where they were instrumental in assisting children in obtaining acceptance to colleges of their dreams and guiding them toward the path to success.Every day while being selfless and serving the citizens of West Palm Beach, Bill has been fighting stage 4 metastatic melanoma cancer.At 44 years old, married with two awesome sons (13 and 4 years old), Bill is being placed into Hospice care and worries about the future of his family.Proceeds will be used to help Bill, his wife Heather and their two boys during this time in their lives, 100% of funds raised will be given to the Nealy Family.  Thank you for your consideration, Bill and his family are humbled and appreciative knowing we are there for him and his family. #nealystrong#wpbpdstrong

Thank you for any help you can give, prayer and or financial. Our need:Jill has a surgery scheduled September 12 for a craniotomy. We have Medishare for insurance. The surgeon is accepting them as "in network" and will process billing after surgery. The hospital wants us to pay their portion and the anesthesiologist up front before confirming and moving forward. Medishare's policy is to not pay upfront (I don't blame them and understand). Medishare is going to contact the hospital and see if they can convince them to make an exception. We are currently sitting with an up front cash payment of $59010 which needs to be paid imediately. They are giving us a 50% discount. There is an urgency because every week that goes by greater symptoms and problems develope for Jill. Whats going on with Jill:My wife Jill Salter, has a Pineal gland cyst that has to be removed. November 2016 she started having dizziness and struggled with remembering things. We weren't sure what was going on but kept an eye on the symptoms that would come and go. March 2017 Jill had symptoms that resembled a stroke. We took her to Shands ER where they ran EKG, Cat scan, and other tests. They told her she had vertigo. Our family doctor sent her for an MRI. The results came back "clear". However the symptoms became frequent and resembled seizures, happening every week or two and left her with several days recovery each time. In March of 2018 she started having bad "seizure" episodes that would last up to four hours and no less that one hour but the residual effects would last for days. She would have slurred speach, couldn't answer basic questions, slowed motor skills and extreme dizziness. We took her in imediately for another MRI where we were informed a cyst they previously found had grown 40% in one year. Since then what we thought were seizures have been identified as pressure on the brain and what happens is the brain shuts down till it can cope again. These cysts can also cause hearing and vision loss which she has recently started experiencing. She now has these pressure episodes on average once a day lasting one to four hours. Jill has been unable to work for  over a year. Performing basic household tasks can be a major challenge as well. The surgeon Dr Dong Kim in Houston has some great info and an impeccable track record in dealing with this issue. When he met Jill he felt she was an extreme case, most people have episodes lasting one to ten minutes. The reality is these episodes are a result of to much pressure on the brain Wich can end up having permanent effects. With this surgery, Dr Kim has had 100% positive results varying from restoration of quality of life to full restoration.Here's a link to understand the issue and surgery: http://neuro.memorialhermann.org/pineal-cysts/Medishare works by submitting a bill and is paid by a pool of resources donated by it's members. Someone asked me "what happens if Medishare pays, where do these funds go?" These funds will pay for this medical bill and any overages will go back into the Medishare pool so other people who have life changing issues will have confidence that your help has granted them another chance at life.We have peace through all this.  Our faith is that God will provide. While we don't understand it at we know He is good and His mercy endures forever. Thankfor your help! Cory & Jill Salter

column3: Move Jordan to Boston Child Hosp
column9: Meet Jordan Chance. This little child had endured so much in his short lifetime.  He has spent most of his life in a FL hospital but, it has become abundantly clear the hospital is not able to care for his special needs any longer. Boston Children’s Hospital has agreed to take on Jordan’s very special case. Jordan will be airlifted to BCH and start his new journey there but, his family is struggling with the already tens of thousands of dollars in medical bills that have accrued. We are hoping to raise enough money to pay for Jordan’s journey to BCH as well as help his family move to Boston for a short time. Please consider donating to Jordan and his family so he may start a new life in Boston. ❤️Here is the SHORT version of his long story...With no prior indications of any issues in utero, at birth Jordan was diagnosed with cleft soft palate, atrial septal defect, heart murmur, hypotonia, jaundice, sepsis, pelvocaliectasis, hypomagnesemia, hypospadias, micrognathia, retronathia, recessed tounge, airway obstruction, severe GERD, respiratory distress syndrome, pulmonic stenosis, anemia, dialed kidneys, apnea, bradycardia and failure to thrive. Shortly after birth he was diagnosed with Pierre Robin Sequence, a congenital condition of facial abnormalities. PRS is a sequence or chain of certain developmental malformations. The main features are cleft palate, micrognathia, (abnormal positioning of the jaw), retrognathia and glossoptosis (airway obstruction caused by backwards displacement of the tongue). This combination of features typically lead to difficulty breathing and feeding issues. Many months later he was also diagnosed with horizontal nystagmus and conductive hearing loss due to fluid in his ears from the cleft palate. He has had to have bilateral PET tubes placed in both ears and replaced during the time of some of his surgeries. He was also diagnosed with hypoplasia on the left thumb and some neurological issues have been suspected but yet to be diagnosed. Some issues from birth have since resolved or improved over time (kidney, pulmonary, some heart and some facial feature issues). He has been hospitalized the good majority of his short life, and has underwent 10 surgeries so far resulting in many developmental delays, brachycephaly and additional feeding and swallowing regressions. Between countless ER visits and hospital admissions, his time at home was mostly filled with therapies (Feeding/speech, OT & PT) and his drs appointments with his many specialists. Since birth he has struggled with feeding, swallowing, breathing, choking, severe reflux, vomiting and failure to thrive. He has had to have several different types of feeding tubes placed and replaced to assist with nutrition. He has had many NG tubes and G tubes placed and replaced. He has had central lines and broviacs to provide emergency nutrients when feeding was not possible and to supplement feeding during the FTT time. He has also had GJ tubes placed and replaced and more recently ND tubes also placed and replaced, all of which have not been successful in one way or the other. He has had to have some major emergency surgeries to correct the undiscovered malrotation and volvulus discovered only during surgery. He also developed adhesions as a result and needed additional emergency surgery. He has had to deal with several complications from multiple surgeries, many infections and lots of still unresolved GI issues. Also during this current admission they have discovered some additional abnormalities in his stomach and duodenum in his GI tract. After 3 months of being hospitalized, he is currently only receiving nutrition through the broviac catheter leading directly into the heart. He has not been able to feed successfully after the last few major abdominal surgeries.Further genetic abnormalities have been suspected but have only in the very recent been discovered. A super rare DNA change has been found and located in the p part of chromosome 19. Inside chromosome 19p13.2, there is a new variant in the SMRCA4 gene. This is a super new, super rare finding which there is no information available yet for. He is only 1 of 5 in the world who have been diagnosed with this genetic mutation. There are no medical publishings and very limited studies conducted. It is believed that he is the only one in the US with this finding. What this all means to Jordan and his future is still unknown but may be related to many of his struggles. He has come a very long way but has a long road ahead of him. However even with all these issues he’s the best boy you’ll ever meet. He will sweep you off your feet and dive right into to your heart with his sweetness, good looks and charm. No matter what he goes through he always has a big smile on his face. We love Jordan and his parents, Pete and Ena, so much and we just want to see this little boy get a fighting chance! -Bonnie & Bryon

Dear Friends and family,There are times in most of our lives when we must face adversity and hardship. That time is now for our wonderful friends Clay and Kimberly (Kevin Devaney’s twin sister) Rawn. As many of you know, Kim underwent a heart and double lung transplant a year and a half ago resulting from a terribly aggressive auto immune disease. While her amazing recovery is nothing short of a miracle, it is a daily battle fraught with numerous setbacks, endless medicines, procedures and constant travel back to San Francisco for doctor’s visits with her transplant team. In a cruel twist of fate, Kim’s husband Clay is now facing the battle of his life. Recently Clay underwent major surgery for colon cancer which has been determined to be stage 4, having spread to other organs. He had been Kim’s constant rock and caregiver during her medical crisis. Clay recently started chemo treatment, but it will be an uphill battle. Now they both need your help! Neither one of them has worked in over a year and their current medical insurance will soon end. The emotional, physical and financial burdens are more than anyone should have to bear. Please find it in your hearts to help out our dear friends who have given back so much over the years. Support this GoFundMe page with any donations you can and help get our amazing friends Kim and Clay through this most difficult of times. Thank you and God bless!

Why this one man? Why "our Tony." Like many families, we have asked that question time-and-time again since we learned that Tony was diagnosed with stage 4 Lung Cancer. Cancer does not care that Tony represents what is best in our humanity: because cancer is blind, because cancer has no empathy.So cancer has decided to try and take Tony from us, from this world, a truly special soul.  We as Tony’s family and friends are asking all who can, to help us fight cancer and to prolong a souls life. In asking this we also understand you will ask "Why this one man?" – "why Tony Lake."  We do not write these words lightly, nor take for granted the weight of categorizing Tony as a "truly special soul." But we must answer the "why" for each of you to give.First Tony falls into the category of those who choose kindness… who choose to light the world with understanding, generosity, patience and goodness, even though his younger days were filled with darkness. As a child who incurred the wrath of an alcoholic and loss of a brother, he decided to protect those around him, regardless of what that meant for him.Tony then chose to serve his country, and it was there as a Navy Sea Bee that his foundation as a union member in LIUNA and his talent in all phases of construction was nurtured. After serving, Tony strapped his meager belongings to his motorcycle and drove from the west coast to the east coast. There he married the love of his life, a single mom with two kids – both who easily called him "dad." Two more kids and a home were added on a single income of a construction worker; an income that would also support the care of two critically ill parents. An avid mountain biker, Tony thought he had injured his ribs in a fall. Instead the cancer gave him an inoperable tumor that grew to crack two ribs. Inside the lung the cancer also sits and waits. Traditional treatments have slightly reduced the larger tumor, but without targeted and new treatments, Tony’s life expectancy is 6 months. Insurance will not cover these prolonging treatments.While not of retirement age he will soon be forced to retire on a limited income, one that cannot pay for any new treatments much less continue with his present treatments. As his family we want more for Tony, because he has given so much to so many. Why should you decide to help this one man? Because the world is truly a better place with Tony in it.Thank you.

￼On Friday, March 16th our cheerful Karen Bright was blindsided with a medical complication that now has her fighting for her own life. There are still so many questions to be answered and so many hurdles still to come.Karen, Darrel and Rachel are surrounded by so many loving family members, friends and co-workers that are all on the sidelines asking, "what can I do to help?" The first request is your continued prayers. Pray for strength and pray for healing. When we pray, God hears more than we say, He answers more than we ask, and gives more than we imagine but in his own time and in his own ways.We are asking those willing, to assist the family financially, allowing them to fully focus on what’s most important at this time, which is Karen and her health. To have the basic expenses covered during this time of crisis would be an enormous support to the family.Everyone no matter how big and strong could use a little help. (despite their adorable disguise as the most powerful animal) ￼The family has also created a calendar for those looking to help with meals, grocery shopping and spending time with the family in the waiting room. The calendar can be found by visiting https://my.lotsahelpinghands.com/community/karenshanleybright(you can also gain access by visiting lotsahelpinghands.com - enter Bright and 28409 for the zip code)Never give up! Today is hard, tomorrow will be worse but the day after tomorrow will be Bright. Bright like Karen always is . . .￼￼￼￼￼ Your support and genoristy is forever apperciated!This campaign is set up on behalf of John Darrel Bright and Karen Shanley Bright.

On Friday April 20th, 2018 Frankie Arzaga was assaulted by a man in a homophobic rage.While waiting for an Uber in downtown Phoenix a drunk man attacked Frankie and his friend while screaming homophobic slurs. Frankie stepped in to defend his friend when the man threw Frankie to the ground and curb stomped his right leg as he was attempting to crawl away. His right knee cap was shattered, and right tibia fractured.He was admitted to Phoenix St. Lukes later that night. His leg was temporarily set and he was discharged 2 days later after inflammation subsided, but he is still awaiting surgery to set the bone and repair his knee.Frankie has impacted so many people in Phoenix's LGBTQ+ community. He's served as impromptu therapist and listened while we poured our heart and soul out, he's helped us feel confident with our image and love ourselves, he's gone out of his way to defend his family and chosen family when one of them is threatened. He's done nothing but love Phoenix and the people in this city and it's time for us to return the favor.No one deserves the amount of hate and pain Frankie has been forced to endure. While none of us are orthopedic surgeons, we can all help out in other ways. Frankie is going to need to be off his feet for post-surgery recovery and will be unable to work and support himself financially. He is also without health insurance and will have to pay for his hospital and surgical bills out of pocket. If you have to means, please help contribute. The $26,000 total will cover the initial hospital stay ($14,000), surgery needed to set his leg and knee ($9,000), and cover his rent, utilities and living expenses for the 3 month recovery time ($3,000). If you can't contribute financially but still want to help feel free to contact Symon L., Ruben G., or Emily C.More details regarding the incident will be released as the investigation continues, but the priority for this GoFundMe is to help get Frankie the medical care he needs.Thanks PHX,Love The Cult

In Venezuela, Laura’s insurance will only pay USD $15 for her cancer treatment. Her medications alone cost more than USD $50,000.Laura’s story (para Español ir al final de este texto / look below for Japanese)------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- I was recently diagnosed with Stage III Melanoma, the most life-threatening and aggressive form of skin cancer. Battling an advanced form of cancer is challenging in any circumstance, but in Venezuela, a country suffering a widespread humanitarian crisis, it can feel impossible.I support myself and my 5 year-old daughter illustrating children’s books. Venezuela’s runaway hyperinflation, has cut my income to less than USD $20 a month. For this same reason, my insurance only pays USD $15 for my cancer treatment.The challengesFor years, Venezuela has made international headlines for its severe food and medicine shortages. We are currently experiencing the highest inflation rates in the world and a crisis with no end in sight.Millions have fled the country, seeking refuge abroad. I chose to stay in Venezuela to care for my mother, and protect my family’s small dairy farm. Even if I find the resources to pay for treatment, the life-saving immunotherapy drugs I need aren’t available in Venezuela. I will have to source the drugs internationally, which could add hundreds of thousands of dollars  to the cost of my treatment. Nobody wants to plead for money from friends and family, but I have no choice. I simply cannot pay for treatment on my own.I am only 44 years old and I have every intention of seeing my daughter, Iroma, grow into a beautiful young woman. I will not let cancer or the Venezuelan crisis win this fight. Please help me defeat this horrible disease and overcome these dire circumstances.  I hope to use your donations to pay for the medications, surgeries and expenses as I receive my treatment. Any donation, big or small, helps reach our USD $50,000 goal. Each gift means the world to me. Thank you for your love and compassion, Laura. -------En Venezuela, el seguro médico de Laura sólo cubre $15 (USD) dólares para su tratamiento contra el cáncer. Ella necesita al menos $50 mil dólares para pagar los medicamentos.La situación de Laura y los retos de enfermarse en un país en ruinas---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Queridos amigos y familiares: Hace poco fui diagnosticada con el tipo de cáncer de piel más agresivo y peligroso:  melanoma etapa 3. Soy madre de una niña de apenas cinco añitos, a quién mantengo con mis ingresos como ilustradora de cuentos para niños.Superar un cáncer y pagar los gastos de un tratamiento tan costoso es una proeza en cualquier país, pero en la Venezuela de hoy, sumergida en una crisis humanitaria sin precedentes en su historia, la lucha es mucho más cuesta arriba.Debido a la hiperinflación en Venezuela, la más alta del mundo, y a la aberración en los controles de cambio, mis ingresos equivalen apenas a menos de $20 dólares al mes. Mi seguro sólo cubre unos $15 dólares para gastos médicos. Enfermarse en Venezuela cuesta la vida En Venezuela, la escasez crónica de comida y medicinas cobra vidas a diario. Millones de Venezolanos se han visto obligados a abandonar el país en busca de protección y una vida digna. Decidí quedarme en mi país para cuidar de mi madre, y proteger nuestra pequeña granja familiar en Los Andes, que se ha visto amenazada por invasores.Incluso si tuviese los recursos económicos para pagar mi tratamiento, los medicamentos que necesito para la inmunoterapia que me salvaría la vida no están disponibles en Venezuela. Para recibir el tratamiento, tendría que importarlos o trasladarme a otro país, lo que podría añadir cientos de miles de dólares al costo de mi tratamiento. A nadie le gusta pedir dinero a sus amigos y familiares, pero no tengo ninguna otra opción, ya que simplemente no tengo los recursos para pagar los costos yo misma.Tengo sólo 44 años, mi mayor anhelo es proteger a mi hija Iroma y verla crecer. No permitiré que el cáncer o la crisis de Venezuela me de por vencida. Te pido por favor que me ayudes a luchar contra esta enfermedad y mis circunstancias.  Las donaciones serán utilizadas para pagar por los medicamentos, cirugías y demás gastos médicos. Cualquier monto es bienvenido y ayuda a llegar a nuestra meta de $50 mil dólares.  Cada ayuda es un regalo que significa el mundo para mi.  Gracias por tu ayuda y compasión,  Laura-------私はラウラといいます。ベネズエラで、私の保険では１５ドルしか出ないのですが、私の治 療にかかる医療費は、５万ドル以上です。診断されたガンは、ステージ3の悪性黒色腫で、皮膚がんの中で、 一番致死的な種類です。ステージ３のガンと戦うことは、どこでも辛いことですが、人道上 の危機にあるベネズエラの場合、本当に、それは無理に思えます。今、絵本のイラストを描く仕事で、自分と５歳の娘の生活費を稼い でいますが、ハイパーインフレーションの影響で、今の月給は、約 ２０ドルしか貰えません。実は、お金が完全に用意できても、それだけで治すことはできませ ん。必要な免疫療法薬物は、ベネズエラでは販売していないため、 外国で探すことが必要になります。親戚や友達、知り合いの皆に、こういうお願いすることは、自分に とって物凄く大変なことですが、自分の力だけでは、医療費を絶対 に支払うことが出来ません。44歳のお母さんとして、娘のイロマちゃんを立派な女性になるま で、必ず一緒にいたいんです。私は、 ガンやベネズエラの金融危機に、絶対に負けたくない！どうか助けてください、この大変な状態を乗り越えて、私は、病気 に打ち勝ちたい。皆の寄付で、イタリアのミラノで治療が受けられる可能性がありま すが、ビザを取るためには、 医療費をちゃんと支払えることを確認し、約束するための書類が必 要となります。皆の協力は、何よりも宝物です。みんなを愛しています。本当にあ りがとうございます。ラウラ---------
Medical Report (Informe Medico): the images below are a report of Laura's diagnose.------------------------------------The drugs Laura needs are Ipilumimab and Nivolumab.Our Campaign-----------------------------------Our campaign was organized by Laura's sister, Lea Stagno, who lives in New York and is working tirelessly to ensure that Laura gets the lifesaving treatment she needs. The funds will be used to pay for or reimburse Laura's surgeries, hospitalizations, medications, travel, legal expenses relating to travel outside of Venezuela and living expenses while she is receiving treatment and examinations related to her cancer diagnosis. Unfortunately we cannot transfer the money directly to Laura because GoFundMe requires a US-based SSN, and as GoFundMe is subjecting Venezuelan's to extreme scrutiny, we want to let you know that the money will be transferred directly to Lea Stagno's account in the US and later used to directly pay for Laura's expenses or else transferred to Laura's Account here in the US. Thank you so much for your support.

Hi everyone,My little brother, Nathan Dyer, had the incredible opportunity to travel with my cousin to Morocco while they visited her husband's family. He was having an amazing time riding camels and exploring - all while wearing a replica Indiana Jones hat!About two weeks in, Nathan came down with symptoms that looked like traveler's sickness. My cousins took him to see a doctor where he was hydrated and given some antibiotics. Days later, he still was not improving - in fact, he was getting worse. He was so weak that he could not even stand. My cousins took him to a hospital where he became worse and worse, until he was in a coma-like state.My mom started working with his traveler's insurance to get him back to the States for better treatment, but he was not stable enough to move that far. It was ultimately decided that he would be flown to Paris, France. Luckily, his traveler's insurance covered my mom's flight to Paris and she was there to meet him when he arrived. The French medical staff told her that he had not been properly treated while in Morocco. Nathan had a bacterial infection, was on a ventilator, was close to kidney failure, and had had at least one seizure.  His kidneys are functioning better now, but he has had another seizure. He was moved to another hospital in Paris to be treated by a specialist, but his initial diagnosis was found to be incorrect. He is still only minimally conscious and we know that the road to recovery is going to be a long one.My family is hard-working and we do not have much. While our focus is on Nathan, we cannot help but worry about how we are going to pay for his international healthcare after his traveler's insurance stops covering care. Nathan and my mom are on BadgerCare, which does not cover healthcare internationally. Nathan was very lucky to be included in my cousin's travel plans and budget and, as a hard worker himself, was able to pay for his plane ticket to Morocco with his own savings from working at the Lake Geneva Cruise Line. My mom works for hourly wages and is currently not working as she is with Nathan in France - we have no money coming in. I am a graduate student and do not have much to begin with. I am leaving to see my little brother soon, which means that I won't be working either.We need a lot of support. Your donation will help my family with...-Plane tickets-Lodging-Food-Medical expenses-To help us stay on our feet after Nathan gets better and my family has not been workingWe have already accumulated $4,200 worth of medical expenses from Nathan's care in Morocco and nearly $26,000 worth of medical expenses from Nathan's current hospital in Paris; this does not include the first hospital that he was treated at in Paris and the additional costs that build up with each passing day. While news sources are emphasizing our efforts to bring Nathan back to the United States as soon as possible, he does not have a diagnosis. Because we do not know what is causing his illness yet, we do not know if he is stable or what other complications may arise if he tries to fly right away. We do not know when he will be able to fly the distance from France to Wisconsin.  This GoFundMe will be used to address all of the above listed costs as they arise - not just the potential full cost of an air ambulance. Nathan is a smart, talented guy with the driest sense of humor and a lot of fight in him. He deserved to have the adventure of a lifetime in Morocco. We want to make sure that he can be well taken care of and surrounded by the people who love him.Thank you,Rachel Dyer*updated 5/2/2018

My darling daughter Heather was diagnosed with aggressive glioblastoma  brain cancer 2 years ago when she was 39 yrs old.  She is married with 3 young children ages 12, 10 and 7.  This cancer is known to be very difficult to treat and has a poor prognosis.   She underwent brain surgery, radiation, and chemotherapy,  finally completing treatment in December 2016.    Heather was monitored with brain MRI's every 3 months.  She was almost back to her old self after about a year off treatment.   In June 2018 we were devastated  to find out that the cancer was back.  Heather had another brain resection, and she is doing okay, very functional, but tires easily.  When she met  the neurosurgeon and neuro-oncologist they mentioned that there are clinical trials looking at a very promising treatment called Opdivo a Check Point inhibitor.  Currently the drug is in early testing in brain cancer.  Unfortunately at this time there are no clinical trials for recurrent brain cancers like Heather's.  The Opdivo is not yet approved for brain cancer so unfortunately the insurance will not cover the cost of the medication, which is about $150,000.00 for a year of infusions.  There have been so many of you that have asked how they might be able to help us.  Assistance with the cost of this medication would be most helpful.  Heather will be getting her 1st infusion on Thursday and will continue to receive the medication every 2 weeks.  Unfortunately,  the cancer is very likely to return but we are praying for  the longest remission possible.  Extending her life will be priceless.   Thank you for any assistance you can provide!

~ “Where there is great love, there are always miracles.” ~ Willa CatherI would love to tell the story of a beautiful family from the island of Trinidad & Tobago … our neighbors who became our family. A family who is filled with such love and hope during their difficult journey, that they are inspiring everyone they meet. Their baby boy needs your help today…Meet Jason Jagdeo and Marissa Naidoo-Jagdeo…loving parents of Baby Michael Anthony Jagdeo (their little Hero aka “Miracle Mikey”).    Background: On November 2nd, 2015, Jason and Marissa’s lives changed forever; their beautiful angel, Michael Anthony Jagdeo, was born. Unfortunately, his birth was so traumatic that it became life-threatening to both mommy and baby. By nothing short of a miracle, they both survived. We’ve affectionately nicknamed him our “Miracle Mikey”.Mikey was kept in NICU for 3 weeks…fighting for his life. He had suffered brain damage, so extensive that doctors predicted that he would never walk or talk; this news devastated his parents, but they never gave up hope! They have faith that Mikey will defy all odds.On his second day of life, Mikey’s seizures began … and evolved over time, into a rare form of epilepsy, West Syndrome, resulting in hundreds of daily seizures. They were told that there is no cure and coupled with Mikey’s extensive brain damage, his prognosis was extremely poor. Yet, his parents never gave up hope. Together with a team of doctors, they cycled through many different combinations of medicines until they found a regime which drastically reduced his seizures! Doctors were amazed! Another miracle! However, because of the extent of his brain damage, doctors predict that his seizures would continue to evolve over his lifetime…and now, they have begun to evolve. Although heartbroken, his parents have faith that Mikey’s healing is on the way! They embody this quote: “where there is great love…there are always miracles.” There is no doubt that because of their unwavering love, faith and devotion, Mikey will continue to defy all odds.How you can help:                                                                                              For the first time, in a long time, this beautiful family has been given some hope. The specialists have ruled out surgery as an option because Mikey’s brain damage is too widespread. They have instead recommended Hyperbaric Oxygen Therapy to improve his quality of life and to reduce, and hopefully eliminate, his seizures. Since Mikey continues to defy all odds, his family believes that another miracle is in the making. To see Mikey walk, talk, run and play one day would be the greatest blessing ever.However, to avoid any untoward adverse effects as a result of Mikey’s extensive brain injury and the complex, evolving nature of his seizure disorder, this specialized treatment would have to be accessed out of country, under the careful guidance of a specialist with more than 30 years experience in treating children with seizure disorders.We would need to raise at least US$89,000.00 to make Mikey’s dream a reality. Through your kindness today, we can do this!Mikey is a little hero who bravely fights his battles every day and lights up the world with his love! He is an angel on this earth, whose eyes radiate hope and determination. He just needs a little help from you right now to get him to his breakthrough.His parents are two of the most beautiful souls you will ever meet. Despite their difficult journey, they are uplifting and inspiring everyone with their love, faith and joy! To see them in tears shatters your heart to pieces. They are blessings to others; let us bless them in return with our kindness. They wish to do everything possible for Mikey because they have faith that he will do the impossible…as he has done thus far! His story is truly a miracle in motion…..

Hello all Fountain Day Families and Alumni!For the past few weeks, our FDS favorites Dave and Ranum have been spending most of their days and nights at the Children’s Hospital of Los Angeles. Their 5 month old son, Levi, has been fighting for his life and I’m happy to report that he is improving everyday! But Levi’s condition is still precarious (the doctors are trying to figure of the cause of his cardiac issues), and Dave and Ranum are still dealing with all of life’s obstacles and medical bills.  Simran Baidwan and I were talking one morning after drop off and thought that a go fund me might be the best way to help this very loved family! Please share this quickly and often! This family needs the support of our amazing FDS community!

Our beloved fellow football official, Tod Reese, has recently been  diagnosed with a very aggressive form of pancreatic cancer.   Tod is a dedicated adoring father of 2 daughters, Delaney and Kaitlin.  He is a loving and caring husband to his wife, Holly.   Tod is undergoing every treatment possible to help in his fight against cancer.  As you might imagine this has taken a heavy burden for him and his family both emotionally and financially.In our efforts to assist Tod and his family with these challenges we are asking that you dig deep into your heart and say some prayers for Tod and his  amazing family as they work through this period on their life.  We also kindly request that you find it within yourself to offer a donation of any size to  Tod and his family through these trying times via this GoFundMe page.  Any and all amounts are very much welcomed by the family and they send their appreciation in advance for your prayers and thoughts.  Tod has helped mentor and advocate for football officials for over 40 years.  He has been a clinician, a fellow on-field official, and has inspired many to achieve the highest levels of football officiating which includes some officials that work today in the NFL.As great as Tod is as a football official during the game he is an even better teacher of how to be an exceptional human being.  I was honored to have him on my crew for my first year as a Referee. He made me better and the crew better each and every game we had both on and off the football field.We kindly ask that you help us raise money to offset the financial obligations in Tod's battle against this horrific disease.  With your help, love and prayers we will see Tod working another college football game in the near future.  And we can expect he'll be there along our side making everyone else around him just that much more better and kinder!

For many, Ana Roman represents the heart and soul of the Ralph Lauren Corporation. Known as both the office mom and the sweetest woman in the company, she has always gone out of her way to make her colleagues’ days a little brighter and always better. And now, more than ever, she needs us to return the favor.In February, Ana suffered a fall, and had to leave the office for extensive shoulder surgery. She faced the procedure with the same courage and determination she approaches any obstacle. However, while recovering, she suffered a major heart attack and stroke and is now in a coma. Her doctors are still unsure of her prognosis, but her family is hopeful for a miracle. And if anyone can pull off a miracle, it would be Ana.Ana’s loving husband, Jose, has been by her side daily, as has her mother, brother and sisters. Her amazing son, Joseph, has been juggling his university studies, coordinating family efforts, while also managing the lines of communication to keep us all informed on her progress. The family has asked for nothing but prayers, well wishes, and good vibes. But there is much more we can do.We are all aware that even with insurance, emergency medical costs can be exorbitant and overwhelming. All those seemingly small individual costs add up quickly to compound an already stressful situation. And even when Ana wakes, the road to full recovery will most likely be long and arduous.The best way to give back to Ana is to take care of her family. We created this fund to alleviate some of the imminent financial concerns, so they can continue to be there with her and for her. The money raised will go directly to them to use for medical bills, transportation costs, and to provide support and care for them so they can focus on her.

￼￼￼Shortly after Mother's Day, our family was rocked by the news that Amy was diagnosed with aggressive Stage 4 Uterine Cancer that had spread to the lining of her abdomen. Two weeks later she was in Chicago at Northwestern Hospital undergoing the removal of her uterus, ovaries, fallopian tubes and the omentum where tumors were found. The surgery was successful in removing everything more than 1 centimeter but we learned that there was a splattering of tiny spots of cancer scattered throughout her pelvic/abdominal area.  Her pathology report came back and after deep research and  many conversations with Gynecological Oncologists and Naturopathic Oncologists,  she and Mike faced the hard reality that the traditional route--- Surgery/High Dose Chemotherapy/ Radiation- has a very poor success rate.They were told that chemotherapy would not be curative. Chemo isn't as successful because this type of cancer has a high and rapid recurrence rate that can happen even before the body has recovered from the initial round of chemo.  This leaves patients who can't do more chemo with no treatment options to handle the recurrence.With this reality facing her, Amy and Mike, after much prayer, feel that traditional chemo is the wrong choice for her and have made the decision to seek Integrative Naturopathic treatment- that combines low dose chemo and immune boosting therapies to help her body become stronger. She and Mike will leave for a clinic near the US/Mexico border on July 19th. They expect to be at the clinic for 3 to 5 weeks and will then return with a plan she will continue at home. While the Naturopathic choice may seem bold to us at first, in reality she has made a very logical decision to reject traditional treatment. Our family is behind her decision 100% and believe that God has led her down this path for a reason. Since Amy's health insurance only covers the conventional chemo/radiation route, we are asking friends and family to help us raise money to make the financial side of this a little easier to bear so that Amy can focus on healing and strength to keep up with their two precious and energetic boys. The costs include time at the clinic, at home treatment costs, supplements, infusions, missed wages and travel.We ask you continue to pray for Mike, Amy, Evan and Andrew and for our entire family. Thanks to the power of your continued prayer, we have felt our initial devastation lift and the light of God's promises start shining through. Thank you for continuing to pray for healing, wisdom and lots of joy filled days as we embrace this detour with determination.[When you pray, you must believe and not doubt, because the one who doubts is like a wave of the sea, blown and tossed by the wind.— James 1:6]

Hi there! My name is Atianna and I am asking you to please help save my son Nick’s life! Nick was Diagnosed with Stage 4 High Risk Neuroblastoma on May 24, 2018.Help Save ‘Super Nick’! We need you!I'm a Single Mom of Three Kids.Nick is a 4 year old little boy with two siblings; Jasmine 12 and David 7. My beautiful son, Nick, is the bravest and most amazing person I have ever known  in my life. His smile hardly ever seems to leave his face. His warm and silly personality has everyone falling head over heels for him. Our nurses never seem to forget him! Nurses visit our room from all floors of the hospital just to say hello, as he leaves a lasting impression with everyone. Choc hospital has named my sweet little boy, ‘Super Nick’ because of his continuous positive spirit and endless level of courage! Our nurses made a poster ‘Super Nicks Room’ and hung it on his hospital room door for everyone to see!Our story began in the most complex and confusing way.. Nick appeared perfectly healthy without any health issues prior to dropping him off to school and rushing to work one morning. It all started as a regular day at school for Nick.. Until he jumped from a little toddler slide while playing at school and hurt his ankle. When I picked him up from school that day, we rushed to our pediatrician and then to mission hospital for an X-ray.. no breaks or fractures were found...we were sent home. Strangely, Nicks pain did not improve with each passing day and instead traveled to his hip and thigh area. With numerous visits to the doctor, including an orthopedic specialist and repeated X-rays, we were told that it was an assumed pulled muscle that should heal with some time.Nicks pain was horrific, unexplainable and worrisome. I took my 4 year old baby boy to our pediatrician a handful of times, each time asking why the pain was traveling to different areas of his legs and back.. each time we were sent home without the right answer. We were distracted by the fall and by Nicks healthy weight, appetite and demeanor. Our pediatrician decided to get some blood tests taken from Nick.. One abnormal lab led us to CHOC children’s hospital Emergency Room, where we came in contact with a very special Doctor that said she would admit us and not let us leave until she got to the bottom of this. Nicks labs were taken again and had worsened from the last ones taken. The following day Nick had an emergency MRI and Catscan done under anesthesia. Soon the sky became dark as we were given the diagnosis of Stage IV High Risk neuroblastoma cancer on May 24, 2018. My world truly turned upside down. How could my innocent child be given a 66% chance of survival from Choc and 30% survival from the cancer association?  All these numbers and statistics gave me little hope, until one day I had decided that we would fight as though we were certain that Nick was the surviving and thriving number. Currently, my son is being treated at CHOC children’s hospital in Orange, California.Over the next year and a half we have a road map set by the oncology team at CHOC that includes three phases of aggressive treatment.  Nicky will endure 2 surgeries within the first phase of treatment which includes 6 rounds of of aggressive inpatient chemotherapy, the retrieval of stem cells from Nick that will be frozen and used to ‘save him’ after intense radiation and ongoing high doses of chemo in phase two of treatment.  Phase 2 of treatment will include 6 weeks of continuous inpatient stay for three cycles with 3 to 4 week breaks in between.. and finally, a stem cell transplant (using his own stem cells) during his Immunotherapy in phase 3 of treatment to ‘save him’ from the damage that radiation and chemo will cause. There is a hope for the possibility of more advanced treatment in Memorial Sloan Kettering Hospital of N.Y. that is the one and only facility to offer cancer vaccines to protect patients from reoccurring cancer after treatment.Nick will be treated with 3F8, which is Memorial Sloan Kettering's proprietary antibody against GD2. It is an experimental medication waiting to be approved by the FDA. It is made only at Memorial Sloan Kettering and other hospitals don't have access to it at this time.Also, Memorial Sloan Kettering has a clinical trial ongoing for a vaccine therapy after GD2 therapy, but it is only available on trial at Memorial Sloan Kettering, CHOC doesn’t  have access to it. Memorial Sloan Kettering treatment is different than what most other centers are using as ‘standard of care’ for this type of rare and aggressive form of cancer. We would end up living in New York  periodically for 2 -3 months each time, getting rounds of radiation and numerous rounds of immune and antibody therapies.  I have been tirelessly searching for more options.  Through outreach to many doctors and organizations, Nick has been offered an opportunity to participate in a new alternative treatment that is not covered by insurance. Please help Nick in his battle with Neuroblastoma cancer!Phase 2  of treatment for Nick, will consist of 6 weeks inpatient of radiation and chemo at a time, then home for a short while and back again with three rotations like this. If Nick survives then phase 3 of treatment begins, which is what we look forward to, Immuno therapy. The doctors explained that Nicks risks are, infertility, deafness, becoming cross eyed, severe pain from radiation, learning disabilities, relapse of cancer, new types of cancers that can be caused by the treatment, and much more. This is all an absolute nightmare. We pray that Nick will fight this cancer and win!! We will fight this battle with him! He is the strongest, bravest, funniest, most affectionate little boy in the world! Nick loves music, it makes him feel better. He receives music therapy at CHOC to cheer him up and heal his spirit. This picture was taken during Nicks first round of chemo just a week after we were diagnosed.Excited to be home and all together for the first day! Siblings were in deep heart ache to be separated during Nicks hospital stay. We had difficulty finding help to watch David and Jasmine during Nicks first round, which was a long 3 week stay. We hoped to have two weeks home together before returning to the hospital for round two of inpatient chemo but we had two emergency trips to the hospital for infections, fevers, hives and more, that unfortunately kept us away from home for almost all of the duration of our anticipated ‘home time’ together. This has been painful for all of us. Watching Nick suffer and being split apart from one another during our hospital stays, has left each of us broken.I had to stop working as soon as Nick was diagnosed, hospital expenses and bills are piling up. I am a single mother and have no idea how I will support my family with this horrible diagnosis and time that I must and will always spend at Nicks bedside. We are in a desperate need of financial resources to help sustain treatment, alternative medications and all expenses that this crisis has brought upon our family.The cost for alternative treatment is substantial, and the need to start is urgent! Thank you in advance for all your love and support!

If you've met Willa Pauletti, you know she's a feisty, fabulous three year old, an independent spirit, a wonderful middle sister and a light in this world. Unfortunately, sweet Willa is facing her biggest challenge yet. In July 2018, she was diagnosed with Neuroblastoma. She started receiving treatment at Memorial Sloan Kettering Hospital (MSK) in New York City starting July 11th.  She has since tested negative for presence of the disease in her bone marrow, an encouraging result. Willa’s doctor specializes in this disease and is walking the Pauletti family through each step of this process. Each day new tests are being done to see what treatments Willa's body will and will not tolerate, so the days are long for everyone involved. At this time, it is expected that treatment will last at least the next six-eight  months. Miss Willa is proving to be a real champ through all the poking, prodding, sometimes-scary procedures and being cooped up — not a preschooler's idea of a good time. Looking down the road, the Pauletti family is going to need lots of love and support in many forms to face this disease head on. There are a few tangible needs that will need to be taken care of right away, and many expenses the family will incur while seeking treatment for Willa in the coming months. What we've learned so far about the path ahead is that Willa's immune system is going to be fighting hard, so as she moves from the hospital to their home for her monthly chemotherapy treatments, increased and ongoing deep cleaning of the Pauletti's home, plus a hospital grade air purifier will be important. Frequent appointment trips to Memorial Sloan Kettering Hospital for treatments brings the associated gas, parking, and tolls.  Heidi and Gregg have diligently stood watch at Willa's bedside for days now, and will continue to do so, taking respite at the Ronald McDonald House nearby in short bursts. So far, this has not incurred a cost, but  there is a maximum stay limitation which we anticipate meeting before treatment is complete for Willa. This campaign has been initiated to defray the cost of supporting the clean home environment Willa needs to heal and the ongoing unexpected costs of travel, childcare, lodging and equipment, the medical/ drug costs we are learning will not be covered, and other needs that the Pauletti family will have to get Willa the treatment  and care required. With time, more will become clear about how Willa's treatment plan will affect the family's lives with regard to missed work, etc. As we understand what else may be required, we will update this campaign to help offset the burden for the Pauletti's.Thank you for all your continued support and prayers for the Pauletti family. Anyone who has or knows children, knows how heart-wrenching this fight will be. Anyone who knows Heidi and Gregg Pauletti knows there are no stronger, more vigilant, more fiercely loving people to support Willa in her fight. Join us in standing behind them and showing your support as they bravely face this challenge head on.With Gratitude, Friends of The Pauletti FamilyTo learn more about Willa's journey:   https://www.caringbridge.org/visit/willapauletti

On July 19th Larissa and Jon landed in Madrid, Spain to perform in their first European show at CA2M (Centro de Arte Dos de Mayo Comunidad de Madrid.)  After meeting with the curator Larissa found Jon in their hotel room in distress and bleeding profusely from the mouth and nose.  He was rushed to the hospital and found to have multiple bleeding stomach ulcers which had ruptured.
