They admitted him to the ICU where Jon has now been for a week.  Since Jon has been in the ICU, he has had multiple complications from losing a significant amount of blood, seizures and blood entering his lungs.  He was able to be off the ventilator for a short time, but was put back on the breathing machine and sedated on Sunday.  We are hopeful that his condition is finally stabilizing and soon he will turn the corner.  As of now he is still intubated and sedated.  As many of our close friends and family know, Jon has been looking for work for over a year and half now as a writer and has been applying tirelessly as well as writing freelance.  Larissa & Jon were unable to perform in the show in Madrid and have been incurring medical expenses for ICU care as well as lengthening their stay in Spain for his undetermined discharge and recovery until he is fit to fly.  These unexpected medical costs at such a vulnerable time in their lives and in another country no less have been an added stress.  Larissa has met with administration in the hospital who is billing weekly to provide continued care to Jon. Larissa and Jon have been so blessed with a large community of artists, curators, fans, friends and loved ones who have always supported their work.  We are hoping for any support, love, positive vibes and financial support, if able, from this community to lift the burden from medical bills during this difficult time.  Larissa has been dealing with all of this while in Spain and thankfully has some great friends looking out for her while she’s there as well providing meals and support.  Any help given in whatever form you see fit would be valued and appreciated.  Here is to a continued and speedy recovery for Jon.With love,Velez Family&Hilary Clark

Casey Lane; an energetic, loving, community caring 34-year-old cheerleading coach from the Houston area, thought he had bit his tongue, back in October 2017, only to have the tongue become more irritated, torn and swollen by December.  A visit to an ENT in late December 2017 suggested his tongue needed to be cauterized to help it heal. Upon the procedure, just days later, the surgery revealed 3 dark spots in which the doctor biopsied. In less than 1 week, we received Casey’s diagnosis of stage 4, Squamous Cell Carcinoma. Casey, due to severe pain and inability to swallow, has lost 33 pounds in about 6 weeks. He’s been unable to work since November 2017. The local Cancer Institute proposed their method for this aggressive deadly cancer. It involved minimal chemotheropy AND TOTAL removal of Casey's tongue. Additionally he will receive heavy radical radiation, surgical addition of a permanent lifetime airway tube and a feeding tube.  The success rate of this method is 40% and life expectancy of only 3-5yrs. After frantically researching for a treatment with a more positive outcome, Casey and his family were directed to University of Chicago Medical Center. The Oncology team, after meeting Casey, projected hope. A 6 session plan of simotanious  chemotherapy and radiation for 5 days. He will receive 6 sessions of these 5 day treatments, one week on and one week off. Casey announced he is ready to fight and undergo the intense, painful treatment to try to save his tongue and his life. The Chicago Cancer team has started fighting Casey's deadly cancer 1 week after meeting in April 2018. Casey will undergo 10-12 weeks of "In & Out" treatment and quite a bit of time rehab and recovery. The family is working diligently, with help from the hospital and friends, to secure living quarters while he is relocated for treatment in Chicago. Donations will help with travel, medical treatments, therapies, and living expenses. Casey may not be able to work for 9 -12 months due to the treatments and therapies to help save his life. The family is struggling to pay Casey's medical and personal expenses which have been mounting since November 2017. With faith, hope and determination to support Casey's decision, we are reaching out to our communities for immediate support for this wonderful young man.

Dear Friends,We are raising the campaign to support Vivek's family who is battling with cancer over last year. He is currently in St Davids Hospital (Near Parmer and Mopac intersection). Based on current situation and doctors advise Vivek has decided to move back to India along with his wife and 2 year old son. Friends are helping and working with airlines / hospital staff etc and making arrangements for his travel. The plan is to make family fly to India on Friday, July 6th, 2018. He needs air ambulance / Business Class travel considering his health condition.Request all your kind support and blessings during this trying times.We will keep you posted as things unfold over next couple days.

Chuck Edwards was diagnosed with throat cancer in early May of this year. For those of you that have been so kind to follow his journey over the past 3 years, he has been through more than any one person should ever have to endure. He has battled two severe back surgeries, a heart attack, 2 existing aneurisms near the heart, and now this. Chuck began a treatment plan to include extensive oral surgery, and 7 weeks of radiation 5x per week and Chemo 1x per week mid June. By God’s grace he has been given an 80%+ cure rate though the effects of the treatment have been quite debilitating and painful to say the least. We expect the road to recovery to be long and costly, and by default, a prolonged period of yet again, being without income. So many of you have reached out and asked how to help, and for this we can not begin to express our sincere gratitude. For this reason, please know that contributing to this fund will be extremely helpful to meet medical and living expenses that have accrued from the beginning and continue to grow. More important, your help will provide peace of the mind for Chuck to focus 100% of his available energy on overcoming this horrible disease.Please direct communication to Chase (EDWARDS.CEE@GMAIL.COM) or Jami (JL.EDWARDS@HOTMAIL.COM) as we attempt to allow Cheri also to focus 100% on caring for Chuck at this time.Anyone who knows Chuck, also then knows that he is the last to ask and first to offer 100% of himself for the benefit of those around him. For this reason, one can imagine that this is not an easy ask. From our family to yours, may you never have to experience these horrible events of life and if you do, may you also be blessed with the incredible family, friends and Father Above that have overwhelmed us with love to see the light at the end of the tunnel. Please join us in prayer through this time. Sincerely,The Edwards Family

A friend of mine is going through a horrific experience.   His 18 month old daughter has been in the hospital since Sunday, and is undergoing a five hour operation to repair the damage done to her.  She will have to have more in the future.I'd like to set up a page where people can donate to help take some of the financial burden off this family.  Even if we can raise a couple thousand to help with gasoline, time off work, meals just to show love to this great man and his daughter.  Thank you.

Dear Friends,As many of you are aware, our friend Gary Rooplal's wife Nirmalla is in critical condition as she battles cancer. Gary is an immensely private person. He appreciates all our support but is not comfortable discussing the details of what is going on in his life right now. We have been working hard to find a way to help him and his family in a manner that is respectful of his privacy. Gary has been with the school for 15 years. Even as Gary and his family navigate through Mrs. Rooplal's illness, Gary continues to greet every student, staff member, parent and visitor by name with his trademark smile, humor and positivity. Gary treats each of our children as his own. He welcomes them each morning by name and escorts them to their bus or carpool with a personal goodbye as well. He is completely dedicated to our students, ensuring they are safe and feel secure and supported throughout the school day.Now it is time for us to demonstrate our support to Gary and his family in return. Please consider contributing to our campaign, any and all donations are welcome. Please note:1. Donations can be anonymous.2. Please feel free to forward this to anyone who would want to help.3. This is not school sponsored - this campaign is being spearheaded by a group of parents who have learned of Gary's situation and would like to help. Thank you.If you have any questions you can contact Marcy Aharon at MarcyAharon@aol.com

column3: Help Dan Red Card Pancreatic Cancer
column9: Thank you for visiting our GoFundMe page.   For frequent updates on Dan's progress and how we are doing, please visit our CaringBridge page !  <3It all started with what appeared to be a stomach ulcer.  A month and a half of various tests later, my husband Dan received the surprising diagnosis that the abdominal pains he had been experiencing were due to stage IV pancreatic cancer.  Since the cancer had already gone into metastasis affecting his lymphatic system, operation was not an option.  Pancreatic cancer is the fourth deadliest cancer in the United States and often is not caught until it has spread to other organs, and it is sadly without a cure.  Our only option is for him to undergo an aggressive chemo regimen called FOLFIRINOX with the hope of controlling the disease and improving Dan's quality of life.Dan is a wonderful husband, a beloved son and brother, and a cherished member of a very large Italian family.  An IT director by day, Dan spends his off-work hours mainly as a soccer referee for the amateur, professional, and collegiate leagues in and around Eastern Pennsylvania.  Dan also enjoys playing soccer recreationally as well as running road races, his favorite being the Broad Street Run 10 Miler.  His friends come from all areas of his life, through his high school years, teammates from rec league soccer, peers in the referee community,  and his work colleagues.  Dan has always been a warm, welcoming person to have in your life.Many have reached out asking for ways like this to support us as we navigate this new path in life for Dan.  We have been very fortunate through our employments and access to the health care he needs, but there are so many unknowns both emotionally and financially when it comes to cancer treatment and disease management.  We truly appreciate the outpouring of love Dan has received already.  We are setting up this page for anyone who would like to use this as means of helping out, but please know there are no expectations from us and no donation will be used frivolously.From the bottom of our hearts, we truly thank you for your support.

Jason's urgent story from 3 team members... "On March 21st, Jason Lee Jones, a singer, musician, missionary, was diagnosed with THROAT CANCER. This was an unexpected and shocking discovery.  God’s hand and favor has been evident in the process from the beginning as the diagnosis was made quickly and the medical care has been initially covered by a local medical charity for those without insurance.  The overall prognosis is good, but it’s clear that the road to recovery ahead will not be an easy one.  He is looking at SIX MONTHS of being home for treatment and recovers. TWO MONTHS of AGGRESSIVE CHEMO & RADIATION,  and then FOUR MONTHS of RECOVERY and possible surgery.  The charity has limited resources, so there will be medical bills Jason and Gina will have to cover.  Jason brings in the family’s main source of income through the ministry, which he will be unable to do for at least 6 months. There will be MEDICAL BILLS &  LIVING EXPENSES that need to be covered ASAP since Jason has been home all of March and will MISS SIX MONTHS OF WORK. Jason and Gina have sacrificed so much and passionately poured out their lives for the Lord and countless people for over 20 years.  They have deeply touched so many of our hearts.  Now is a beautiful opportunity to give back to them in their time of great need, both through our prayers and our financial support.  Their faith through this process has been incredible and they are believing for a miracle and for God to receive much glory through this.  Let’s help carry them, surround them with love and support and believe with them for this miracle!" Connie Wantling"It is with a burdened, but very hopeful, heart that I make this request of friends and family of Jason Lee Jones, my brother in law. Very recently he was diagnosed with throat cancer. For those that know him, you know that he is an extraordinary human being that has dedicated his life to God. The lives that Jason has touched and brought to God around the world is uncountable. His unending dedication and devotion to the Lord through his music and voice is his livelihood. That is why this disease, especially because of where it has afflicted him, is so crucial to hit head on and immediately with very aggressive radiation and chemotherapy. Jason is a strong man and very physically fit for his young age of 44. We know and believe that with your help he will be able to beat this disease with a full recovery to get him back on the road. Without insurance to cover the already increasing costs of unforeseen treatment, the next months are going to be difficult for him and his family. Your support during this time for Jason is going to allow him to focus on fighting and beating this disease without worrying about how he is going to be able to make ends meet for his family; his wife and two young children, since he will miss 6 MONTHS  of his traveling missionary & philanthropic work with The Godbreed & Iris Savannah . Even the smallest amount of financial support during this time will go a long way in helping the family. Please help us to give back to Jason and his family some of the love and support that they have so selflessly given of themselves through their dedication to the ministry over the past 20 + years. Even if you don’t have the means to help out financially, your love and prayers would be very well received. We appreciate every single one of you for all your love, gifts of time, prayer, love, or any creative support during this time. We thank you from the bottom of our hearts and will keep you updated on his status. God is good."Kory & Andrea Reeves, your brother-in-law & sister."One of my dearest friends. My brother (truly, don’t mess). I remember the phone call. The news. The surprise. The lament. The sorrow. But, more than all,  the hope. And the joy of Jesus over my brother's life. In the midst of my fear and confusion about it all...the thing he says continually? “The devil messed with the wrong man. I’m going to preach Jesus even harder and stronger than ever before. Even if I lose my voice, I will still shout Jesus in my inner man.” So thankful to know him and his family. In the midst of a cancer diagnosis, he has a true John the Baptist message (tattooed, big bearded, wild eyed and all)...”prepare the way of the Lord”. Find friends who call you higher. Especially in the midst of trial. Find friends who call you higher. Support and love looks like something. Nobody can be prepared for this kind of news practically. Let’s rally together. For healing in all ways. Any little bit helps. Yesterday, 9:42 PM" Amber Brooks

column3: Angela's fight to live with ALS
column9: March 2, 2018, Angela was diagnosed with ALS.  Angela is 34 years old, has a 4 month old son (Patrick), a husband (Scott) and very little hope that she will live to see her son's first day of school.When Angela was a few months pregnant, she first noticed weakness in her hands. In the past year her diagnosis went from pregnancy-related fatigue to carpel-tunnel to an auto-immune disease from which she would recover and finally to ALS, a terminal disease with a life expectancy of 3-5 years.ALS destroys the nerve cells responsible for controlling your muscles, leaving your mind intact to perfectly understand what is happening to your body and to your loved ones as they are left in grief for the unlived dreams you leave behind and their complete inability to help.  Unfortunately, her family has been through this before with her grandfather, Bill, who passed away a year after being diagnosed with ALS in 2006.  He was a great man, extremely hard working, utterly devoted to his family, and robbed of his well earned retirement enjoying traveling and family with his wife and 4 grandchildren (whom he doted on).  He is missed.Although she hopes to participate in a clinical trial and has started medication in hopes of extending her time with Patrick and Scott, there are some immediate needs for modifying her home and purchasing adaptive aids.  In the future, her care needs will include home care, travel expenses, and setting up a fund for Patrick's education.If you are unable to give, please consider adding Angela to your prayer list and sharing her story with others.Thank you so much and God Bless,Angela's Familyp.s.  Angela really lived life.  She pursued her dreams and built up a large network of friends whom she loves.  She loved to watch KU basketball, ski, and be outdoors.  Below is a picture from one of her proudest moments, having reached the summit of a "fourteener" in Colorado.

This is an appeal to help pay Dr. Nyang's ’s medical bills. As most of you know that in March 2016, Dr. Nyang had a massive stroke which left him incapacitated.  Although, he regained partial mobility, he still needed 24hr help with his daily needs.  Due to his condition, he was not been able to do a lot of things by himself.   In October 2017 as he tried to pick up an object,  he lost his balance and fell, causing him to have fractured vertebrae bones and a spinal cord injury.   Due to his injury’ he is currently totally paralyzed, and has needed many surgeries in different hospitals has been in many Rehabilitation Centers.  Dr. Sulayman Nyang, the literally giant, the man whom people could bring their problems to, the professor, who gave all he could humanly give without asking for anything in return, needs your financial assistance to help with his medical bills.Our goal is to raise two million dollars.

In February 2018 Misha Grigoriev suffered a brain aneurysm from which the doctor in the emergency room said he would die. After being transferred to another hospital where he had surgery, he is very much alive today. Misha has spent the last five months in rehab where he has made remarkable progress. His work is not done, however. On August 3 Misha is coming home as his insurance will no longer cover his rehab stay and, in addition to continued physical and occupational therapy sessions, he will need a home care attendant. Misha is clearly a fighter, defying the odds to still be here with us. Please help Misha continue the fight as we raise funds for his expenses related to continued therapy, home care services, and medical supplies.I am Trevor Dawes, Misha's husband, and am the organizer of "Team Misha".  We have been married for almost 4 years, and have been in each other's lives for over 23 years. A friend of ours, Adi, recently captured our story in a blog post here ( https://www.adiredzic.com/journal/2018/8/2/trevor-misha-a-story-of-love-fate-and-resilience.).The funds we raise here will be used for Misha's ongoing care expenses, including: - Home health care aide - Medical supplies (diapers, underpads, disposable washcloths, and the like)- Medical equipment (e.g. shower bench, bedside commode, sit-to-stand lift)- Adjustments to the home (e.g. additional railing, grab bars in the shower, stair lift)We thank you, in advance, for your support.

Last year, my brother, Brett Campbell, was diagnosed with non-Hodgkin’s Lymphoma (DLBCL). After undergoing an unsuccessful round of chemotherapy in Croatia, he came to Boston in search of second-line treatment. Within a week of being here, the doctors discovered that he was suffering from another life-threatening condition, heart-failure brought about by acute cardiomyopathy. In short, the first round of chemo didn’t kill the cancer, but it did manage to kill his heart. Soon thereafter he underwent heart surgery to implant an LVAD (mechanical heart) and spent months in the hospital.Unfortunately, because of his heart condition, he would not be able to receive any more chemotherapy, nor any of the more cutting-edge treatments (stem cell and bone marrow transplantations, CAR-T cell therapy, etc.) taking place at Dana Farber. All that was left was radiation, which he underwent in January and again in April.  Last week, he underwent a PET scan, which revealed that the radiation did not work. The tumor on his neck has not only grown back aggressively, but as well, the cancer has spread to his lungs. While we knew the news from this appointment would likely present additional challenges, no one was ready to hear that the end may be upon us.With no more ‘western’ options available, Brett is not giving up and is as determined as ever to beat this. He’s taking his fight back to Europe, where he has found several alternative health clinics in Slovenia and Switzerland, which specialize in bio-energy. Not only do these clinics bring forth their own costs (starting at approx 50K for treatment), but as well, Brett and his wife Masa have been invested full-time in his recovery. As such, we would like to help him raise some money that would go towards travel costs, treatment, pain management, and if nothing else, a little bit of comfort.

On 2/26/18, I was diagnosed with stage 4 stomach cancer.  Many of our friends and family have asked how they can help. Thank you to those that have watched the kids, provided meals, cleaned our house, and those that have provided many other favors while I am admitted in the hospital. While we have health insurance, the next 12 months of cancer treatment will not be cheap. We also appreciate gift cards to local restaurants to help with meals when we are busy with everything else. Additionally, we will be traveling to Mayo Clinic in Minnesota for a second opinion. The funds raised here will help cover the costs of medical, travel, and meals for my wife and kids to lessen the burden on them. I have never been a person to ask anyone for help financially. I don't know what this will cost, but I think this is a good place to start. There are other ways that you can help, but I understand that financial contributions may be the easiest way for most. It's time that I be vulnerable with you, put my pride aside, and ask for your help for my family and I.  Please visit my caringbridge website for more details:  https://www.caringbridge.org/visit/austinhillsfightInstagram: ahill96God Bless You All,The Hill Family

I don't know what to say right now. My friend Cara and her 19 year old son,  Nick and family need your positive thoughts, your good ju-ju, your endless prayers. Nick was shot twice in the face and head and is currently in the ICU fighting  the fight of his life. It’s going to be a long expensive road to recovery.  They own Bluebird Farm in MA, where they do not turn any animal away. They sacrifice everything to rescue and rehabilitate domestic animals, farm animals, and wildlife.  https://www.facebook.com/BFASR/ It's time for us to rescue them and give back to a family that truly deserves giving back to. I can't begin to digest what they are going through. Anything you can donate to help, will help the family and also Bluebird Farm, as they process the days to come. My heart is broken and has lost faith in humanity and mankind. Please help us all restore that by coming together. If you can donate, anything, please do. If all you can do is keep this family in your prayers, send love, and positive encouragement, than please do. Here is the link to the news article: https://www.news10.com/news/local-news/teen-arrested-in-shooting-in-massachusetts-october-mountain-state-forest/1384784683

As most of you know, our dear friend PJ Brown has been battling cancer for over two years. He and his family have accumulated many expenses, and at this particular point in his care, they could use our help. Specialized patient care, transportation to Martha's Vineyard, temporary housing for PJ and his family, are the major expenses, but there are many minor costs, too.We all love PJ and want to help him in any way possible, so if you can contribute, please do. Here is your chance to make his remaining time peaceful, comfortable and surrounded by family and friends in a place he loves!Your generosity will be greatly appreciated.

Hello friends,Our sweet Sara needs your continued prayers and if possible, your financial help.She has been bravely fighting cancer for months and has praised God through it all.  She's been a true warrior in her faith!A recent CT scan showed tumor growth instead of the expected shrinkage.  Doctors said there's nothing more they could do, not even surgery.  Sara's body just can not tolerate any more chemo.  The doctor said it was now time for hospice.In a matter of hours from receiving the CT results, they were made aware of an alternative treatment which has given them hope!  This treatment has been successful in treating horrible cancers! With no more options ahead of them, she is going to fight the best she can with this treatment.  This alternative treatment opportunity feels like it was handed to her by God. Treatment will cost around $20,000 and none of it will be covered by insurance.  Any amount of donation will help!Thank you for considering helping the Wierman family with the expenses of this possible life-saving treatment!

We hate having to do this...but we really need help. Our son, Brenden Matthew, was born on April 1st and is still in the NICU due to many medical conditions (see **Brenden’s Story**). Jessica has returned to work for the last month to preserve medical insurance for our family. This has been extremely mentally/physically taxing on her to juggle work/going to the NICU/going home to Juliana. Mike has been unable to work so he could help balance being at the NICU and taking care of important appointments for Brenden while Jessica is at work.   Each day, specialists are seeing Brenden, evaluating him and making decisions...the nature of Mike's work would make it impossible for him to be there and work simultaneously. Now, we have found out that our insurance will not cover everything that Brenden will need to go home. While some  equipment is covered, he will need back up equipment (and back up for the back ups)....and 24/7 skilled nursing at home, among other expected expenses. We also will need to move from our apartment and get a different car to best accommodate Brenden’s needs. It’s going to take awhile to get him home. He has at least another 3-4 more weeks in the NICU (if all goes well). Then, he will be going to a rehab facility where they can train us on how to best take care of him. He had a tracheostomy on 6/12/18 and is going to have a gtube/feeding tube surgery on 6/19/18. He will require a ventilator at home. We need to become experts in how to care for all of that. During this time, neither of us can work, as we need to be present and with Brenden each day to learn...the faster we are trained, the faster he can come home. We don't know how long this part will take. A summer without Mike's income, after all of these months of him being unable to work while living off of one income and so many unexpected expenses, will definitely put us into a crisis financially.Then, once he can come home, depending on when that is, Jessica may need to take some days off from work to get Brenden settled.  She has exhausted her "CAR" days (personal/sick in bank) and already borrowed 18 days that she needs to repay to the DOE.  She has 4 weeks left of FMLA that she could take, if needed (which would be unpaid).  


At this point, the level of care Brenden will need after he gets home and as he grows older is unknown.So many people have reached out and asked how they can help...so here is our request. If you can’t donate, we would appreciate it if you could keep Brenden in your continued thoughts and prayers. He’s a fighter and amazing...and has already done more than anyone expected...so please keep those prayers coming!

We have been asked  by so many on how you can help.  For those of you who may not know, here are the details on our current situation.On April 20th this year I was diagnosed with Stage 4 Colon Cancer.  As a family, like many others, we started to work through this process and are sincerely grateful for all the prayers and support that we received from our family and friends.   During this time, Donna started to develop some bumps on her skin.  We prayed that this might be some type of stress related issue as a result of my condition, but on July 19th this year Donna was diagnosed with Acute Myeloid Leukemia.  As any parent, your focus is on taking care of your kids and couldn't imagine what they are going through with both parents being diagnosed with cancer within three months of each other..So far my treatments are going well with minimal side effects, but as I have been told, that the treatment I am working through is based on a accumulation to combat my disease.  Donna has just finished her 1st induction chemotherapy.  Her disease is much more aggressive and has to be combated much more aggressively to get her cured.  Donna will be needing a bone marrow transplant in the future.  During this time she will be treated in the Moffitt center in Tampa, FL.I will let you know that I have been reluctant to start this website, especially with all of the love, prayers, and support that so many have shown to us during this time.  I really do not know what unexpected costs we will have in front us but we will be extremely grateful for any support that you are able to provide.  We know that God has had us both prior to being diagnosed, He has us now as we walk through this path, and he will have us once this journey is completed.  God is good.

Shelby is such an amazing wife, mother and friend. She is the person who keeps our family functioning and our house filled with love each day. She is our Superwoman. Unfortunately, we found her kryptonite. My beautiful wife and your friend Shelby (Wood) Wasicki was recently diagnosed with Stage 3b (triple positive IDC) breast cancer in Feb 2018. After a lumpectomy and lymph node removal surgery in March, her pathology indicated her cancer had spread. She is currently enduring 20 rounds of chemo, which will be followed by further surgery, radiation and then 10 years of hormone therapy. (Shelby is encouraging ALL her female friends to get mammograms. Her cancer was found during her 10th annual mammogram/sonogram. Her mother, a BC survivor, was diagnosed at 41 and her aunt was diagnosed at 35. Luckily, Shelby found out that she does not carry the gene). The really good news is that Shelby’s prognosis is for a full recovery.

Unfortunately, her recent rounds of chemo have made it too difficult for her to work. She recently had no choice but to leave her job. We don’t see her being able to work again until next year.

After almost 10 years together, you can imagine that Shelby’s cancer diagnosis has been such a blow to our family. We are all fighting and amazingly, Shelby is in good spirits most of the time! But with this sudden change of events we cannot survive on just one income. It’s quite hard for me to admit, but we have to ask for help. These times have shown me that I cannot do this alone. We are so blessed to have some great people surrounding us with love, prayers and support; however we can’t make it through without further assistance.


Any donations will go toward the following:

·     Mortgage and monthly bills

·     Medical bills

·     Emery’s daycare tuition

·     Childcare and healthcare during Shelby 2nd surgical recovery

·     Grocery delivery


I’m hoping we can all come together some way and make a big difference. Every penny counts and we appreciate each one!

Thank you all so much. More updates coming soon!


With love, Tim (and Shelby and Emery!)

Joey's  Wedding Day        Joey and Aly of Long Beach, New York, were married on November 25 2017. One week later Joey was diagnoised with stage 4 locally invasive colorectal cancer. He stopped working and began the arduous process of surgeon appointments, oncology consultations, lab work and chemotherapy.  Never one to complain or ask for help, he was determined to conquer this uphill battle alone. The grueling treatments are taking a punishing toll on him physically, emotionally, financially and breaking the spirit of his happy go lucky, gentle soul. There are times in our lives when we all need help, but are too proud to ask. Let's be the village that gathers together to help Joey and Aly face this hardship and conquer cancer. We can make the difference that helps Joey heal. One Week Later        Adorable newlyweds waiting for the results from the CT, MRI and biopsyFirst Day of Chemo     True to his nature, smiling through the storm

Neha’s parents have already suffered the unimaginable loss of one daughter who was born with a terminal degenerative mitochondrial disease.Now their second daughter, Neha, is gravely ill with the same devastating and terminal disease.  Time is limited and we need your help. Your generosity will help ensure that Neha and her parents, along with her healthy brother, have as much quality time together as possible.  Your contributions will also help purchase critical medical equipment that Neha needs to live as dignified and as comfortable a life as possible, as the illness continues to take hold of her. Neha is a sweet, smart, and funny 13-year old girl whose body is deteriorating while her mind remains perfectly intact. Her increasingly limited mobility poses a challenge to her loving parents’ ability to serve as caretakers and the demands of her disease have introduced extreme financial stress into their lives. Neha is in immediate need of critical and costly medical equipment, the claims for which insurance has unfathomably denied.  Specifically, Neha’s care requires specialized equipment for showering and personal care (a specialized toilet seat and a “stander” device will help Neha stand in the shower).Beyond medical equipment, Neha requires care beyond what her parents can provide. Her condition requires non-stop medical attention to ensure she’s breathing, so her parents alternate between working daytime and night-time hours so that one parent can be constantly by her side. Neha’s father works days as a pharmacist and stays up all night to assist her; Neha’s mother works the night-shift at the US Postal Service, comes home and sleeps for just a few hours, then tends to her daughter throughout the day.  Your support will allow Neha’s parents to purchase medical equipment and bring on part-time professional help that will enable them to focus on enjoying the only gift that matters – precious and limited time with their beloved daughter.  How you can help:1. Please give generously to help Neha get the medical devices she requires and the quality time with her family she deserves to enhance the dignity of her life.2. Please forward this GoFundMe campaign to at least 5 people.MORE ABOUT NEHA (from her Physical Therapist):Neha is a 13 year-old girl who has a degenerative mitochondrial disease where she is deficient in POLG, a part of her genome. When I started working as Neha’s physical therapist four years ago, we would walk down the block together.  I stood close by to make sure she wouldn’t fall, but together we walked. Today Neha is confined to a chair, unable to sit up alone, and her voice barely rises above a whisper as she does not have the strength to project loudly. Neha’s family is one of strength and kindness. No matter how hard the day, her mom meets me with a smile and thanks me for coming to see her daughter. Her mother does not complain that she barely sleeps, that she’s already lost one daughter, and is watching another slip away.  Instead she worries  that she has used all her sick time to take care of Neha and now any additional days off go unpaid. Everyone in the home understands that Neha is declining, and her mom just feels saddened over lost time with her daughter.In an incomprehensible ruling, her parents’ insurance rejected both a stander and a shower/toileting chair for Neha. Her parents worked with a hospital to file all paperwork correctly and yet insurance responded they are not responsible for her toileting or standing needs. Neha now cries when her family puts her in the bath. Her mother goes into the shower with her and holds her head as they quickly try and wash her. It also takes 2 people to toilet her as there is no way to support her body and head without a specialized chair. Neha is fed through a tube that goes straight into her stomach. Almost every other week, she will now go 2-3 days without speaking, constantly grimacing due to extreme gas pains. A stander would help with her digestion. I have previously asked Neha’s parents if they would allow me to help raise funds. Proud and self-sustaining immigrants, her parents always said no, that they would manage. When they received the notice of rejection for the chair and stander, they agreed for the first time to allow a fundraiser, as time is of the essence.  Neha’s future is uncertain but together, we can help give her family the comfort she so deserves right now. Thank you so much for your help and support.

On Monday, June 25th a father, our friend, and Consumer Electronics Industry colleague Gregory Keys suffered a stroke.  Greg was admitted into Stony Brook Hospital in Long Island, New York and was immediately rushed into surgery to remove a blood clot from his Carotid Artery which was unsuccessful. The part of the brain that supports his speech was affected by the stroke and he remained in Neuro-Intensive Care Unit for 6 days until he was able to receive enough oxygen on his own to support the rest of his brain function. He was moved to the stroke unit of the hospital where he is currently being monitored. Doctors told the family that he is extremely lucky and he continues to amaze the doctors with his drive to get better. Eventually, he will be moved to St. Charles Rehabilitation Hospital where he will be admitted for an indefinite amount of time.Many of you have called and asked how you can help. This is how. Our goal of this GoFundMe campaign is to do what we can financially to allow Greg to be able to focus on rehabilitation and not to worry about the mounting medical bills or how he will support himself or his family moving forward. Greg has a long road to recovery. As many of you know his livelihood is the CE business which requires him to travel for work on a weekly basis. However, this is not an option right now. He has overcome so many previous obstacles, such as open-heart surgery, but this will be another lengthy road to recovery in terms of weeks in the rehabilitation center and extended home care. Greg’s determination to overcome this continues to amaze everyone around him. He is still positive and thankful for his life and his spirits are up that he will win this fight. If you can contribute to help Greg, please do so. Your donation will allow Greg to focus on his difficult recovery. If you cannot contribute financially, please continue to send positive thoughts, prayers, and good vibes to him and his family. Please share this campaign with your friends, family, and colleagues.If you would like to send a card or personal correspondence to Greg please feel free to send it to the following; Greg Keys, 9 Sunset Lane, Patchogue, NY 11772.  Thank you for considering donating to Greg’s recovery and as Greg always says, “Rock Your Day!”

Hi all! My name is Kathlyn Carney and I am so blessed to be able to call Trish Churchill my best friend for the last 9 years. Trish and I met freshman year of high school at Archmere Academy and quickly became inseparable. Even though we both ended up at different colleges and in different cities, we have remained extremely close. Trish is currently studying at the prestigious Thomas Jefferson University’s College of Pharmacy where she is completing her Doctor of Pharmacy degree. She is one of the hardest working people that I have ever met, so it was no surprise to me when she was accepted to the Jefferson College of Pharmacy. I know I speak for so many people when I say that Trish is one of the most dedicated, resilient, selfless and kind people I have ever met. Trish always puts her friends and family first and she has taught so many of us what it means to truly care about someone. In the midst of finishing her last didactic year at Thomas Jefferson University and enjoying her favorite city, Philadelphia, Trish received unexpected news. At the end of February, Trish was diagnosed with the rare autoimmune disease Myasthenia Gravis and more recently stage 4A Thymoma. A thymoma is a tumor that is found in about 10% of patients with Myasthenia Gravis. Trish’s tumor is currently too large to surgically remove, so she is estimated to undergo 4-6 cycles of chemotherapy to shrink the tumor; in hopes that it can be surgically removed following treatment. When Trish told me the news, I was devastated and couldn’t believe this was happening to her. However, I have never met a stronger person than my best friend and I know if anyone can get through this, it’s her. Her attitude since she found out about her recent health conditions has been incredibly admirable. She is determined to complete her final semester of academics on time and begin her final year of rotations as planned in May. Every time I talk to Trish, she is positive and encourages all of her friends and family to have the same optimistic attitude. Despite her situation, Trish has never once asked for sympathy and has continued to be the same resilient and compassionate woman that we all know and love.  By creating this page, we’d like for the Churchill family to solely focus on Trish’s healing process. It is our goal for her to receive the best possible treatment without insurance limiting the medication options available to her. Please join us in supporting Trish’s journey to a cure. All donations will be used for any medical out-of-pocket expenses that the Churchill’s will endure. Thank you so much for your time and donation - it is greatly appreciated.

Please Help Support Scott’s Family While He Fights for His Life!Scott Williamson, Husband, and Father of three, recently had a severe asthma attack that led to cardiac arrest. While medical personnel were able to revive him he remains in a sedative state, unable to breathe on his own and fighting for his life. Scott, former owner of “The Shack” in Clinton Illinois, and his wonderful wife (Shannon) have 3 Beautiful Children; Skyler (16), and Savannah (9), and Saige (6). All three are active athletes and performers. Anyone that knows Scott and his family knows they like to have fun, and would give the skin off their backs to help and support their friends and community. Now, they need your help.Scott is the primary bread winner in the household. While Shannon stays dutifully by his side while he fights for his life, the financial obligations continue to compound. Friends and Family have started this go-fund me page to help off-set some of those expenses so the family can focus on being there for Scott. We ask that you donate any amount that you can. The monies received will go directly towards paying for:for:• Medical bills• Food• Shelter• Utilities (Gas, Electricity, Water, etc…)• GasolineWe appreciate all the wonderful thoughts, prayers and support we have received thus far. Any assistance you can provide will be much appreciated.Thank you,The Williamson Family￼

Chad Wingo’s wife Megan has been diagnosed with a malignant brain tumor and is undergoing surgery to have it removed, which will be followed by ongoing treatment. Megan has been struggling with constant headaches over the last month so they went to Urgent Care where they recommended she schedule an MRI. She met with Neurologist the following week who put her on a 7-day steroid and scheduled an MRI for 6/25. The steroid finally relieved the pressure and pain for the first time she first started feeling it a week so prior.  At this point, the Neurologist was not expecting to see anything abnormal on the MRI, but just scheduling for due diligence. After the 7-day steroid pack, the headaches returned. The Neurologist then prescribed a migraine medication. That only partially worked. Last week they called the Neurologist office every day seeking a consistent pain relief management strategy. The Neurologist said there was nothing more she could prescribe until after the MRI and advised if they need relief to go to the ER so they returned to the ER last Thursday night. Megan received an IV with a steroid where for the second time she finally had relief from the pain. She was discharged that night, but once the steroid subsided, the pain returned. They scheduled an MRI for yesterday at 6:30 AM dressed in their work attire, not expecting to find abnormal results. But the results unfortunately showed a sizable malignant tumor in her right brain, bigger than a golf ball, pressing on her brain stem and pushing into her left brain. This was the reason for the constant pressure and headaches. She was immediately admitted back to ER and surgery scheduled for Thursday to remove the tumor. The Neuro Surgeon explained that the cancer is not curable with surgery, its just the first step.  After surgery, she will start treatment.Please consider donating to help show your support and love for these two IG family members. We will be arranging for meals and other supportive activities to help them through this difficult time and to help Megan win this fight. Help spread the word!

Hello everyone! 

My name is Ai Sonomura. I have been a good friend of both Megumi and Hiroyasu Nunokawa since high school in Chiba Japan.  Former residents of Utah, work opportunities took them to Indiana about three years ago.  They have five children ranging in age from 18, with plans to head off to college in the fall, to 5.  Over the years I have seen how much they have extended themselves to others, opening up their home, resources and hearts, helping freely and unconditionally.    

They have recently learned of a serious medical condition afflicting Megumi that will significantly impact their family's lifestyle and livelihood for the foreseeable future.  Hiro provides for the family, but they are not wealthy by any means, as Megumi has juggled raising the kids and finding ways to bring in additional income. 

I am copying a portion of her own explanation of the situation from a Facebook post, so please read below to understand the more in-depth details. However, I truly believe it is time they become the recipients of some good will in this uncertain and challenging time for them.  Many who are aware of their recent circumstances have asked how they could best assist, including being willing to send money, which is how we collectively decided this would be the most effective and convenient way to help them at this time.

 

Hi, Families and Friends!Some people might be curious about my situation so I will share a brief of it !I am hospitalized now because they found tumors in my heart and between the heart and lungs. The one in my heart is about 5 cm and the other is 3 cm and tangled in some tubes that connect the heart and lungs, making it hard to breathe, but I'm surviving for now.I am so blessed to have great doctors to take care of this severe issue and they are trying to figure out the best treatments for me. There were some options, like open heart surgery or chemo therapy . Since this is a really rare case, the doctors are discussing from every angle every day.  And for now, chemo looks like the best option to try. (UPDATE: Doctors have been determined that surgery is not possible. They are pending various test results to determine when and how to proceed with the chemotherapy).It might seem like a huge trial, but I have already received so many blessings through this experience! 1️⃣ I am feeling that I have THE BEST family and friends and they love me soooooooo much!(Hiro stays with me all the time. Mia takes care of the other kids and so many families and friends are supporting us) 2️⃣ I am in the right place to receive great treatment!Please include my name in your prayers.  That would be extremely powerful help for me!I love you all  ❤️I will try to update when possible as long as I am able to hold my phone ! 

皆様

園村愛と申します

この度、布川恵美の緊急入院に伴いまして、この寄付金サイトを設立させていただきます。

私は布川夫妻とは、高校時代からの親友で、布川家がユタ州に住んでいた頃も、家族ともども仲良くさせて頂いておりました。3年前に布川家族は転職のために、インディアナ州に引っ越しました。布川夫婦には、今年の秋から大学生になる18歳の娘から6歳の息子まで、3男2女のかわいい5人の子供がいます。

布川夫婦は、5人の子供を育てる中で、どんなに忙しくても、困っている方がいるとすぐに助けに行くような、奉仕の人たちです。

今回の緊急入院によって、彼らの現在の生活と将来に、大きなダメージを受けています。

下記には、恵美ちゃん本人がFacebookで記載した内容を転写しておきます。この状況を理解していただき、是非ご協力ください。

ｰｰｰｰｰｰｰｰｰｰｰｰｰｰｰｰｰｰｰｰｰｰｰｰｰｰｰｰｰｰｰｰｰｰｰｰｰｰｰｰｰｰｰｰｰｰｰ

個人的にお知らせが難しいので、こちらから少しだけ現状報告を！

ただ今入院中でして、その理由は心臓の中に5センチ大、肺と心臓の外側に3センチ大の腫瘍が見つかり、多分リンパ腫ではないかと。外側にある腫瘍が心臓と肺をつなぐパイプに絡みつき圧迫しているせいで、呼吸が苦しいですがちゃんと生きています。恵まれた事に素晴らしいドクター達のチームが私のために毎日検査と話合いを色んな角度からしてくれて、最も良い治療法を模索してくれています。 あまりにレアなケースなだけに、開胸手術か抗がん剤治療かで意見が二転三転しましたが、今のところは抗がん剤治療の可能性が高いようです。一見、厳しい試練のように見えますが、それでもすでに沢山の溢れる祝福を受けています。

1️⃣ 私には最高の家族と友達がいて、ものすごく愛されていること。（ひろくんは常に私と居てくれて身の回りのことをしてくれます。美愛は自宅で子供達を家事をしてくれています。沢山の素晴らしい友達が毎日色んなサポートをしてくれています）2️⃣凄腕のドクターたちのチームが見てくれている事（一人のドクターから、もし僕があなたの状況ならこのチームで診てもらいたいと言われました）

私には信じる宗教があり、信仰に寄って生きる者なので、どうぞ、どんな形でも言葉でもいいで、私のためにお祈りしてくださいね。お祈りの偉大な力を知ってます。皆さん一人一人が大好きです❤️携帯を持てる限り、また報告します！

Let me tell you about our best friend. She is selfless, full of joy, an amazing co-worker, a leader, always down for an adventure, a wonderful daughter, sister, niece, aunt and cousin. She is hilarious and keeps us laughing at all times. Unfortunately in April, Mary was diagnosed with an aggressive form of breast cancer. She started chemotherapy immediately at the end of May. Although she is in great spirits and refuses to let cancer define her, it has paused her ability to work full time. She needs our help for to cover medical and living expenses while she undergoes treatment. Any amount is appreciated and will help her stay afloat during this journey. We don't want Mary facing financial uncertainty. We want her to focus on her health, wellness and, most importantly, her future, which she envisions as cancer free. Thank you so much from the bottom of our hearts.

On Sunday, April 29th, Jordan and Lillian, her 1-year-old daughter, were in a tragic car accident. They were t-boned on the driver’s side, causing significant damage to the vehicle. Emergency responders had to cut both Jordan and Lillian from the vehicle using special equipment. They were flown out to separate hospitals as a trauma. Lillian was flown to Children’s Hospital and although is bruised and sore, has been medically cleared! Her guardian angel certainly was looking over her.Jordan was flown to Washington Hospital Center, endured multiple traumatic injuries, and is currently in critical condition. The first few hours consisted of repairing an aorta tear and stabilizing her blood pressure and heart rate. Over 1,200 images have been obtained, demonstrating the thorough evaluation by the specialists at Washington Hospital Center as they evaluate her body millimeter by millimeter.  Jordan has stretched ligaments in her neck and an injured blood vessel, which with time, will heal on its own. She has a hole in her diaphragm, which is scheduled to be repaired on Wednesday, May 2nd. She has a tube in her left lung and is having a tube placed in her right lung on Wednesday, May 2nd. She has broken ribs and has multiple fractures in her pelvis in both the front and back. She is scheduled to have pelvic surgery on Thursday, May 3rd. She has a bruised kidney and they are beginning to feel a pulse in her leg. Doctors remain optimistic and are so proud of her improvement and stability.Jordan has endured the most traumatic injuries, and although intubated, her vibrant personality has never left. She is awake, and can write but does not remember the accident. Jordan has a long road of recovery ahead of her. There has been an out-pour of positive thoughts and lots of prayers. Your thoughts, prayers and generous contributions allow Dustin, her husband to be with Jordan and Lillian as Jordan embarks on a long recovery. Please join us in lifting any financial concerns and burdens, and allow their focus to be on Jordan and her recovery.

This gofundme account is being set up on behalf of Keri and Randy Aschenbrenner, who lost their sweet 2-year-old baby girl yesterday at 2:20 in the afternoon, April 14th. Earlier in the week Chloe was suddenly taken ill and transported to the hospital where medical staff fought tirelessly to save her life. Despite all medical intervention and countless prayers, her fight sadly came to an end. Medical costs unfortunately add up quickly. Any assistance you may be able to offer in the next couple weeks will make a difference. Continued thoughts and prayers for Keri, Randy and family are needed!

On April 2nd, 2018 our dad, Brad Snapp, was diagnosed with an aggressive form of acute Leukemia. We were told that without immediate treatment he would live only a couple months. April 11th he was admitted to the hospital for anywhere between 30-40 days, until complete remission occurs. At that time he will be allowed home for only a short time, before he will undergo a bone marrow transplant, followed by another 3 months in a secluded living space near the hospital.It goes without saying that this news has thrown our worlds into a complete tailspin. It has been devastating, scary, confusing, and it's all happened so incredibly fast. No one has had much time to really think about the financial crisis this is going to be for Brad and Cindy. Truth is, not very many people could live for 5-6 months on less than 1/2 their income plus a medical bill that is inestimatable. My whole life my parents have stretched slightly beyond their means, relying on faith and frugality, to continually provide me and my brothers opportunities that allowed us to become the people we are today. We are forever indebted to them, and because of this; and like many of you, we want to do whatever we can do within our control to be there for them when life gets really, really  hard. That time has very unexpectedly come, and we want to ask something very big of all of you. Some have known my parents since they were born, some met them when you were all young kids, some are relatives both near and far, co-workers, acquaintances, some of you are my friends, or Luke and Josh's friends. So many people have shown such support, and asked how they can help, we are truly blessed by the company we keep. We cannot say thank you enough for the sincerity we have felt.Can we come together financially to support two of the most humbled-hearted, compassionate, generous, loving, and most genuine people we have ever come to know? What we can say we know for sure is that cancer is awful, and it really can strike anyone at anytime. It is REALLY unfair, and it has the power to destroy a person and their family in more ways than one. You never think it will happen to you, but then one day you wake up and it's all you think about. We are all forever even more compassionate and ready to help others in our situation than ever before. We did a little math, and if we can find 200 people who would be willing to donate $100 dollars each, we can help my parents pay the medical side of this beast. They would be blown away, and it would offer them reprieve from the daily stress and allow them to focus on my dad beating leukemia. Whatever your finances may allow you to afford, we come full of gratitude to say thank you from the bottom of our hearts.

The Chiappetti family of Orland Park, IL needs help with the cost of substantial medical bills for David Chiappetti, age 19.David Chiappetti was seriously injured on February 22, 2018 in a snowmobile accident in Wisconsin. David’s snowmobile hit a bump on the trail and he was thrown from his machine.  He has suffered head trauma and has multiple internal injuries.   David was airlifted to Central Wisconsin Trauma Center where he still remains in a coma.   David’s family has been at his side and his doctors’ have said David has a long recovery ahead.Any donation is much appreciated for this family.

In the words of Sevi's momma........."Family and friends, Friday evening we admitted Sevi into OU children’s emergency room. Sevi has myocardiopathy. It’s a result from his virus traveling to the heart and causing dilated infection. He is currently in ICU on life support. The team let us know that there is nothing we could have done or the pediatrician could have done differently to expect this since it is not a common concern. With a 50/50 success rate, we must wait and see over the next week if Sevi will fight and his heart will heal. If not, a heart transplant will be the last option.We share such grief so that you will pray. Pray hard and loud. We appreciate the overflow of love and support up to now. Thank you and love you all. ❤️"Our hope is to raise funds in order that Ellie and Devin can focus their time and attention on Sevi and restoring his health and not on the financial toll this could have on their family. This family has endured more than most with the recent loss of Ellie's mom (after a long battle with cancer) and her grandmother. Their faith in God has never waivered and they will continue to place their fate in God and the exceptional care they are receiving from the dedicated doctors and nurses at Children's Hospital. Sevi's road to recovery is certain to be a long one. If you're able to help, thank you so much. Please feel free to share. From all of us, thanks for continuing to love and support this precious family. All the funds raised will go directly to Ellie and Devin Morales to cover the medical costs and expenses incurred by the terrible situation.

THERE IS A CRACK IN EVERYTHING. THAT'S HOW THE LIGHT GETS IN. - Leonard CohenIf I could go back in time and shake the Cecily who cried every time her heart got broken by some frat boy, or comedian or writer of bad movies (sorry ex boyfriends) - I would. I'd say, "You think your heart is broken now? Cut to 15 years in the future, when a cardiologist will tell you - No….it's really, really broken." Last month, I was told I had a heart aneurism, which is the cause seemingly of one of my heart valves to have completely malfunctioned. Scarier, the root of my aorta is apparently crumbling and the tissue that basically holds my heart in place in my body is breaking apart. Eventually, it can burst and ya know, that's kinda it.This month, aside from having to re-build the aortic root, they have to fix the valve by most likely replacing it with another one. I'm just going to be honest…I am terrified. What has confounded this is that one of the "helpers" at the hospital (after my MRI) found out I live alone and kept saying, "This is so hard, because you are so so so so alone. How WILL you DO this ALONE?" I of course know I'm not alone. (My beloved Beagle mix just can't drive or help me with finances.) But a few nights ago, when I was writing my will and thinking "who would even WANT my 1993 Mazda", I felt a sense of existentialism never quite described in high school philosophy class. It feels so scary and that’s just the truth. The "why" of it can't be answered. I haven't eaten red meat in 10 years, I have never once smoked a cigarette, I'm not a heavy drinker. The only thing that's ever gone up my nose was probably a marble, but that was in the 70s! Aside from these fears, I'm equally terrified of the expenses about to land in my lap. I have health insurance, of course. But even insurance can't keep up with the demands of today's healthcare costs. Open heart surgery is obscene. I do know there will be a lot that's not covered by insurance. There already is. And because I'll spend time in the ICU  and re-habbing after. I won't be able to work one of the many extra jobs I do to make ends meet…for months.  So I'm trying to make myself feel better by putting it like this: I've never had a wedding or a baby. So think of all that could have been spent flying out to see me get married. Or the wedding gifts. Or the baby gifts. Since Bloomingdales won't let me register for "Aortic Root Replacement" or Bed, Bath and Beyond does not have a "pig valve" or "aftercare" section, think of this as a registry.In truth, I'm putting this out into the universe in hopes of easing some of the horror of this. Physically and emotionally, I feel underwater. I have no idea what my financial "goal" should be, but if I could just write "life raft" up there, I would. Even the tiniest bit of help will help and so from my crumbling heart to yours, I thank you for reading, giving or sharing.

Hello everybody,My name is Ayse, 21 years old. I came to the U.S. to study Computer Science in 2014. I went to language school, and now I am a junior Software Engineering student. I was caught by rhabdomyosarcoma type of cancer at the end of 2016. Since then, I am trying to hang on to life. At first, I got a 30 cm chunk of tumor in my abdomen, and I am through too many destructive but healing chemo-therapy sessions. The beginning was really hard. Thank God, I passed those times.Even though I got cancer, praying and studying were two of the most important things that made me happy.I had a surgery on Jan. 2018. Surgeons got rid of all tumor cells they could see. Now, I feel like this survival journey will end. Right now, I am taking maintenance chemo-therapies to make sure this nightmare illness will not be occurring back. Since I am sick I cannot work or go back my home.  I am out of all my funds. I have to continue to be treated.Please, help me pass the finish line.This is when I need to go into crowd.This is after my surgery.This is when I am under chemo tho' happy.

Our infant nephew, Jonathan Cerniglia, was recently diagnosed with spinal muscular atrophy. This disease is the number one genetic cause of death in infants. It will rob him of physical strength by affecting the motor nerve cells in the spinal cord taking away his ability to walk, eat or breathe. In his one month of life he has suffered more than any baby should and so have his parents, Joe and Natalia. He is currently under pediatric intensive care and his parents are going to have to endure exorbitant care, treatment and travel costs. They are meeting with specialists and are looking into experimental treatments that will hopefully buy him enough time for a cure to be found for this devastating disease. We are heartbroken and just want this sweet boy to have the fighting chance he deserves. Please help if you can. Thank you!

My niece's husband, Aaron, has been recently diagnosed with stage 4 colon cancer that has spread to his liver and lungs. Aaron and Joy have two beautiful kids that do not understand what is happening. All they know is daddy is very sick. These funds will help with Aaron's  medical bills to obtain the treatment he needs to beat this cancer and at the same time provide for his family. Please, please find it in your heart to donate so that he can fight this horrible disease. Thank you in advance for your donation!

https://www.caringbridge.org/visit/sandyrogers/journalOur mom, Sandy is in the midst of a great fight against Acute Myeloid Luekemia. She has battled this disease since Christmas of 2017 with the utmost of courage and bravery during the multiple chemo treatments, hospital stays and doctors visits. She is truly undeserving of this disease, yet continues to be a light to her family, friends, doctors and nurses - always putting others’ needs before her own. We are at the point now where chemo treatments are just keeping the cancer at bay and it is necessary for her to undergo a bone marrow transplant. This is a very extensive and expensive treatment, requiring her to be in the hospital for one month and obtain housing nearby Moffit for the next few months until she is cleared by her doctors to go home. She will be required to take expensive medications and continue with ongoing tests and medications throughout her recovery. All money donated will go towards medical and doctor bills, living expenses for her family, and travel expenses needed for her care and support.Most important your prayers are needed! Our God is able to do above what we ask. He is her Rock and pray she will continue to receive the comfort she needs from Him. Thank you!

We only know that he is in the Survival Intensive Care Unit at Illinois Masonic Medical Center. Let's all come together and show our friend Robby and his wife Jennifer that we are thinking about them and wishing him a speedy recovery!Please help spread the word!

Let's Come Together for Kerri!What’s Happening…On behalf of my amazing sister in-law Kerri Rowland, my gracious brother Bob and their two sons, Nick (15) & Ryan (11) I am opening this GoFundMe page.  Last July, after 3 years of fighting the good fight, my Dad passed away from colorectal cancer. It was so hard for everyone in our family and so many of our friends. As the holidays approached and we were still grieving the loss of my Dad, we got news no one could have dreamed we would hear.  Kerri was diagnosed with Stage 4 colorectal cancer after a check up to address some digestive issues she was having. We were all devistated, but Kerri and Bob rose quickly.  They had a plan and quickly acted upon it as 2018 started.Kerri started chemotherapy almost immediately and has endured months of treatment, while consistently being strong and positive for herself and family. Watching her over the past few months has been a solid confirmation to me that she is beyond a doubt one of the toughest people God has placed on this earth. Her determination is phenomenal. Everything she does, her family drives her determination. My brother and their boys have also been determined – to keep Kerri and each other moving forward!After a recent scan, we learned that the cancer has grown and the chemotherapy was only marginally effective. Chemotherapy has been stopped and the option of radiation is now being explored. Kerri was refered to MD Anderson Cancer Center in Houston where they specialize in late stage colorectal cancer. This is the BEST place in the country for her to receive treatment and she was fortunate to get an appointment.  Without a doubt – she needs to go, NOW!The CostsRight now, and the reason I am opening this page, is they need your help. This open-ended trip, as well as what lies beyond, all have an unknown price tag. It stinks that money has to be considered right now – because peace of mind is something everyone deserves. Bob and Kerri have health insurance, but it will not cover everything (co-pays, deductibles, travel, lodging and more).  The new lifestyle changes that their family has endured will be expensive.  How you can helpPlease consider hitting the “Donate Now” button on the upper right side of this page, adding a monetary gift, and giving my sister in-law some financial peace of mind.  Every dollar we raise will go directly to Kerri’s fight. It will help her and Bob cover medical expenses, additional treatments they may opt into, and make it possible for my brother Bob to be with Kerri during her treatments.I hope you're able and willing to support my family through this difficult and devastating experience.  With your help, Kerri, Bob and their boys can focus all of their energy on healing and remission.  It would be great to surpass our goal!Thank you!Thank you so much for reading my story!  Thank you for opening your heart to my family. Thank you for whatever contribution you have made or can make going forward. Your love, support, friendship, and your prayers have been overwhelming and greatly appreciated.

On April 10th, my best friend and housemate was diagnosed with cancer. In February, Janelle fell outside our home on her way to class and began having pain in her lower back. After a month or so she went to the hospital to see what was wrong, as it couldn’t possibly be from falling a month prior. Doctors thought it was a bruised bone, maybe a slipped disk, or possibly a kidney infection... Come April, after spending 10 days at Mass General Hospital, undergoing multiple scans and tests, Janelle had a biopsy done revealing the pain was from cancer. She was diagnosed with Ewing’s Sarcoma, an extremely rare bone cancer most often found in children and adolescents. When I found out it was cancer, I said to myself, “Of all people to get cancer… I am absolutely stunned it’s Janelle.” If there is a poster child for healthy living and positive energy, it would be her. Before her diagnosis, Janelle was either at the yoga studio, tearin’ up the mountains in the winter, whipping up a delicious healthy (usually vegan) meal in our kitchen, or hanging with friends at the Ski and Board house. She also spent the last two years working with the UMass Amherst based nonprofit, Protect Our Breasts, an organization that focuses on sharing the conversation about chemicals in products that contribute to cancer, and empowering women to make safer choices to protect their health. Janelle is currently the co-president of the UMass Ski and Board Club, and will be beginning her senior year online this fall.  Janelle is still on track to graduate from UMass Amherst in May 2019. As Janelle continues this long journey, she needs your help! She is currently receiving treatment and going through rounds of chemotherapy at Mass General Hospital in Boston. Her treatment is extremely rigorous, tiring, and will be ongoing for the unforeseeable future. Once she is done with chemo, she will most likely need additional treatments such as a bone marrow transplants and clinical trials. Janelle and her family greatly appreciate your support in her fight against cancer. We thank you for your positive thoughts and any contribution to her fund.  To follow Janelle’s journey, check out her blog at  https://climbingontrees.com #TeamJanelle #BeatSarcoma #StrongerThanSarcoma

As you may know, Alexa Castillo was diagnosed with cancer in March, 2018. What you may not know is the severity. Alexa, who is 15, has stage IV Osteosarcoma in her right shoulder and it has metastasized to both of her lungs. She had been experiencing increasing pain, and sudden swelling led us to take her to the emergency room for evaluation, and she was admitted for additional testing. We received the diagnosis within days. She had her first inpatient Chemotherapy on March 19th. She will continue Chemotherapy for 10 weeks. Then the results will be evaluated and she will have surgery. Lack of money stops people from having the home or car of their dreams, traveling, or pursuing their dreams or interests. In this case, it could cost the life of our dear Alexa. Please help. Our dream is a healthy Alexa. With Chemotherapy alone, her odds of survival are approximately 30%. We desperately want to pursue an alternative treatment that works in conjunction with the Chemo and improves her chances. The cost of this additional treatment from the Orange Coast Medical Center of Hope could be at least $50,000. With your kind donations of any amount, we can get treatment to increase the chance of conquering her illness and living as normal life as possible. Thank you in advance for your prayers and any help you can provide. Sincerely, The Castillo Family John, father Cynthia, mother Diana, stepmother Tiana and Sara, sisters, Mark Froelich Cynthia's partner.

Hi everyone. My name is Laura Boyle and I am 27 years old from Smithfield, Rhode Island. Last year I was diagnosed with Von Hippel Lindau Disease. VHL is an extremely rare genetic condition where blood vessel tumors can form in up to ten areas of the body. These tumors can be benign or cancerous. So far, VHL has affected my adrenal glands, my pancreas, and now my brain.My first tumor was discovered when I was in college, just 19 years old. Last year they found a malignant tumor on the head of my pancreas that was resting on my small intestine. Just one short, hectic week after finding this out, my life was uprooted and I was in the OR at Rhode Island Hospital, having pancreatic surgery known as the whipple procedure. A whipple procedure entails removing part of the pancreas, stomach and small intestine, as well as the gallbladder and liver duct. The entire digestive system then needs to be rerouted. After the surgery, they determined the tumor to be pancreatic cancer called a pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor. This led them to discover that I have a cancerous genetic disease called VHL.After more testing, they also found that I currently have three brain tumors, known as hemangioblastomas that they continue to monitor. These tumors rest on the back of my brain and spine and continue to cause symptoms like nausea and migraines. Throughout recovery, maintaining a healthy weight has been most difficult. I am severely underweight and malnourished and my tumors and digestive issues make it extremely difficult to maintain a normal 27 year old lifestyle. In recent weeks, I have had to take a leave of absence from my teaching career because of my debilitating symptoms. I have the most amazing seventh grade students this year and it breaks my heart that I am no longer well enough to teach them and spend their last few weeks of this school year with them. Right now, I ask you to please help me in any way you can. I am currently struggling to manage my symptoms enough to get back to my students, my life, my wonderful fiancé and my caring family. I am finding it more and more difficult to maintain my job, my health bills, my doctor's appointments, and pay off my student loans. If you can help in any small way, it will mean more than you know! Thank you for reading my story.  I will be using any money I earn on my medical bills and maintaining my student loans while out on leave. This is an inspirational poem I found that was written by a fellow VHL warrior. I couldn't explain my situation any better than she does!“To look at me you’d never knowBut the tumors in me just grow and growNo matter what I do or sayThey just won’t go awayAt first the feelings just flowedThe time stood still, it got very coldFrom a care free teen with my whole life aheadTo a dying teen lying in a bedThat night I lay awake till dawnAnd before I knew I had a new plan drawnI realized something in the dark of nightThat I was going to win this fightThe tumors the doc had foundThe news that put my parents on the groundThey said that I was going to dieBut I wasn’t prepared to say goodbyeSo I got myself ready for warAnd promised my loved ones I’d walk out that hospital doorAnd sure enough the road was roughBut I was never willing to give upI know my war is not over yetBut one thing I’ll never forgetTo smile in troubles remember I’m blessedGod gave me this imperfectionCause he knew I could handle the stressAnd in a funny way I’m glad for that dayfor the scars and the tearsI’ve gathered through the yearsFor all these things is what makes meMy von Hippel-Lindau, My Life, and Me.”

A little over a week ago, the lives of our brother Chris & sister-in-law Tiffany flipped upside down.  Their second born son, Calvin, went into the ER for what was thought to be an allergic reaction.  Tumors were found and he was transported more than three hours away to the Children's Hospital in Omaha for a biopsy.  There, they heard the words parents never want to hear...words, parents should never have  to hear: "your son has cancer."  Over the course of the next three days, they were given a diagnosis, prognosis and suggested treatment. Our nephew Calvin who's nine has been diagnosed with stage 4 / group 4 / high risk rhabdomyosarcoma, with the alveolar genetic marker. This is an aggressive form of cancer and has a 20 percent cure rate if the treatments are successful.  Because of the location of the tumors (which are pressing up against major blood vessels), surgery is not permitted at this time.  Calvin will need to undergo chemo in hopes of shrinking the tumors so that surgical removal can take place. They are still waiting on the results of the bone marrow biopsy which took place at the same time his chemo port was put in. A U.S. Army veteran, our brother Chris is the sole financial provider for his wife and four kids and has not left Calvin's side since that trip to the ER.  Chris is on family leave which unfortunately means he does not get paid.  This means there is no income to cover expenses.  Expenses that sadly won't stop adding up during this difficult and life-altering situation: gas, food, utility bills, car payments, mortgage, everyday living expenses.  These are on top of any medical bills that may occur.  This past week is just the beginning to a long battle ahead...physically, emotionally and financially.  Please help Chris and Tiffany by donating.  Any amount is helpful!  Along with your donation, prayers for Calvin are appreciated.  Updates will be provided as we learn more. We would be humbly grateful if you share our link to your social media timelines to help spread the word. Signed, Calvin's uncles & aunt: James, Shawn & Ryan

Hey everybody!Unfortunately Mikey started feeling ill on 4/7/18. He started running a fever and while being treated for that at Asante Rogue Regional Medical Center, Mike had a series of unfortunate medical emergencies that have led to him currently being intubated, on a ventilator and in an induced coma. He has a long road to getting back to making us smile and laugh again. Please understand that Mike, Erin and the entire Longmire family appreciate your support and would never ask for a help. So I am going to do it for them. If you can, please donate to this. Mike is a one of a kind husband, son, friend and firefighter that has impacted us all in a different way. All money raised will be given to Erin and Mike for support. GO FUND ME taxes what is donated but if you are fire related or just want to make the extra effort please contact L314 and write a check to Erin Longmire to avoid that tax.  If so inclined you can mail or deliver the check to 265 Commercial St. SESuite 250Salem, OR 97301We will be doing updates on here and on Facebook page Mustaches for Mike.If you have any questions feel free to contact me (Jeremy) at 503-984-3608 call or text. Please give ALL of the Longmire family privacy so they can focus on Mike.

Stephanie, Our Warrior Queen, has entered the ring for the fight of her life and she is going to need the support of her army and beyond to get through this, as she was recently diagnosed with Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML. FLT3). On Thursday, May 17, 2018 Steph was sent to Stanford Medical Center after results from a local blood test came back with dangerous levels of white blood cells. The tests were a result of Stephanie seeking medical attention after experiencing a recent series of issues that she had believed to be related to her Multiple Sclerosis. Severe headaches, debilitating in nature, a terrible ulcer on her tongue that made it impossible for her to eat and she even blacked out at one point. It was then that she realized this was beyond the challenges that she already dealt with and considered part of her “normal” with MS. Upon her arrival at Stanford they immediately began chemotherapy treatment and told her that she had cancer.
