It took a couple of days and a very painful bone marrow biopsy to reveal exactly what form of leukemia she would be battling. Given the seriousness of Stephanie’s already highly compromised immunity, the treatment plan for her is very individualized and she is being taken care of with extra care and attention.Tad has not left Stephanie’s side since she was admitted almost two weeks ago, and he plans on supporting her continually in the time ahead. Stephanie is currently undergoing induction chemotherapy with the hopes of putting the cancer into remission before undergoing a bone marrow transplant. If, or should I say when her marrow test comes back clean of the cancer cells, she will undergo stem cell therapy and that will then have them staying in Palo Alto an additional 100 days for 24 hour care and treatment. Much is uncertain at this point, but we do know that the Rothbauer family could use the help of each and every one of us to get through this scary, unpredictable, and very expensive journey.This Go Fund Me account is being set up to go directly to the family to pay for the many costs associated with Stephanie’s current and future treatments.ABOUT STEPHANIE:To know Steph is to love her. Her vibrancy and genuine love of life is present in everything she does. Even during these difficult times. What would cripple many has only displayed her strengths even more. This passion is displayed in everything she is a part of. She has been a supporter of the national and local MS Foundation, she’s a well-recognized interior designer (which class studies she completed in the initial stages of battling her MS), she’s an amazing participant in the county Big Brothers and Big Sisters project where she was recently honored as Big Sister of 2018. Steph received this honor because like everything she commits to she has been committed to her little sister and it is a commitment that she plans to see through the young lady’s time in school and beyond. Steph’s family is her biggest passion and her focus is and always has been to ensure that TJ (age 14), Brayden (age 12), and Mia (age 8) are happy, loved and know their place in her heart. The battle ahead is not going to be easy and the only option is that she comes out the champion, but Steph and her family are going to need all of our support facing this future of uncertainty. For a woman that lives by a plan and a calendar you can imagine the strain and fear that she is feeling and yet she does so with smiles, jokes and making the rest of us still better for being a part of her life. Let’s help where we can and take whatever burden away so that her and her family’s focus can be on her recovery and time together that is and always will be a priceless amenity.WHAT THE MONEY WILL BE USED FOR:Although Stephanie and Tad have medical insurance through his employer, there are many, many costs that are not covered through insurance. Your generous donations will go towards helping pay for a variety of costs associated with Stephanie’s treatment including:- Co-pays for medications and treatmentsMany of the treatments that Stephanie is and will be receiving are VERY expensive and insurance does not always cover everything. - Gas, hotel rooms and restaurant foodStephanie is currently being treated at Stanford Medical Center in Palo Alto, CA, a 4 hour drive north from her family’s home in Paso Robles. Her future treatments and potential bone marrow transplant will also be at least a few hours from her home. Your contributions will go directly towards covering the many ancillary costs associated with a family of five living away from home for an extended period of time.WHAT YOU CAN DO TO HELP:In addition to donating, you can help us spread the word! Post a link to this campaign on your Facebook timeline, twitter or Instagram#stephstrong

This is Michael Heaton’s GoFundMe Page. Michael has been diagnosed with a Medullary Cancer that has now spread to his lungs. Sadly surgery and chemotherapy are not options. Radiation therapy is on the table and expenses are expected to start to pile up as soon as that treatment begins. They are hoping to begin treatment in about 2 weeks. Mike has a CaringBridge Page that can be found at  www.caringbridge.org/visit/michaelheaton. Please visit this page often to see journal entries, updates and other ways that you can help. Mike has an incredible number of friends and family that love him. If you can contribute to this GoFundMe page, he will be incredibly grateful. If you are unable to contribute money, please visit the CaringBridge page above for other ideas or simply send your love. Words of encouragement and friendship are incredibly valuable commodities.

On April 4, 2018, while at work, co-workers recognized Tim was acting in a manner not normal to a young man with personality that was active, vibrant and most of the time amusing. At that very moment this 31-year-old man's life would change forever; he was suffering a stroke. He displayed all the classic signs, dropping face, tingling on one side of his body, slurred speech and total confusion. He was taken to the emergency room where the diagnosis confirmed that Tim did suffer from a "mini" stroke. He stayed overnight in the hospital and after further observation he was released the next day with instructions to return for further evaluation. Shortly after his release, while walking his dogs with his girlfriend, Tasmyn, Tim once again was suffering from another stroke, this time his condition was much more severe.Test after test, Neurologist were baffled and could not pinpoint a definitive diagnosis. After much research the experts saw traits in Tim's condition and tentatively concluded that he may have a disease called Moyamoya. This disease is a rare, progressive cerebrovascular disorder caused by blocked arteries at the base of the brain. This was a first for Neurologist at the Kaiser Permanente of San Diego, so they were perplexed in how to treat it. During that time, Tim had worsened even more. To the point where he could no longer speak, had lost his ability to move his right arm and became very lethargic. Initially, doctors began a regiment of blended medications in hopes it would stabilize him. Unfortunately, the medication was not working so the ultimate and last resort was for the Neurologist to perform an angioplasty to the area of Tim's brain that was not getting enough blood flow.With the grace of God and the many prayers offered up for Tim, the procedure was successful. The doctors were able to open up the vessel and to get blood flowing back into the affected area of Tim's brain. After spending one week in the Direct Observation Unit and another week in the ICU, Tim was transferred to a Rehabilitation Center where he will have to relearn how to speak, walk and do many of the basic functions of everyday life that he was doing prior to his stroke.Tim's journey is long, but he is resilient and determined to get back to some type of normality. As you can imagine the cost of his stay in the hospital, the surgery, the treatment plan, the medications and all the other expenses you can think of will be another challenge for him to overcome.To our friends, family and anyone reading this message, your donation to assist Tim in tackling this debt will be greatly appreciated. We are humbled and words or actions could never repay your kindness and generosity.  However, if you are not able to make a monetary donation, please keep Tim in your thoughts and prayers. We are thankful for your prayers as well. We truly believe that the power of prayer is the ultimate gift you can give to anyone in need. We pray that no family should go through this life changing experience that Tim and our family and friends are going through now. Many blessings to all and may God keep you in his tender care always.

As you have all heard by now, my sweet little girl was involved in a horrific life-threatening car accident this past Sunday.  We’d like to thank everyone for your incredible support with your prayers, calls, texts, thoughts, shares, etc. Farrah is still in a coma, so she’s unconsciousness and breathing only with the help of a ventilator. It is probably going to be a few weeks before her brain trauma has healed enough to allow her to open her eyes. All of your prayers have gotten us to this point!!!!She is a very active person. She’s very loving and caring and someone who always likes to help people when she has the opportunity to do so. She has so many hopes and dreams for her bright future, which now have no certainty... Please help our Family raise the money to cover these costs. We need help with her medical expenses, so she can get the proper medical care and treatment in order for her to wake up and enjoy the life she was meant for. We’ve created a GO FUND ME account so please help us spread the word. She needs all the love and support she can get.

On Wednesday, April 18th, Dustin King & LaChelle Leigh Blow King were married in Hawaii. 2 days later, on Friday, April 20th Lachelle had a hypoglycemia attack. Dustin rushed her to the ER, her blood sugar had dropped to 29. They immediately began treatment and testing. They found that her liver was not functioning properly and they transferred her to the liver center at Queens Medical Center in Honolulu where she is currently in ICU. She is on the waiting list for a liver transplant. Dustin and Lachelle are so grateful for the outpouring of love and the prayers they are receiving. The Doctors have told them that weather Lachelle receives the transplant or recovers on her own it will be a long recovery and she could be in he hospital for months. Please continue to pray for Lachelle, Dustin and that God will be glorified in all this.

Our dear friend Kika (Christine Garcia-Concheso) was diagnosed with Pancreatic Cancer, Stage III, on June 18th. At this point, the only treatment available is chemotherapy. If she responds well and if cancer has not spread, she might be able to have surgery after several rounds of chemo, but the doctor suspects there are a few cancer spots on the liver too. We all know Kika, she is in severe pain, but always in a great mood and is enduring all the tests exceptionally well. Housing SituationKika's house was severely damaged during the hurricane last year. There was significant flooding, and she lost almost all the renovations she had done to the house a few months before, including a brand new kitchen and flooring. She has been fighting with the insurance and just now got the approval to fix the house (although she did not get all the money she was asking for). She will start renovations soon and will try to sell the house as soon as it is done. Currently, her home has no kitchen, no living room, no washer/dryer and only one functioning bathroom. That was "fine" until she was diagnosed with cancer. Now she cannot stay there anymore, nor she can deal with the remodeling herself (to save money she was going to supervise it). We plan to rent her a small apartment, preferably near her son and his family immediately, since she will start chemo on July 13th. In the meanwhile and whenever she wants, she will stay at my house. She knows she is always welcome here (we set up a bedroom for her) and I will do everything I can to be with her at every medical appointment and treatment, but I know she would like to have her own place and be close to her grandson. By the way, Kika's son and his family live in a two-bedroom condo, so there is no space to accommodate Kika and her beloved dogs comfortably.Work and IncomeWork-wise; the situation is even tougher. Kika always worked as an independent contractor but has no new projects (nor she can take new projects right now.) So, she will have no income at all, but a very small retirement check.Health Insurance and Medical ExpensesHer health insurance is Medicare, and she will have several out of pocket expenses. We also would like to get a second opinion from MD Anderson or John Hopkins in Maryland and to join medical trials around the U.S. that offer hope. This gofundme campaign is to help us get through the next few months until her house is sold. She plans to use the house money to pay for her future expenses. Unfortunately, we cannot wait until she sells the house and, with no new project/work, she cannot afford to rent an apartment or pay for her mortgage, treatment, and medication. I know Kika has some great friends out there and that you all will help her through this. Any amount is highly appreciated. I plan to post a few updates here, but if you would like to contact Kika and/or myself directly, please email TeamWinKika@gmail.com. We both have access to that email so that I can send updates in her behalf. Thank you all so very much.

column3: Join the fight for Tammy Schriver
column9: If you know Mrs. Tammy, you know that she is a Godly woman full of faith. She is precious and dear to so many as a wife, mother, daughter, sister, grandmother, mother-in-law, aunt, sister-in-law, friend and so much more.In February 2018, Mrs. Tammy was diagnosed with pancreatic cancer. She had surgery on March 15th to remove part of her pancreas. At that point, the cancer had not metastasized and we were believing for a surgical cure. After Mrs. Tammy recovered from surgery, she began chemotherapy.  On August 8th, she had a CT scan done to see if the chemo was working. Unfortunately, the chemo is not working and there are now multiple tumors in her abdomen.Through much research and many phone calls to oncologists, medical centers and the top hospitals all over the country, Mrs. Tammy has found New Hope Medical Center. Their central office is in Arizona, and their treatment hospital is in Mexico. They offer a 12 day cancer treatment. This treatment is her next best option for a cure. Through much prayer and faith, Mr. Tim and Mrs. Tammy have concluded that this is her best option and the door that God is opening. Fortunately, they allow one person to go with her and stay with her for the duration of the treatment. Because of the aggression of the cancer, we are hopeful Mrs. Tammy gets approved to go next week (August 20th).  Our goal is to raise $35,000  to completely cover the cost of the 12 day treatment and travel to get there.  If you feel so led to give, we thank you so much! Please also join us in prayer for healing, peace, wisdom and for God's will to be done. Join us in the fight on the journey to Mrs. Tammy's recovery!A note from Tim and Tammy: "Thank you for joining us in this fight. We are so humbled by all of your love, prayers and any financial support you can offer. God bless you!"The Lord will fight for you; you need only to be still. Exodus 14:14"For I know the plans I have for you," declares the Lord, "plans to prosper you and not to harm you, plans to give you a hope and a future." Jeremiah 29:11

KIMBALL NEEDS OUR HELP NOW!  She has just gotten results back from her MRI and not only has tumors in her brain, they are on her spinal cord and her lungs are failing as well.  We need to give as much as we are able to help her pay her monthly bills ($1100/mos) as she she explores treatment options.  It is unsure what Obamacare will cover, but it will not be cheap and not being able to work means WE NEED TO GIVE BACK TO SOMEONE WHO HAS GIVEN SO MUCH TO US.It's not all about positive thoughts and sending her healing, it is about practical help so she can focus on getting well.  You would want to have your friends come to your aid if you were in the same situation, so please GIVE NOW AS MUCH AS YOU ARE ABLE...

Elikapeka Garcia is a vibrant, loving and carefree 17 year old young lady who has been dealing with stomach pain for a little over a year now.  With multiple tests, ultrasounds and blood tests all returning normal it was determined to be constipation and intense menstrual cramps.   This past February when blood started to be present in her stool we scheduled a colonoscopy.  But due to there only being one specialist on island, it could not be scheduled until April 19, 2018.The Doctor could not perform the colonoscopy because her intestines were inflamed so she recommended that we go to Kapi'olani Hospital for Women and Children on O'ahu for further tests.  We flew out that afternoon and she was admitted.  Her CT scan the next day revealed a softball size tumor in her abdomen which is applying immense pressure on her intestines.  They needed to run more tests to determine what kind of tumor it was.  On April 26, 2018 they conducted another biopsy and on May 2nd she was diagnosed with Stage 3 Ovarian Cancer.  Chemotherapy and surgery was determined to be the plan to battle this.  She was about to graduate High School from Lahainaluna and was determined to walk the line with her classmates.  Her Doctor advised since it was low grade they would wait on treatment and allowed her to finish school.  She graduated on May 27, 2018 and we celebrated this amazing achievement with her party on May 28. Her first chemotherapy treatment was on June 6, 2018 at Kapiolani Hospital.  It went well with little side affects.  She went back to Maui that same day and went about her daily happy go lucky life by going to the beach or hanging out with friends and family.  Her next scheduled treatment was on June 27.  On June 19, 2018 while at work her Mom Darice received a call that afternoon that Peka was in extreme pain from her stomach.  She called 911 and they were able to administer pain medicine immediately to give her some relief.  Maui Memorial Medical center did a CT scan and it revealed that her intestines were heavily backed up and she could not move her bowels due to the tumor blockage.  They tried a regimen of Miralax to get things moving but it just made her pain worse.  During this whole process she was undergoing fertility treatments so her eggs could be harvested and saved for her future, but that proved unsuccessful.  The plan was to try fertility again after the second or third round of chemotherapy.  But while she was in so much pain she made the heart breaking decision to not save her eggs and to perform the needed surgery and remove her ovaries now.  Her Doctor agreed and she was medevaced to Kapiolani Hospital on June 20.  Her Surgery was conducted on June 21, 2018 as she was surrounded by family and friends.  After a few hours her Doctor advised us that her cancer had spread and he was no longer able to remove the tumor and cancer from her abdomen without putting her life in danger, so he stopped.  She is at Kapiolani Hospital now recovering from surgery and has had some challenges, so recovery is longer than expected.  Plan B is to now give her a series of shots and pills to stop the estrogen production in her body which is feeding the cancer.  This will stop it from spreading while also shrinking it.  Once that is accomplished, she will go into surgery again to remove everything. At this point, insurance has not approved to cover the required shots for her treatment.  Her family plans to proceed with or without their approval to ensure she receives the needed treatment to get her back to normal.Darice has been by her side while Daddy Louis has been home taking care of her two sisters, 'Ihilani and Kolokea.  Peka has a huge support base from her family, friends and church family.  Her faith in God is strong and we believe that God has his hands on her and she will be his walking testimony to share his miracle healing upon her.  While prayers are what she needs the most, medical bills are starting to come in and as much as her family hates asking for help, there have been so many people reaching out wanting to help financially so they have decided to start this page to aslo keep everyone updated on her progress.  We Love you all and thank every one of you for your love and prayers.Peka and the Garcia OhanaPeka can do all things thru Christ who strenghthens her.  Phillipians 4:13

Shaedyn is just 23 months old, but in her short life she has brought so much joy, love and laughter to everyone that knows her.  She has always been very active, loves to dance and even as a newborn she always wanted to be around people.  She has even enjoyed learning how to hop and how to tumble.    She began having a series of ailments in March and doctor visits without any resolution to the symptoms she was experiencing.  During this time the energetic little girl we all know and love became very lethargic.  She was having difficulty sleeping and was increasingly irritable,  began wanting to sleep most of the day away and only wanted her mom, Elizabeth, to hold her.It became so concerning that, on Sunday, March 18th her father Chris and Elizabeth decided to bring her in to be seen by a doctor yet again.  This Austin Regional Clinic doctor recommended that some blood tests be done.  The results of those tests showed that she had profound anemia.  The hematologist said that she had Pancytopenia and recommended admitting her to Dell Children's Medical Center of Central Texas.More blood tests were run that Monday, a spinal tap was done and her bone marrow was tested.  The results came back and Monday evening Shaedyn was diagnosed with B-Cell Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (ALL).After receiving enough transfusions to get her blood counts to an acceptable level a procedure was performed to install a portacath  and Shaedyn received her first of a 2.5+ years long regimen of chemotherapy. The Warzecha family are some of the most warm, welcoming people you'll ever meet.  Right now they "are hard pressed on every side, but not crushed; perplexed, but not in despair."  All of us that love them and are within physical reach of them are doing all we can to try and meet whatever needs we can with our own individual, limited time and resources.  The reality is that not any one of us can do it alone and we want the Warzechas, we want Shaedyn to know that she is not in this fight for her life alone. If you are reading this story we believe you found your way to this fundraiser for a reason.  We are asking anyone who sees this to thoughtfully, prayerfully, consider donating to the cause of helping this little girl and her family pay for the long road ahead; the medical procedures and the bills that will result from them. Thank you for all of your support. Please continue to pray for our girl!

Mavrik will be 13 years old on April 25th, 2018 and he has been fighting a heart condition since the day he was born, HLHS. Hypoplastic left heart syndrome (HLHS) is a birth defect that affects normal blood flow through the heart. As the baby develops during pregnancy, the left side of the heart does not form correctly.Throughout his life, Mavrik has had 9 open heart surgeries, 2 stokes, has survived with only 1 lung and still continues to fight but over these past few weeks his health has seriously deteriorated. He has been bed ridden and stuck in the hostpital to ride out his last few days or weeks on this earth. We are pleading for your help to raise money so we can get Mav back home to live out his last few weeks in the place he loves most and with his family around him. The insurance company will only provide coverage for 16 hours of around the clock care but Mavrik NEEDS 24 hour care. The insurance company would rather spend millions of dollars to keep him in the hospital rather than provide him with the care necessary for him to be able to come home and live comfortably surrounded by his family and enjoy his last few weeks, which would cost considerably less. Please find it in your heart to donate anything you can to grant him his last wish. Thanks so much for all the support and love you all have given thus far. #themavmovement

A final chance to liveHello there. My name is John Bacile and I’m a Christian father of 4, and a stage 4 cancer patient with only a few months left to live (Again.)I know that some of you reading this may have also heard these words from your doctor, and if you haven’t, I can tell you, it is sobering. Your entire world comes to a stop. By the time I discovered I had bladder cancer 2 and a half years ago, it wasalmost too late. I had a very aggressive, invasive cancer that had already eaten into the muscle wall of my bladder.My options were so stark, so quickly, that I could barely breathe. I was told that unless I had a Cystectomy (surgery to remove the bladder and other nearby organs that are affected) and take Chemotherapy and Radiation for 3-6 months, I would probably only live 12 months and suffer a painful death as the cancer was obviously progressing in an unfavorable area. Even if I elected to allow the surgery, the cancer may have already grown past the point of being eradicated.I really wasn't given other choices and the Oncologists wanted to begin their operations, chemo and radiation within 2 weeks. But I consider myself fortunate that my first instinct was to pray. Seemingly out of nowhere, I remembered a book I had read the year before that discussed holistic therapies for cancer patients and it recommended ingesting overwhelming clean and raw nutrition in large doses in order to rebuild your immune system's natural weapons against disease.So I politely refused the doctor’s advice since having come to believe that destroying my immune system with chemicals and poison would greatly affect my odds of living a quality life in the few months I had left with my family. Instead, I decided to go on an all-natural, holistic, organic diet - juicing, raw organic foods, steamed vegetables, lean meats and various supplements, vitamins and enzymes, etc.That was February 2016 and we acted immediately with no hesitation. However, because the cancer was so aggresive by June it had begun to cut off urination and so I elected to have a secondary surgery called a TURP where they go in and cut out as much of the tumor as possible. The pain and the constriction were immediately relieved, but not for long. By August, I needed another operation, and by December, a third.By the time of that operation 11 months had passed and the tumor had now merged so much with my bladder that it was increasingly difficult to tell them apart in key areas like the ureters where urine drains from the kidneys to the bladder. I remember that disappointing day when I was informed that the doctors could perform no more operations; the cancer would only grow from here.The day after the December 2016 operation, my kidneys began to fail. The next morning, I needed an emergency Nephrostomy (where tubes are inserted into your kidneys through your back to drain them.)I remember being very discouraged that day as I lay in my hospital bed. Tubes in the front of me, and bags and tubes on my sides and back; the pain of back to back operations and the dreadful thoughts in my head of how quickly I was deteriorating were overwhelming. One day in the beginning when I had initially prayed to the Lord, I heard His voice tell me, “This disease is not unto death.” It was quiet; it was deep, and I daily held on to it as I fought to beat back the cancer. “But what now?” I thought. “After all this how could I possibly be saved?” Because also in June of that year, a new breakthrough in Immunotherapy for bladder cancer had been rushed to the market by the FDA, the first such advance in over 30 years. I remember thinking about how fortunate I would be if only I could take the IV therapy. However, the FDA had approved the wonder drug only for dying patients who had exhausted all other standard options - surgery, chemo, and radiation.But remember I had turned all that down.How unfortunate, I thought, that something that could possibly save me was so close and yet so far. While I was pondering our limited options, the Oncologist informed us that because I was given the emergency Nephrostomy, I was no longer a potential Chemo patient. And as of that day, I had technically exhausted all possible cures. I was now terminal, and eligible for the immunotherapy.And just like that, I was the second person in Dallas Texas to begin taking the advanced bladder cancer drug, “TECENTRIQ.” And then like magic after only 3 months, the scans showed that I had responded wonderfully to it. All the cancer outside of my bladder had disappeared and the main tumor had shrunk over 25%. What great excitement and hope we had. It happened so quickly and was such a miracle at the very last minute. But cancer is very clever and unfortunately, after only 8 months, the drug stopped working and the next scans showed that the cancer was back and worse it was growing in many other places as well. Month after month we continued with a similar bladder Immunotherapy and always taking the nutrition program as there was nothing else to do. As the months have passed, the cancer had continued to spread to my kidney and my lymph system in my throat and groin, and the main tumor has become very large. 2 weeks ago we took new scans since an additional 8 months have passed since the last, and based on them, the oncologists have again given me only months to live. Thank you for reading this far because you won't believe what happened next. Naturally our hopes and hearts were shattered and our finances had become utterly depleted. I know this is how it is for so many people with cancer, and my heart aches for those less fortunate than myself. My story up until now is the same story so many people share. It's just a devastating disease in so many ways.I am once again faced with this fact - If I do not have a miracle very, very soon, I am going to die. This was not as frightening to me as it once was though, because we have already had so many miracles during our journey that we have simply come to expect them. It seems that whatever we needed, whenever we needed it, was always there. (But this time, I must admit, I didn’t know what else there could possibly be) Are you going through a cancer trial or any other great difficulty in your life? I want to encourage you to never give up and always, always trust the Lord. He is good and merciful. With all this despair and difficulty surrounding us, our trust in the Lord was all we had left. That was when, only two days ago, two of my customers who had heard about my cancer walked into my business and sat down. They said that they are involved on the margins in one of the world’s most exciting cutting edge scientific Immunotherapy drugs, developed at Baylor Medical College in Houston Texas. They wanted to know if I’d go to a clinic in India to take treatment.And again, seemingly out of nowhere, just hours after I had been on the verge of accepting my imminent demise, my fatalism has turned into hope. For me, this is not a trial. The drug has been proven to work and is not just for bladder cancer; it has already completed a remarkable trial and it works for all solid tumor cancers.There I was, as you can imagine, stunned, speechless, and light as a feather as another timely miracle was laid at my feet.  But in order to take advantage of it I will need a lot of financial help. That's where you come in and I need your help as fast as possible - timing is essential - I must leave soon and begin the treatment that could well save me from this aggressive cancer.Having to act so quickly, we cannot take the time to first raise the funds, so we are leaving June 3rd on faith and well-placed hope because this treatment has been proven to work favorably on 40% of the first group who had been given treatment. And now the door has been opened for us to go. The cost of the medicine and travel expenses is in the neighborhood of $85,000/95,000 - and the initial part needs to be raised fairly quickly.Fighting this disease for 3 years now, has left us with virtually no money in order to take advantage of the treatment being offered to us. From a brief email this week sent to a few of our family and friends - an initial amount of cash was raised to begin the process and secure a deposit in order to be accepted into treatment.However, none of the estimated $85,000 plus is covered by insurance so we are needing to turn to the mercy and grace of anyone wishing to help. Even if you cannot help us financially, please sign up for our blog and follow our experiences as you or someone you may know could easily need this therapy in the future – hopefully as it gets less and less expensive.This is what we can share with you as of now:-            We are asking that you donate any cash amount you can via Go Fund Me. We are also asking that you donate any excess Frequent Flier points as we can use these points by giving miles in exchange for cash. -            From our initial email above, we additionally received donations from several people of over 600,000 Frequent Flyer miles. With a portion of these, we were able to purchase 3 roundtrip airfares as my two sons Kelly 19 and David 28 will be going with me. (David will only stay for 3 weeks)Here is our Itinerary:-          June 3rd through June 6th we fly from Dallas to NY to London to New Delhi India. (There were direct flights but I'm so easily fatigued we needed to factor in a couple of rest nights)-           My first injection will be June 20th. -           Second injection will be July 3rd, and the third and final injection will be July 17th.-           By the 2nd injection, I should begin to see reduction in tumor sizes. By the 3rd injection, my cancers will be a fraction of their original sizes. By August 1st, I should be in full remission. What a glorious day that will be!-          HOW DOES THE TREATMENT WORK-          The treatment is a dendritic cell immunotherapy.-           The technique is absolute cutting edge state of the art.-          It was developed at Baylor College of Medicine Houston Texas-          Cancer tissue is taken from the main tumor, and then the DNA of the patient’s white blood cells are altered to attack that specific cancer.-          It works on all solid cancers.-          Tests to date show the treatment to be extraordinarily effective.  The treatment has no side effects and results begin immediately.-          The treatment has not yet been approved in the U.S. but has been approved in India, that's why I am going there to receive the treatment.-          However, the very first United States trial will be at Baylor College of Medicine starting late next month on pancreatic cancer.  The treatment I will be receiving in India is a very similar treatment being given to the pancreatic patients here in the first American trial.I'm so excited!-          Because after looking at my 3-year medical history, my immune system, and estimated time left to live - the scientists believe that I have an excellent probability of having no discernable tumors by the end of August.-            I thank you all in advance for helping me and my family. Without help from people like you there would be no hope for us. You are our only hope.God bless you all so very much,And thank you. John Bacile and family.Dallas Texas

Our beloved Masoud Hosseini, dedicated husband, loving father, and generous friend has been diagnosed with Stage IV Melanoma Cancer.  It started as what was thought to be a simple strained muscle, unfortunately, tests came back with a different story. Many people have asked how they can help the family. Masoud and his family will be facing medical bills very soon, as his treatment has begun. It would help to ease their burden if we could assist them in this way.We are asking for contributions towards our goal of $100,000 to support his medical treatment without delay.   Please share his story with others because chances are someone you know also knows Masoud.Masoud and his family are grateful for your prayers and support.

One day a little girl is placed in your arms.One day that little girl says her first word.One day she takes her first steps, and before you know it...One day she is off to kindergarten.Then, one day, life changes.Ella is a beautiful 6 year old. She sings and dances like it’s her job. She spends countless summer days playing at the beach, and school year afternoons with friends, family, or belting out her favorite songs like Moana’s “How Far I’ll Go.” She knows that she wants to be a singer or a princess, (or maybe even both), one day when she grows up. Ella has won the praise and acknowledgement of her teachers for being a conscientious and courteous student and an amazing friend and classmate. On Monday, February 12, 2018, Ella stayed home from school with a rash her mom, Tracy, believed to be Fifths Disease. While on the way to the pediatrician’s office for a quick check to be sure, Ella’s dad, Mike, noticed a strange lump on her lower left back. Because Ella and Tracy had attended a roller skating party 3 days prior to this visit, the pediatrician diagnosed the non-painful lump as a muscle spasm, along with her confirmation that Ella had Fifths Disease. When the lump did not change two days later, Tracy contacted the pediatrician, asking for further exploration of its cause. The pediatrician agreed, and Tracy set an appointment for an ultrasound at Hasbro Children’s Hospital in Providence, RI for 4pm on Friday, February 16. By 4:15pm on the day of the ultrasound, Tracy, Mike, and Ella were being ushered to the Emergency Room at Hasbro for further testing on what the doctors determined was a soft tissue lump. From there...that day, and the ones that immediately followed... everything became a blur. Encouraging test results came back one by one, giving the family hope, until the MRI displayed every family’s worst fear; Ella has Ewing’s Sarcoma. Through this process, a family learns a lot. They learn to take their train that until now, had encountered the same bumps and turbulence most families experience, and switch it to a track of uncertainty. A track that is often plagued with long waits and dark tunnels, much like a roller coaster at Disney World, Ella’s favorite place to visit. Parents learn to say, “My daughter has cancer,” and only cry on those days when they wonder why, and they tell people how they’ve learned that Childhood Cancer Research is devastatingly underfunded. They learn how to tell their daughter that she will lose her hair, and that she won’t be able to regularly attend school where all of her friends continue their routine. They learn how to research and explain medical procedures, while fielding questions and giving care to their child. Family members and friends learn to ask, “What can I do,” or “What do you need” before even saying “Hello.”Most importantly, a 6 year old girl learns that even though she doesn’t feel sick, there is a thing in her body called a tumor that the doctors removed...mostly...but that some sneaky cells hung around to try to make more mischief. She learns where her chemo port is, and that the awesome nurses and doctors at Hasbro treat her with gentle kindness even when performing physically difficult procedures. Ella learned that these cells she has need chemotherapy to go away for good. And that’s what they will do. They will go away for good, because no singing princess will stand for a devious disease blocking her way.Parents learn that, even with healthcare, there’s unpaid leave from work and travel expenses that add up. The doctors at Sloan Kettering in New York City are specialists in Ewing’s, and they have agreed to see Ella and help treat her. This will mean regular trips from Rhode Island to New York. Even with donated sick days, Tracy does not have enough sick time to get her through the eight plus months of chemo Ella will need to kick Ewing’s Sarcoma to the curb. Even after the chemo, there will be months of radiation, blood work, scans, and doctor’s visits to make sure our singing princess Ella remains on the road to recovery.Tracy, Ella, and Mike have a long way to go before their train can switch back to a more well-lit, less tumultuous track. Until then, they need our help so finances do not add extra bumps and worries to their already burdened travels. Because...One day, Ella and her family will celebrate new milestones.One day will be the last chemo treatment.One day will be the first of countless clear scans and tests.One day we will all join Ella and her family in celebrating a cure for everyone.Ella, Tracy, and Mike are forever grateful for the kindness of friends, family, and especially those who give without ever having met Ella. She promises to send you an autographed picture when she becomes a famous, singing princess.

Dear Friends and Family, Matt was in a very serious mountain biking accident on June 23rd  in Aspen and broke his neck. He was airlifted to Saint Anthony’s Hospital in Lakewood, Colorado where the surgeons performed a 7 hour surgery where they were able to repair his spinal column by fusing several vertebrae.  There have been some positive signs of Matt moving his arms and legs, but at this point the doctors are unable to give any definitive prognosis or timeline for his recovery. As you know, Matt and Janelle are going to need help caring for Davis and Ivy while Matt recovers. Friends of the family have set up this GoFundMe page as a gift to Matt and Janelle to help ease some of their burdens. Our hope is that we can raise enough funds to pay for a part-time nanny, cleaning services, and other household help they may need for at least the next three months.

We are raising funds to allow our 3-year old profoundly deaf child to have a cochlear implant surgery as soon as possible as recommended by ENT specialist. This will be Elroi’s 5th surgery in his young life, after having been diagnosed with CHARGE syndrome (explained below) not too long after birth. Every amount you can give is utterly appreciated to help us give our Elroi the gift of hearing (and consequently speech)! THANK YOU SO MUCH! Here’s a background into Elroi’s few years on God’s beautiful earth so far.Our Miracle baby Elroi was born on the 29th of January 2015. He was born without opened nostrils which impeded his ability to breathe, a condition the doctors termed as Bilateral Choanal Atresia. Since babies are obligatory nose breathers he was not able to compensate by breathing through his mouth. At only a few minutes old, he experienced his first of three pulmonary cardiac arrests and had to be resuscitated, and several pinches administered just so he could stay alive. It was scary as a parent to see the frail body of our supposed bundle of joy go through this life threatening experience; his color would turn pink when he cried, meaning he had sufficient oxygen in his body, to an eerie purple when his mouth was closed, which meant he was oxygen-deficient. Elroi was rushed to the major teaching hospital in Ghana called Korle Bu Teaching Hospital as a matter of urgency, where a life-saving operation of perforating the nasal cavity was performed. This was not to be the only time he would go under the knife. Elroi has had other operations since this first one, including removal of the stents, and a heart surgery at five months to close an open duct.To compound issues, Elroi was later diagnosed to be profoundly deaf in both ears which led to another diagnosis of CHARGE syndrome. This is known to occur only in 1 in every 10,000 births. It is a complex combination of medical conditions which includes Coloboma, heart defects, choanal atresia, growth retardation, genital abnormalities, and ear abnormalities (severe to profound sensoneural hearing loss in both ears)After several trials and speech therapy with two fitted hearing aids, the doctors in Ghana concluded that a cochlear implant would be the best solution in aiding him to hear.Unfortunately this procedure is not done in our homeland Ghana, hence our doctor suggested Nationwide Children’s Hospital (NCH) in Columbus, Ohio. NCH requested to redo all the assessments to ascertain if truly our son was eligible for the Cochlear implants. This reassessment came at a cost of $6,000 which we paid in full prior to the  tests getting done. After the various evaluations were conducted it was confirmed that Elroi is indeed a candidate for a cochlear implant in order for him to have the gift of hearing. With hearing, Elroi will be able to speak as these two essential life skills are interdependent in Elroi’s case.Now..to get the cochlear implant surgery done comes with a price tag of $50,000. The Nationwide Children’s Hospital has requested payment in full before surgery can be done, and as per the Cochlear Implant Specialist we met with, the surgery needs to be done as soon as possible…the further we delay the further Elroi’s speech development is impacted negatively. A lot has been committed so far to get us to this stage and your benevolence will be greatly appreciated to give our little miracle the needed hearing required to complete his full cycle development. Any amount will be greatly appreciated.

Christina is the sweetest girl you would ever want to meet! She has an infectious smile and loves to laugh with her family and friends. Christina also loves to eat, but because of a rare disease called Chronic Intestinal Pseudo-obstruction, she can’t. Her digestive system won’t move and absorb nutrients like it should, instead food causes a great deal of pain, nausea and retching. The doctors at Cleveland Clinic have told her she is in intestinal failure and the only hope that remains is a modified multi-visceral transplant, which means she needs a stomach, duodenum, small intestine and pancreas transplant to have hope to eat - and to live. She is currently awaiting transplant.Right now Christina is receiving all of her nutrition through a surgically placed IV line that provides the nutrition her digestive system can’t (Total Parenteral Nutrition), but without the ability to eat anything she will go into liver failure, and as she knows all too well, long-term use of surgically placed IV lines brings life-threatening infections. Please join us in praying that a transplant will happen soon.During the transplant evaluation at Cleveland Clinic Christina was told the cost would be in excess of a million dollars, and although she has insurance, there are significant amounts insurance is expected not to pay. As part of the evaluation she was counseled to begin fundraising to help cover the costs of transplant, which is why this page is being created. In addition to medical costs, Christina and her mom, who will be her primary caregiver (required for transplant), will have to stay in Cleveland awaiting transplant because Christina cannot be more than three hours away when she receives the call that a donor has been found. After transplant she will be required to stay in the area for a minimum of 3-6 months. No travel or living expenses are covered by insurance.Christina is a delightful young lady with a big smile and a heart full of dreams for the future. Will you please help her raise the funds she needs to get a transplant? Asking for help is hard, but with your help, she will move forward to being able to eat again and live a life full of hope for a bright future.You can follow Christina’s journey at christinasjourney.com. Please help however you can! Please share this page! Please pray for Christina!

Justin is a member of the HSI San Diego SRT team.  A piece of equipment being tested during recent training malfunctioned and resulted in major injuries to his lower extremities.  Justin has undergone 2 major surgeries since the incident, and it is anticipated that he will undergo at least one more.  The road to recovery will include months of rehabilitation both at the hospital, and will eventually transition to in-home care.The donations will be used by Justin's wife, Lyndsey,  to make necessary modifications to his home that will allow for a speedy recovery.

We come to you with heavy hearts for our sister in Christ, Jen Eccleston. We have known Jen for many  years through our church. She is a wife to Matt and mother to three beautiful children. Recently, Jen went to the ER for what she believed was a kidney stone. The CT not only confirmed the kidney stone, but also found a 13.5 cm mass in her liver, and two soft tissue masses. The natural doctor Jen has been working with the last year has specifically been working on her circulating cancer cells (a/k/a CTCs). All of this work has not been in vain as her cell count is now down to 2. Upon follow up, a PET scan has revealed that the cancer has spread.  The natural doc has a connection with a specialist in CA, Dr. Ahvie. Dr. Ahvie is an M.D. and graduated from Johns Hopkins. He takes very difficult cancer cases and offers targeted approaches with chemotherapy, as well as another therapy that acts as a cancer vaccine of sorts. (They still have more information to obtain.) The targeted therapy would be based on the RGCC testing that Jen did with her natural doc that outlined the exact chemo that gave her the highest death rate of cancer cells. Dr. Ahvie has been consulting with Jen’s natural doc and believes she would be a candidate for his therapy. He indicated how happy he is for the work that has been done to lower the CTC count, as it’s important to his therapy as well.This is where you come in. Jen and her family need prayer warriors to rally behind her. The specialized treatment from Dr. Ahvie in CA is not covered by Jen’s medical sharing company, so she also needs monetary funds to cover testing, traveling, procedures, etc. Upon her return from the initial treatment, Jen will need to keep up Dr. Ahvie’s protocol at home, which will involve costs as well.Please join kingdom forces with us to pray specifically for Jen and her family. And please consider giving a monetary gift for these mounting medical costs. God bless you, and please continue to follow Jen’s journey here as we give updates. We would be so grateful to have you share this on social media or email.Abbie Brigham and Mary Graves____________________________________________Prayer Requests by Jen:Please pray that I would have spiritual and physical strength, not fear the future, and trust in my Sovereign God completely. May He be glorified.Please pray for my dear husband, Matt, as he works tirelessly to provide working his full time job and extra side jobs to pay for medical expenses. Matt also faithfully serves the kids and me at home as I have not been operating at full speed.Pray for my children to trust in Christ and draw near to Him. They also serve our family so sweetly. Pray for their strength and for God to bless them.Of course, please pray for total healing and for us to have wisdom as we navigate the path the Lord has for us to walk.Please pray for God to provide for my medical expenses.Please pray for doctors to have wisdom for the best treatment.Please pray that I would be able to eat and sleep and hold my weight. The doctor emphasized this is very important.Thank you from our hearts. We praise God for every prayer, every kindness, and His provision.  - Jen

Our friend Isaac has been diagnosed with cancer.  None of us know how much time we have on this Earth, but since Isaac has touched each of us through his generosity, knowledge, compassion, humor, and leadership we want him to enjoy his time with his family. We also want to help care for his family if he becomes unable to work. The situation is not good and funds are needed now. Beyond fundraising, the Conway family might enjoy a meal or housecleaning service, donation of a family activity or getaway, or just a visit or phone call to show you care.

In Venezuela, Laura’s insurance will only pay USD $15 for her cancer treatment. Her medications alone cost more than USD $50,000.Laura’s story (para Español ir al final de este texto / look below for Japanese)------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- I was recently diagnosed with Stage III Melanoma, the most life-threatening and aggressive form of skin cancer. Battling an advanced form of cancer is challenging in any circumstance, but in Venezuela, a country suffering a widespread humanitarian crisis, it can feel impossible.I support myself and my 5 year-old daughter illustrating children’s books. Venezuela’s runaway hyperinflation, has cut my income to less than USD $20 a month. For this same reason, my insurance only pays USD $15 for my cancer treatment.The challengesFor years, Venezuela has made international headlines for its severe food and medicine shortages. We are currently experiencing the highest inflation rates in the world and a crisis with no end in sight.Millions have fled the country, seeking refuge abroad. I chose to stay in Venezuela to care for my mother, and protect my family’s small dairy farm. Even if I find the resources to pay for treatment, the life-saving immunotherapy drugs I need aren’t available in Venezuela. I will have to source the drugs internationally, which could add hundreds of thousands of dollars  to the cost of my treatment. Nobody wants to plead for money from friends and family, but I have no choice. I simply cannot pay for treatment on my own.I am only 44 years old and I have every intention of seeing my daughter, Iroma, grow into a beautiful young woman. I will not let cancer or the Venezuelan crisis win this fight. Please help me defeat this horrible disease and overcome these dire circumstances.  I hope to use your donations to pay for the medications, surgeries and expenses as I receive my treatment. Any donation, big or small, helps reach our USD $50,000 goal. Each gift means the world to me. Thank you for your love and compassion, Laura. -------En Venezuela, el seguro médico de Laura sólo cubre $15 (USD) dólares para su tratamiento contra el cáncer. Ella necesita al menos $50 mil dólares para pagar los medicamentos.La situación de Laura y los retos de enfermarse en un país en ruinas---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Queridos amigos y familiares: Hace poco fui diagnosticada con el tipo de cáncer de piel más agresivo y peligroso:  melanoma etapa 3. Soy madre de una niña de apenas cinco añitos, a quién mantengo con mis ingresos como ilustradora de cuentos para niños.Superar un cáncer y pagar los gastos de un tratamiento tan costoso es una proeza en cualquier país, pero en la Venezuela de hoy, sumergida en una crisis humanitaria sin precedentes en su historia, la lucha es mucho más cuesta arriba.Debido a la hiperinflación en Venezuela, la más alta del mundo, y a la aberración en los controles de cambio, mis ingresos equivalen apenas a menos de $20 dólares al mes. Mi seguro sólo cubre unos $15 dólares para gastos médicos. Enfermarse en Venezuela cuesta la vida En Venezuela, la escasez crónica de comida y medicinas cobra vidas a diario. Millones de Venezolanos se han visto obligados a abandonar el país en busca de protección y una vida digna. Decidí quedarme en mi país para cuidar de mi madre, y proteger nuestra pequeña granja familiar en Los Andes, que se ha visto amenazada por invasores.Incluso si tuviese los recursos económicos para pagar mi tratamiento, los medicamentos que necesito para la inmunoterapia que me salvaría la vida no están disponibles en Venezuela. Para recibir el tratamiento, tendría que importarlos o trasladarme a otro país, lo que podría añadir cientos de miles de dólares al costo de mi tratamiento. A nadie le gusta pedir dinero a sus amigos y familiares, pero no tengo ninguna otra opción, ya que simplemente no tengo los recursos para pagar los costos yo misma.Tengo sólo 44 años, mi mayor anhelo es proteger a mi hija Iroma y verla crecer. No permitiré que el cáncer o la crisis de Venezuela me de por vencida. Te pido por favor que me ayudes a luchar contra esta enfermedad y mis circunstancias.  Las donaciones serán utilizadas para pagar por los medicamentos, cirugías y demás gastos médicos. Cualquier monto es bienvenido y ayuda a llegar a nuestra meta de $50 mil dólares.  Cada ayuda es un regalo que significa el mundo para mi.  Gracias por tu ayuda y compasión,  Laura-------私はラウラといいます。ベネズエラで、私の保険では１５ドルしか出ないのですが、私の治 療にかかる医療費は、５万ドル以上です。診断されたガンは、ステージ3の悪性黒色腫で、皮膚がんの中で、 一番致死的な種類です。ステージ３のガンと戦うことは、どこでも辛いことですが、人道上 の危機にあるベネズエラの場合、本当に、それは無理に思えます。今、絵本のイラストを描く仕事で、自分と５歳の娘の生活費を稼い でいますが、ハイパーインフレーションの影響で、今の月給は、約 ２０ドルしか貰えません。実は、お金が完全に用意できても、それだけで治すことはできませ ん。必要な免疫療法薬物は、ベネズエラでは販売していないため、 外国で探すことが必要になります。親戚や友達、知り合いの皆に、こういうお願いすることは、自分に とって物凄く大変なことですが、自分の力だけでは、医療費を絶対 に支払うことが出来ません。44歳のお母さんとして、娘のイロマちゃんを立派な女性になるま で、必ず一緒にいたいんです。私は、 ガンやベネズエラの金融危機に、絶対に負けたくない！どうか助けてください、この大変な状態を乗り越えて、私は、病気 に打ち勝ちたい。皆の寄付で、イタリアのミラノで治療が受けられる可能性がありま すが、ビザを取るためには、 医療費をちゃんと支払えることを確認し、約束するための書類が必 要となります。皆の協力は、何よりも宝物です。みんなを愛しています。本当にあ りがとうございます。ラウラ---------
Medical Report (Informe Medico): the images below are a report of Laura's diagnose.------------------------------------The drugs Laura needs are Ipilumimab and Nivolumab.Our Campaign-----------------------------------Our campaign was organized by Laura's sister, Lea Stagno, who lives in New York and is working tirelessly to ensure that Laura gets the lifesaving treatment she needs. The funds will be used to pay for or reimburse Laura's surgeries, hospitalizations, medications, travel, legal expenses relating to travel outside of Venezuela and living expenses while she is receiving treatment and examinations related to her cancer diagnosis. Unfortunately we cannot transfer the money directly to Laura because GoFundMe requires a US-based SSN, and as GoFundMe is subjecting Venezuelan's to extreme scrutiny, we want to let you know that the money will be transferred directly to Lea Stagno's account in the US and later used to directly pay for Laura's expenses or else transferred to Laura's Account here in the US. Thank you so much for your support.

Hi everyone,My little brother, Nathan Dyer, had the incredible opportunity to travel with my cousin to Morocco while they visited her husband's family. He was having an amazing time riding camels and exploring - all while wearing a replica Indiana Jones hat!About two weeks in, Nathan came down with symptoms that looked like traveler's sickness. My cousins took him to see a doctor where he was hydrated and given some antibiotics. Days later, he still was not improving - in fact, he was getting worse. He was so weak that he could not even stand. My cousins took him to a hospital where he became worse and worse, until he was in a coma-like state.My mom started working with his traveler's insurance to get him back to the States for better treatment, but he was not stable enough to move that far. It was ultimately decided that he would be flown to Paris, France. Luckily, his traveler's insurance covered my mom's flight to Paris and she was there to meet him when he arrived. The French medical staff told her that he had not been properly treated while in Morocco. Nathan had a bacterial infection, was on a ventilator, was close to kidney failure, and had had at least one seizure.  His kidneys are functioning better now, but he has had another seizure. He was moved to another hospital in Paris to be treated by a specialist, but his initial diagnosis was found to be incorrect. He is still only minimally conscious and we know that the road to recovery is going to be a long one.My family is hard-working and we do not have much. While our focus is on Nathan, we cannot help but worry about how we are going to pay for his international healthcare after his traveler's insurance stops covering care. Nathan and my mom are on BadgerCare, which does not cover healthcare internationally. Nathan was very lucky to be included in my cousin's travel plans and budget and, as a hard worker himself, was able to pay for his plane ticket to Morocco with his own savings from working at the Lake Geneva Cruise Line. My mom works for hourly wages and is currently not working as she is with Nathan in France - we have no money coming in. I am a graduate student and do not have much to begin with. I am leaving to see my little brother soon, which means that I won't be working either.We need a lot of support. Your donation will help my family with...-Plane tickets-Lodging-Food-Medical expenses-To help us stay on our feet after Nathan gets better and my family has not been workingWe have already accumulated $4,200 worth of medical expenses from Nathan's care in Morocco and nearly $26,000 worth of medical expenses from Nathan's current hospital in Paris; this does not include the first hospital that he was treated at in Paris and the additional costs that build up with each passing day. While news sources are emphasizing our efforts to bring Nathan back to the United States as soon as possible, he does not have a diagnosis. Because we do not know what is causing his illness yet, we do not know if he is stable or what other complications may arise if he tries to fly right away. We do not know when he will be able to fly the distance from France to Wisconsin.  This GoFundMe will be used to address all of the above listed costs as they arise - not just the potential full cost of an air ambulance. Nathan is a smart, talented guy with the driest sense of humor and a lot of fight in him. He deserved to have the adventure of a lifetime in Morocco. We want to make sure that he can be well taken care of and surrounded by the people who love him.Thank you,Rachel Dyer*updated 5/2/2018

My darling daughter Heather was diagnosed with aggressive glioblastoma  brain cancer 2 years ago when she was 39 yrs old.  She is married with 3 young children ages 12, 10 and 7.  This cancer is known to be very difficult to treat and has a poor prognosis.   She underwent brain surgery, radiation, and chemotherapy,  finally completing treatment in December 2016.    Heather was monitored with brain MRI's every 3 months.  She was almost back to her old self after about a year off treatment.   In June 2018 we were devastated  to find out that the cancer was back.  Heather had another brain resection, and she is doing okay, very functional, but tires easily.  When she met  the neurosurgeon and neuro-oncologist they mentioned that there are clinical trials looking at a very promising treatment called Opdivo a Check Point inhibitor.  Currently the drug is in early testing in brain cancer.  Unfortunately at this time there are no clinical trials for recurrent brain cancers like Heather's.  The Opdivo is not yet approved for brain cancer so unfortunately the insurance will not cover the cost of the medication, which is about $150,000.00 for a year of infusions.  There have been so many of you that have asked how they might be able to help us.  Assistance with the cost of this medication would be most helpful.  Heather will be getting her 1st infusion on Thursday and will continue to receive the medication every 2 weeks.  Unfortunately,  the cancer is very likely to return but we are praying for  the longest remission possible.  Extending her life will be priceless.   Thank you for any assistance you can provide!

~ “Where there is great love, there are always miracles.” ~ Willa CatherI would love to tell the story of a beautiful family from the island of Trinidad & Tobago … our neighbors who became our family. A family who is filled with such love and hope during their difficult journey, that they are inspiring everyone they meet. Their baby boy needs your help today…Meet Jason Jagdeo and Marissa Naidoo-Jagdeo…loving parents of Baby Michael Anthony Jagdeo (their little Hero aka “Miracle Mikey”).    Background: On November 2nd, 2015, Jason and Marissa’s lives changed forever; their beautiful angel, Michael Anthony Jagdeo, was born. Unfortunately, his birth was so traumatic that it became life-threatening to both mommy and baby. By nothing short of a miracle, they both survived. We’ve affectionately nicknamed him our “Miracle Mikey”.Mikey was kept in NICU for 3 weeks…fighting for his life. He had suffered brain damage, so extensive that doctors predicted that he would never walk or talk; this news devastated his parents, but they never gave up hope! They have faith that Mikey will defy all odds.On his second day of life, Mikey’s seizures began … and evolved over time, into a rare form of epilepsy, West Syndrome, resulting in hundreds of daily seizures. They were told that there is no cure and coupled with Mikey’s extensive brain damage, his prognosis was extremely poor. Yet, his parents never gave up hope. Together with a team of doctors, they cycled through many different combinations of medicines until they found a regime which drastically reduced his seizures! Doctors were amazed! Another miracle! However, because of the extent of his brain damage, doctors predict that his seizures would continue to evolve over his lifetime…and now, they have begun to evolve. Although heartbroken, his parents have faith that Mikey’s healing is on the way! They embody this quote: “where there is great love…there are always miracles.” There is no doubt that because of their unwavering love, faith and devotion, Mikey will continue to defy all odds.How you can help:                                                                                              For the first time, in a long time, this beautiful family has been given some hope. The specialists have ruled out surgery as an option because Mikey’s brain damage is too widespread. They have instead recommended Hyperbaric Oxygen Therapy to improve his quality of life and to reduce, and hopefully eliminate, his seizures. Since Mikey continues to defy all odds, his family believes that another miracle is in the making. To see Mikey walk, talk, run and play one day would be the greatest blessing ever.However, to avoid any untoward adverse effects as a result of Mikey’s extensive brain injury and the complex, evolving nature of his seizure disorder, this specialized treatment would have to be accessed out of country, under the careful guidance of a specialist with more than 30 years experience in treating children with seizure disorders.We would need to raise at least US$89,000.00 to make Mikey’s dream a reality. Through your kindness today, we can do this!Mikey is a little hero who bravely fights his battles every day and lights up the world with his love! He is an angel on this earth, whose eyes radiate hope and determination. He just needs a little help from you right now to get him to his breakthrough.His parents are two of the most beautiful souls you will ever meet. Despite their difficult journey, they are uplifting and inspiring everyone with their love, faith and joy! To see them in tears shatters your heart to pieces. They are blessings to others; let us bless them in return with our kindness. They wish to do everything possible for Mikey because they have faith that he will do the impossible…as he has done thus far! His story is truly a miracle in motion…..

Hello all Fountain Day Families and Alumni!For the past few weeks, our FDS favorites Dave and Ranum have been spending most of their days and nights at the Children’s Hospital of Los Angeles. Their 5 month old son, Levi, has been fighting for his life and I’m happy to report that he is improving everyday! But Levi’s condition is still precarious (the doctors are trying to figure of the cause of his cardiac issues), and Dave and Ranum are still dealing with all of life’s obstacles and medical bills.  Simran Baidwan and I were talking one morning after drop off and thought that a go fund me might be the best way to help this very loved family! Please share this quickly and often! This family needs the support of our amazing FDS community!

Our beloved fellow football official, Tod Reese, has recently been  diagnosed with a very aggressive form of pancreatic cancer.   Tod is a dedicated adoring father of 2 daughters, Delaney and Kaitlin.  He is a loving and caring husband to his wife, Holly.   Tod is undergoing every treatment possible to help in his fight against cancer.  As you might imagine this has taken a heavy burden for him and his family both emotionally and financially.In our efforts to assist Tod and his family with these challenges we are asking that you dig deep into your heart and say some prayers for Tod and his  amazing family as they work through this period on their life.  We also kindly request that you find it within yourself to offer a donation of any size to  Tod and his family through these trying times via this GoFundMe page.  Any and all amounts are very much welcomed by the family and they send their appreciation in advance for your prayers and thoughts.  Tod has helped mentor and advocate for football officials for over 40 years.  He has been a clinician, a fellow on-field official, and has inspired many to achieve the highest levels of football officiating which includes some officials that work today in the NFL.As great as Tod is as a football official during the game he is an even better teacher of how to be an exceptional human being.  I was honored to have him on my crew for my first year as a Referee. He made me better and the crew better each and every game we had both on and off the football field.We kindly ask that you help us raise money to offset the financial obligations in Tod's battle against this horrific disease.  With your help, love and prayers we will see Tod working another college football game in the near future.  And we can expect he'll be there along our side making everyone else around him just that much more better and kinder!

For many, Ana Roman represents the heart and soul of the Ralph Lauren Corporation. Known as both the office mom and the sweetest woman in the company, she has always gone out of her way to make her colleagues’ days a little brighter and always better. And now, more than ever, she needs us to return the favor.In February, Ana suffered a fall, and had to leave the office for extensive shoulder surgery. She faced the procedure with the same courage and determination she approaches any obstacle. However, while recovering, she suffered a major heart attack and stroke and is now in a coma. Her doctors are still unsure of her prognosis, but her family is hopeful for a miracle. And if anyone can pull off a miracle, it would be Ana.Ana’s loving husband, Jose, has been by her side daily, as has her mother, brother and sisters. Her amazing son, Joseph, has been juggling his university studies, coordinating family efforts, while also managing the lines of communication to keep us all informed on her progress. The family has asked for nothing but prayers, well wishes, and good vibes. But there is much more we can do.We are all aware that even with insurance, emergency medical costs can be exorbitant and overwhelming. All those seemingly small individual costs add up quickly to compound an already stressful situation. And even when Ana wakes, the road to full recovery will most likely be long and arduous.The best way to give back to Ana is to take care of her family. We created this fund to alleviate some of the imminent financial concerns, so they can continue to be there with her and for her. The money raised will go directly to them to use for medical bills, transportation costs, and to provide support and care for them so they can focus on her.

￼￼￼Shortly after Mother's Day, our family was rocked by the news that Amy was diagnosed with aggressive Stage 4 Uterine Cancer that had spread to the lining of her abdomen. Two weeks later she was in Chicago at Northwestern Hospital undergoing the removal of her uterus, ovaries, fallopian tubes and the omentum where tumors were found. The surgery was successful in removing everything more than 1 centimeter but we learned that there was a splattering of tiny spots of cancer scattered throughout her pelvic/abdominal area.  Her pathology report came back and after deep research and  many conversations with Gynecological Oncologists and Naturopathic Oncologists,  she and Mike faced the hard reality that the traditional route--- Surgery/High Dose Chemotherapy/ Radiation- has a very poor success rate.They were told that chemotherapy would not be curative. Chemo isn't as successful because this type of cancer has a high and rapid recurrence rate that can happen even before the body has recovered from the initial round of chemo.  This leaves patients who can't do more chemo with no treatment options to handle the recurrence.With this reality facing her, Amy and Mike, after much prayer, feel that traditional chemo is the wrong choice for her and have made the decision to seek Integrative Naturopathic treatment- that combines low dose chemo and immune boosting therapies to help her body become stronger. She and Mike will leave for a clinic near the US/Mexico border on July 19th. They expect to be at the clinic for 3 to 5 weeks and will then return with a plan she will continue at home. While the Naturopathic choice may seem bold to us at first, in reality she has made a very logical decision to reject traditional treatment. Our family is behind her decision 100% and believe that God has led her down this path for a reason. Since Amy's health insurance only covers the conventional chemo/radiation route, we are asking friends and family to help us raise money to make the financial side of this a little easier to bear so that Amy can focus on healing and strength to keep up with their two precious and energetic boys. The costs include time at the clinic, at home treatment costs, supplements, infusions, missed wages and travel.We ask you continue to pray for Mike, Amy, Evan and Andrew and for our entire family. Thanks to the power of your continued prayer, we have felt our initial devastation lift and the light of God's promises start shining through. Thank you for continuing to pray for healing, wisdom and lots of joy filled days as we embrace this detour with determination.[When you pray, you must believe and not doubt, because the one who doubts is like a wave of the sea, blown and tossed by the wind.— James 1:6]

Hi there! My name is Atianna and I am asking you to please help save my son Nick’s life! Nick was Diagnosed with Stage 4 High Risk Neuroblastoma on May 24, 2018.Help Save ‘Super Nick’! We need you!I'm a Single Mom of Three Kids.Nick is a 4 year old little boy with two siblings; Jasmine 12 and David 7. My beautiful son, Nick, is the bravest and most amazing person I have ever known  in my life. His smile hardly ever seems to leave his face. His warm and silly personality has everyone falling head over heels for him. Our nurses never seem to forget him! Nurses visit our room from all floors of the hospital just to say hello, as he leaves a lasting impression with everyone. Choc hospital has named my sweet little boy, ‘Super Nick’ because of his continuous positive spirit and endless level of courage! Our nurses made a poster ‘Super Nicks Room’ and hung it on his hospital room door for everyone to see!Our story began in the most complex and confusing way.. Nick appeared perfectly healthy without any health issues prior to dropping him off to school and rushing to work one morning. It all started as a regular day at school for Nick.. Until he jumped from a little toddler slide while playing at school and hurt his ankle. When I picked him up from school that day, we rushed to our pediatrician and then to mission hospital for an X-ray.. no breaks or fractures were found...we were sent home. Strangely, Nicks pain did not improve with each passing day and instead traveled to his hip and thigh area. With numerous visits to the doctor, including an orthopedic specialist and repeated X-rays, we were told that it was an assumed pulled muscle that should heal with some time.Nicks pain was horrific, unexplainable and worrisome. I took my 4 year old baby boy to our pediatrician a handful of times, each time asking why the pain was traveling to different areas of his legs and back.. each time we were sent home without the right answer. We were distracted by the fall and by Nicks healthy weight, appetite and demeanor. Our pediatrician decided to get some blood tests taken from Nick.. One abnormal lab led us to CHOC children’s hospital Emergency Room, where we came in contact with a very special Doctor that said she would admit us and not let us leave until she got to the bottom of this. Nicks labs were taken again and had worsened from the last ones taken. The following day Nick had an emergency MRI and Catscan done under anesthesia. Soon the sky became dark as we were given the diagnosis of Stage IV High Risk neuroblastoma cancer on May 24, 2018. My world truly turned upside down. How could my innocent child be given a 66% chance of survival from Choc and 30% survival from the cancer association?  All these numbers and statistics gave me little hope, until one day I had decided that we would fight as though we were certain that Nick was the surviving and thriving number. Currently, my son is being treated at CHOC children’s hospital in Orange, California.Over the next year and a half we have a road map set by the oncology team at CHOC that includes three phases of aggressive treatment.  Nicky will endure 2 surgeries within the first phase of treatment which includes 6 rounds of of aggressive inpatient chemotherapy, the retrieval of stem cells from Nick that will be frozen and used to ‘save him’ after intense radiation and ongoing high doses of chemo in phase two of treatment.  Phase 2 of treatment will include 6 weeks of continuous inpatient stay for three cycles with 3 to 4 week breaks in between.. and finally, a stem cell transplant (using his own stem cells) during his Immunotherapy in phase 3 of treatment to ‘save him’ from the damage that radiation and chemo will cause. There is a hope for the possibility of more advanced treatment in Memorial Sloan Kettering Hospital of N.Y. that is the one and only facility to offer cancer vaccines to protect patients from reoccurring cancer after treatment.Nick will be treated with 3F8, which is Memorial Sloan Kettering's proprietary antibody against GD2. It is an experimental medication waiting to be approved by the FDA. It is made only at Memorial Sloan Kettering and other hospitals don't have access to it at this time.Also, Memorial Sloan Kettering has a clinical trial ongoing for a vaccine therapy after GD2 therapy, but it is only available on trial at Memorial Sloan Kettering, CHOC doesn’t  have access to it. Memorial Sloan Kettering treatment is different than what most other centers are using as ‘standard of care’ for this type of rare and aggressive form of cancer. We would end up living in New York  periodically for 2 -3 months each time, getting rounds of radiation and numerous rounds of immune and antibody therapies.  I have been tirelessly searching for more options.  Through outreach to many doctors and organizations, Nick has been offered an opportunity to participate in a new alternative treatment that is not covered by insurance. Please help Nick in his battle with Neuroblastoma cancer!Phase 2  of treatment for Nick, will consist of 6 weeks inpatient of radiation and chemo at a time, then home for a short while and back again with three rotations like this. If Nick survives then phase 3 of treatment begins, which is what we look forward to, Immuno therapy. The doctors explained that Nicks risks are, infertility, deafness, becoming cross eyed, severe pain from radiation, learning disabilities, relapse of cancer, new types of cancers that can be caused by the treatment, and much more. This is all an absolute nightmare. We pray that Nick will fight this cancer and win!! We will fight this battle with him! He is the strongest, bravest, funniest, most affectionate little boy in the world! Nick loves music, it makes him feel better. He receives music therapy at CHOC to cheer him up and heal his spirit.
